story:
Playwrights’ Theatre is a company dedicated to producing compelling, relevant, thought provoking theatre while simultaneously developing the new works from playwrights around the country, and providing a forum for their work to be shown.

To the Naked Eye is a world premiere play by Seattle playwright James Lyle and directed by Zachariah Robinson. It integrates the designs of local artists Suzi Tucker (set design) Gywn Skone (lighting design) and Savannah Baltazar (costume design).

The show consists of six comedic vignettes that paint the canvas of our multifaceted perception around the meaning of nakedness. This poignant and funny evening ultimately strips away our preconceived notions and reveals three simple truths: Naked people are funny! Naked people are beautiful! Naked people are people!

The deeper theme of the evening challenges the audience to reconsider our common perceptions. It is about stripping away the pretense and being truly and honestly yourself. The use of nudity in these pieces is a metaphor challenging the audience to strip away their own false perceptions and witness the beauty that appears when allowing ourselves to be fully present. Only by courageously allowing our vulnerability, our flaws and imperfections to shine as brilliantly as our strengths, can we be free of judgment and insecurity and allow ourselves to truly experience the art that is life. 


To the Naked Eye is scheduled to run at the Cornish Playhouse Studio on the Seattle Center Campus, which we have already leased from June 6th – 28th.  The total cost of facility rental, including rehearsal space is $2,370.   Total labor including designers, actors, director, and IATSI stage hand equals $6,920.78.  Additionally we will need set, props and costumes.

Playwrights' Theatre is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization under Shunpike.  A portion of your donation to Shunpike for the benefit of Playwrights' Theatre is tax deductable.

story:
Edge Theatre Company has three facets of passion that we focus on – Professional Theatre, Youth Theatre and Theatre for Special Needs.  The Professional aspect is the newest addition to Edge, and the purpose behind it is to give the students in both the Youth and Special Needs ensembles to intern and experience Chicago stages alongside professional, trained actors and technicians.  Into the Woods is a perfect beginning to this merge of ideas, as it has ensemble from all three facets.  Your contribution to Into the Woods is going directly to funding for the production – everything from rights to the show, space rentals for rehearsals and performances, to costumes, props and programs – but more importantly, your contribution ensures, both educationally and professionally, that Edge is able to continue its mission of empowering youths and young adults through a creative and open environment.  We are seeking out to produce the best, most creative and magical theatrical experiences for performers, students and audiences.

What We Need & What You Get

Our production total cost is  $2845.00 Rights, Royalties and Rentals take up half of that amount, where publicity takes up the next quarter and what is left of the budget is given to costumes, props and whatever else needs monetary attention. As I’m sure that you’ve noticed, our IndieGoGo Goal is less than the budget of this show – this is so that we may feasibly reach our goal in the amount of time that we have to fundraise.

We have an incredibly talented ensemble on both sides of this production, and the IndieGoGo perks reflect that. These Perks range from a simple and enthusiastic “Thank You!” to hand crafted items, to time with our cast and production team.  All perks are being provided or created by our Into the Woods ensemble, such as our Education Staff Sydney Ray and Miquela Cruz, Director Emma Couling, Production Manager Angela Davis and Artistic Director Orion Couling.


We guarantee some of the most unique perks you have ever heard of in any fundraiser! Read on and be delighted! The first few levels are pretty basic but check out the upper levels, you may find something you really enjoy!


...Level 4 at $30 

The Bakers Lucky Scarf 

A hand made, knitted scarf just like the Baker wears in our show. Knitted by the Bakers Wife, Sydney Ray and a ticket. Only 6 available.

Level 5  at $40 

Milky White. 

A super cute hand crafted  Amigurumi (Japanese styled stuff crocheted) cow made by our Stage Manager Angela Davis and a ticket. Only 4 available.

Or

The Witches Bag of Tricks

A custom made, authentic bag of magic. Each pouch is catered to the donor using Celtic and Nordic traditions to bring you good fortune by our spell masters who practice magik in our cast. Positive, powerful and unique. This also includes a ticket!

Level 6 at  $50

Once Upon A Time:

Find the ability to translate the words on the page to vibrant life on stage! Tell your own story with a 45 minutes monologue session with Director Emma Couling. Known for her impeccable text work.

Or

Royal Tombs 

1 hour walk through Graceland Cemetery to see the graves of Chicago's High Kings and Queens and hear their stories!  Guided by our Artistic Director and Chicago Historian, Orion Couling – for you and up to three additional guests per walk through. (Redeemable this upcoming Fall 2014)

Level 7 at $75 

The Tea with a Princess and Prince (kid based)

We'll treat you and your prince or princess like royalty as they enjoy a Pre-matinee tea with our Prince and Princess. Meet other local royal families. Try on capes, sword fight, and take pictures with our royalty. It comes with two tickets for you and your heir to the throne. This event takes place on our first matinee April 6th 1.5 hour before the show


The Royal High Tea(Grown ups)

Mimosas and tasty treats abound as you don your tiara or crown. Lets face it, how often do you want to wear a crown and be treated like the queen or king you are. 

Try on capes, sword fight, and take pictures with our royalty. It comes with two tickets for you and your royal "other.” This event takes place on our first matinee April 13th 1.5 hour before the show.

Level 8 at $100

It Takes Two 

Two tickets, two drink vouchers and Two Baker's scarfs – perfect for you and your companion.  Only 4 available.

Level 9 at $150

Happy Ever After 

Get the royal treatment. You will be announced by our Steward using your most dignified title. Seat in the prestigious comfortable thrones with two tickets to match, two drink vouchers (one per royal), a side table, given two gifts, two crowns and listed as donors in all our publications. (Please note that we only offer two such ceremonies a night so coordination with our company to pick the right one is recommended before selecting this. Email treasureisland8@gmail.com) Only 12 available.


The Impact

What Edge is beginning today with your help, with your donation will not just assist with the current production of Into the Woods, but will also support everything else to come – future musicals, classes, workshops, adaptations, budgets, dreams, the whole process. 

Our past productions have included a staged tribute of The Princess Bride, MacSith (Shakespeare’s Macbeth set in a Star Wars-esque universe), original musicals, script adaptations of screenplays geared towards an educational curriculum, and social change.  Currently we have four projects going on in the Chicagoland area.  Our goal is that these projects foster creativity and nurture the individuals’ artistic essence.  We hope that they take the craft and skills learned with Edge and are able apply it in other aspects of their lives.

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

If you like what you’re reading, every and any contribution will help.  From monetary to positive thoughts and creative vibes.  If you’re interested in getting involved in any of our programs or if you have a youngling that would be interested in our youth programs, please visit our website at edgeoforion.com or drop us an email at treasureisland8@gmail.com.

story:
WHO ARE WE AND WHAT ARE WE DOING

Original Practice Shakespeare Festival

OPS Fest is a team of performers united by two things: our love of Shakespeare's plays and our willingness to be part of a dangerous experiment. "Original Practice," or OP is a technique as well as a goal. We strive to recreate the original conditions in which these plays were produced to best illuminate the drama and historic details surrounding the world's greatest English-language writer.

We believe the plays were performed unrehearsed and without a director, which means even with the help of some unique theatrical skills and features, things often go weird, or scary, often funny, and sometimes very, very wrong. And our audiences love it! We're entering our sixth summer and we are so proud and grateful for the Portland summer Shakespeare fans who have been gathering by the hundreds to sit in the hot sun or the rain and mud to heckle us. THANK YOU, PORTLAND!!

Laurelhurst Festival - The OPS Fest Challenge

Each year, as the company has developed, we've added new titles to our summer touring calendar, and each year, we celebrate our new record in a Laurelhurst Festival, mounting each of the shows in our repertoire once, all in one place, one after another. It's the peak of our season, a huge chunk of our summer performances, and it takes place in beautiful and beloved Laurelhurst Park in SE Portland, so it's lots of fun for the neighbors.

Initially we added one new comedy a year, then expanded to one comedy and one tragedy. This summer brings a total of nine different plays to our season, and Laurelhurst Festival 2014 will span two weekends, Friday, July 18 - Sunday July 27. (Our poor apprentices even have a three-show-day to look forward to!) We hope to eventually test our mettle, muscle, and memories against the model of the 16th century masters, whose schedule regularly involved producing six different plays in six days, or seasons consisting of 26 performances of 16 different plays, a couple of which would be premieres!

Become a Patron of the New Old Arts

Please support our efforts by making a monetary gift towards our Laurelhurst Festival. As fascinating as it is to run into the same limiting factors as our predecessors - the original Original Practicioners - we are not solely conducting the OP experiment as an exercise. Our performers do step into the shoes of 16th century professionals and walk miles in them all summer long, so we are less excited about exploring how they struggled with their model than where it succeeds in 21st century Portland.

Read further to learn more about supporting our festival, what it means to OPS, and what we have to offer your community. Or, if you're ready to give, check out the sidebar to the right of your screen and find a level of giving that matches your means and your corresponding gift!

THE DEAL

What We Need...

Our shows are always free, so we depend on audience donations to cover costs, plus grants and the support of schools and a few private theatre patrons. The base rate for actors to cast this years Laurelhurst Festival alone will cost approximately $4,000!

We humbly request the support of those in our community with the means to help us raise $4,500 - a substantial portion of our operating budget, symbolic of mounting the Laurelhurst Festival. As catchy as it sounds to ask you to "Pay an actor's salary!" this year, our success in this season's campaign will determine our operating budget for next year's festival. We would love to show you what we can do with a significant increase in production value! But none of our actors will be going hungry this summer.

Of course we don't expect all our supporters to be season sponsors. When you join us in the park, we'll ask you to drop a small contribution into a post-show bucket (our version of passing the hat), and if you are able to give more than spare change or cash on hand, we will gladly accept a check or credit card donation on site. Huge thanks to everyone who has given and continues to give regularly in person. We can't do it without you.

...And What You Get

If you are prepared to make a larger scale donation to our Laurelhurst fest, thank you in advance! And please check out the many awesome and hilarious rewards for giving. Patrons of Shakespeare's company were known to favor individual actors, sometimes directly supporting them with personal tips or gifts, sometimes voting with their wallets in other ways, expanding an actor's wardrobe to help him appear wealthier and more attractive on stage, perhaps in turn helping him win larger, more impressive roles. Although we encourage supporters to give on an organizational level, we've taken some inspiration from the older economic structure in designing your perks...

Sponsor an actor and you have the option to have a creative exchange over a role, perhaps inspiring the kind of character, costume, or behaviors you'll see on stage. Business owner? Running for office? Shakespeare's plays are notoriously referential - his audience was used to hearing jabs at rival playwrights, shout outs to favorite taverns, or send ups of contemporary political figures. Find a level of support that works for you and you could orchestrate a better (not to mention more historically accurate) ad lib than we alone can pull off. (See the full list of perks and levels of giving to the right.)

If we don't make our goal this summer, we may not be able to expand to an eleven-show festival next season, but all proceeds will certainly still go towards then development of the company, primarily paying theatre practicioners to exercise their skills on and off stage.

WHY?

The Impact

OPS Fest has been developing our own version of cue script technique over the past six summers, based on the pragmatics of the contemporary stage. (For example, we now allow women to perform!) Many of our long-time performers have begun to master the tricky combination of subtle text analysis, vocal and physical athleticism, and improvisation skills through a combination of training and some truly rigorous experience, impossible to recreate without a viable company. This invaluable development of the performer is not only a gift to our audiences, but also increases their personal value in other theatre circles and careers.

With the help of Ronni Lacroute and the Willakenzie estate, we've been able to hire professional actors at far more competitive rates and find ourselves a home in the local theatre community, sharing actors with sister companies such as Portland Actors Ensemble, Anon It Moves, Portland Shakespeare Project, Fuse Theatre Ensemble, Post 5 Theatre, and Northwest Classical Theatre, among many others, and participating in the city-wide Complete Works Festival - two years to mount all of Shakespeare's plays and poems in honor of the 450th anniversary of his birth and 400th anniversary of his death. Next year, we'll be adding Richard III and Merry Wives of Windsor to our cannon as our contribution to this festival.

The last piece of the puzzle is accessibility. We do our part by keeping costs low so we can expand the reach of our free-of-cost tour into more and diverse neighborhoods. We are able to do this by honing our improvisation skills, trusting our actors, and streamlining production design to match that of The King's Men - an impressively a sustainable model. Relative to the modern tradition of massive set construction and architectural verisimilitude, our universal set is lightweight, compact, and reusable. That and minimal properties are able to meet actors on location in just one pickup truck, so we are able travel all over the greater Portland metro area and beyond.

Now we need you to do your part – assuming our post-show bucket donations stay consistent with previous years, this Indegogo campaign must earn $4,500. That way, we'll be on track for next summer's even larger festival, more and more experienced actors, more extensive training for an ever-growing list of roles, and staffing a few 12-hour production marathons. Not only is it a stunt, but the shows are FUN! Come see for yourself why kids of all ages makes our seasons an integral part of their summer.

HOW?

Risks & Challenges

Shakespeare depicts actors as talented, mentally gymnastic, and hungry.  OPS is proud to focus our annual budget on paying the artists, but 16th century London was a grim period in which to struggle financially, and actors generally did, often oscillating between feast and famine. 400 years later, the state of the arts has evolved, but not been drastically overhauled. Though the theatre is still a hub of cultural life (perhaps most obvious on the summer park tour circuit), live performance competes with countless forms of audio/visual entertainment and other media to bring people together. We have not yet escaped the challenges of arts funding.

OPS Fest also demands a great deal of training and outside preparation from the actor, and for this investment we are dedicated to paying a competitive wage. We offer training in techniques unique even within the Shakespeare community, and qualified performers may play upwards of a dozen roles in one season. Not all performers are prepared to make this kind of commitment to one writer.

We understand that not everyone can support live theatre like Queen Elizabeth. This is one reason that, at least economically, we veer from the 16th century model: to celebrate the quality of living that came with the civil rights movement. YOU, our audience, can afford to support the humane treatment of actors!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Hear the Plays

As one famous title character says, The play's the thing. Monetary contributions help us operate, but our raison d'être is, of course, mounting as many plays as we can squeeze between Midsummer and Labor Day, and as accessibly as possible. It's just not a play without an audience, so check out the touring calendar on our website, http://www.opsfest.org/tour-calendar.html, and share it with your friends!

Share This Campaign!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us promote our goal for next season!


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! WE LOVE YOU!!!

We understand that not everyone can support live theatre like Queen
Elizabeth. This is one reason that, at least economically, we veer from the
16th century model: to celebrate the quality of living that came with the civil
rights movement. YOU, our audience, can afford to support the humane treatment
of actors!
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Hear the Plays
As one famous title character says, The
play's the thing. Monetary contributions help us operate, but our raison
d'être is, of course, mounting as many plays as we can squeeze between Midsummer
and Labor Day, and as accessibly as possible. It's just not a play without an
audience, so check out the touring calendar on our website, http://www.opsfest.org/tour-calendar.html,
and share it with your friends!
Share This Campaign!
Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us promote our goal for next season!THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! WE LOVE YOU!!!

story:
The Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill area (the "Triangle") is home to a vibrant and evolving arts scene. Having been involved in the founding of theater companies elsewhere, we started Tiny Engine to contribute to the Triangle's reputation for innovative theater. Our goal is to support the emerging voices and entertaining works that audiences might not otherwise see, brought to life by local actors, artists, and designers. 

Hearts Like Fists is our first production ever. We are very excited to be bringing Adam Szymkowicz's superhero noir comedy to the stage at Durham's Common Ground Theatre. Hilarious and heartfelt, it's an action-packed exploration of the dangers of love, the power of the human heart, and the importance of kicking ass in the fight for what's right.  

Starting a new theater company is always risky. That's why we're so grateful to the generous friends and colleagues who have already helped us in securing rehearsal space and developing publicity materials. Your donation will go to producing and promoting the show, compensating our talented designers, and keeping ticket prices low.  It will also help strengthen our community's ability to innovate, collaborate, and produce theater that rewards audiences and artists alike.

Thank you for your support. 

Visit our website for more information about Tiny Engine, and show dates and times for Hearts Like Fists.

The Story

The city's heart beats with fear: Doctor X is sneaking into apartments and injecting lovers with a lethal poison. Lisa's heart beats with hope: Now that she's joined the elite Crimefighters, maybe she can live a life with meaning. And every beat of Peter's wounded heart brings him closer to death, but he's designing an artificial replacement that will never break. 

Can the Crimefighters stop Doctor X? Do Peter and Lisa have a chance at love? And who is the girl with a face like a plate?

(Image and logo design by Jackson Lau.)

The Production 

Cast: 

  • Mara Thomas as Sally the Crimefighter
  • Kirsten Ehlert as Jazmin the Crimefighter
  • Tara Nicole Williams as Nina the Crimefighter
  • Laurel Ullman as Lisa 
  • Liz Webb as Nurse
  • Jon Todd as Doctor X
  • Ryan Ladue as Peter
  • Melissa Makhoul as Ensemble

(Right to left: Ryan Ladue, Laurel Ullman, Kirsten Ehlert, Mara Thomas, Tara Nicole Williams, Liz Webb, Jon Todd. Photo by Michael Salerno.)

Crew: 

  • Paul Sapp……….Director
  • Taylor Shumate……….Stage Manager & Costume Designer
  • Wil Deedler……….Costume Designer
  • Jon Todd……….Set Designer
  • Adam York……….Lighting Designer

Original music by Leopardactyl.

The Goal

We're looking to raise $3000 to support this production. This is not the entire budget by any means, but it would definitely help with such costs as:

  • performance rights
  • performance space rental
  • costumes
  • set
  • props 
  • printing 
  • advertising 
  • stipends for design & technical crew
Among the perks you can receive are a Tiny Engine bumper sticker, a Hearts Like Fists special edition print, a Tiny Engine tee shirt, and a ticket to the show of your choice.

(Tiny Engine bumper sticker.)

(Hearts Like Fists special edition print. Design by Darling & Dear. Fist logo by Jackson Lau.)

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? No worries.

  • Help us make some noise on Facebook, Twitter, etc.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Email tinyenginetheatre@gmail.com if you would like to be an usher, help hang posters, help build the set, or any of the other tasks that are crucial to getting this production up and running.

The Company

Paul Sapp is a director, freelance writer, and stay-at-home dad to two kids. Local credits include directing Closer at Burning Coal Theatre this past May, and a production of his original work, Magnitude of the Slope, at North Raleigh Arts & Creative Theatre. He has also worked with Axis Theatre in Baltimore and Collective Hole Productions in New York.

Laurel Ullman acts, directs, and spends most of her time at the theatre when not at her 9-5. She recently played Anna in Closer and Amelia in Magnitude of the Slope. She has also performed at  Cary Players and the ArtsCenter in Carrboro. Her directing work includes The Art of Deception for Playground Collaborative and Wait Until Dark for Studio 1.

story:
CHI SIAMO E COSA VOGLIAMO FARE
Buongiorno! Siamo Daiana, Gaia, Irene. 
Siamo donne, attrici, mogli e madri professioniste che cercano un ' armonia tra vita artistica e vita quotidiana.
Uno degli scopi principali della nostra associazione teatrale "Har Baje" è coltivare e supportare gli aspetti dell' essere donna.
Fin' ora abbiamo provveduto alla produzione dei nostri spettacoli autofinanziandoci,  vorremmo con questa campagna alzare ulteriormente il livello artistico.
Per farlo necessitiamo di fondi da utilizzare per pagare: prove, scenografie, costumi e materiale promozionale.
Ecco perchè abbiamo bisogno di voi!

IL PROGETTO
2015. Centesimo anniversario della Grande Guerra.
Facciamo uno spettacolo che la ricordi?
Leggiamo libri sulle donne dell' epoca...
Perchè?
Perchè siamo donne.
Scopriamo cose.
Nascono i ruoli, la relazione tra loro.
Iniziamo a scrivere il testo.
E' un pozzo che ci parla di guerra, di donne.
Di noi?
"Guerra?
memoria feroce 
che adesso ritorna 
a questa domanda
noi stesse di fronte."
Allora per dicembre facciamo un primo studio?
Sì!
Sabato 13 dicembre ore 20.00 spazio Har Baje via Zuretti 47 milano.
Ma ci servono soldi!
Soldi per continuare a studiare, a scrivere, a provare...
soldi per materiali e competenze...
soldi per lavorare meglio e in meno tempo!
Ci aiutate voi?
Voi come risorsa, voi come amici, voi come pubblico.
Per dare corpo a un'idea che già c'è e che funziona.
Grazie.

LO SPETTACOLO IN BREVE
Tre donne, tre classi sociali.
Guerra.
Una crocerossina, una postina, una madrina di guerra. 
Durante la guerra i soldati scrivevano lettere alle loro famiglie dettandole alle crocerossine, le madrine scrivevano ai soldati per mantenere alto il loro spirito e molte donne si ritrovarono a fare lavori cosiddetti maschili tra cui le postine. Questo il trait d'union tra le tre: le lettere. Un territorio di relazione che unisce queste tre donne, questi tre ruoli, che le aiuta ad affrontare l'insensatezza, il dolore e la fatica che la guerra richiede. Una guerra insensata come lo sono tutte  le guerre.

LE RICOMPENSE PER VOI
10 €  
tessera associativa di Har Baje valida per tutto il 2015.
25 € 
tessera Har Baje + 1 omaggio per il debutto.
50 €   
tessera Har Baje + 2 omaggio per il debutto.
100 €  
tessera Har Baje + 2 omaggio per il debutto + lettera di ringraziamento su carta anticata scritta a mano e autografata.
200 €
tessera Har Baje + 2 omaggio per il debutto + lettera di ringraziamento su lettera anticata scritta a mano e autografata + 1 fotografia dello spettacolo.
500 €
tessera Har Baje + 4 omaggio per il debutto + lettera di ringraziamento su lettera anticata scritta a mano e autografata + 1 fotografia dello spettacolo + dvd dello spettacolo.


COME CONTRIBUIRE

Contribuire su Indiegogo è facile e soprattutto è sicuro, può essere effettuato attraverso qualunque carta di credito. 

Per chi NON HA UN ACCOUNT PayPal è IMPORTANTE, durante l'inserimento dei propri dati, assicurarsi che la casella "Save this information with a PayPal account" NON sia spuntata.

N.B NON è OBBLIGATORIO AVERE O CREARE UN ACCOUNT PAYPAL.

SE NON PUOI CONTRIBUIRE MA VUOI COMUNQUE AIUTARCI:

Diffondi la notizia di questa campagna, del progetto e dello spettacolo.

per ulteriori informazioni:

Daiana: dayhope@libero.it - Gaia: bacionigaia@yahoo.it - Irene: quirene@tiscali.it


Grazie, a presto.

Daiana, Gaia, Irene.

COME CONTRIBUIRE
Contribuire su Indiegogo è facile e soprattutto è sicuro, può essere effettuato attraverso qualunque carta di credito. 
Per chi NON HA UN ACCOUNT PayPal è IMPORTANTE, durante l'inserimento dei propri dati, assicurarsi che la casella "Save this information with a PayPal account" NON sia spuntata.
N.B NON è OBBLIGATORIO AVERE O CREARE UN ACCOUNT PAYPAL.

SE NON PUOI CONTRIBUIRE MA VUOI COMUNQUE AIUTARCI:
Diffondi la notizia di questa campagna, del progetto e dello spettacolo.
per ulteriori informazioni:
Daiana: dayhope@libero.it - Gaia: bacionigaia@yahoo.it - Irene: quirene@tiscali.it

Grazie, a presto.
Daiana, Gaia, Irene.

story:
~ my story ~

Hi my name is Christine Armand, I'm a drama teacher, writer, and an actress. But, first and foremost I am one heARTsy momma. I try to live creatively with compassion and connection to the world, all the while trying to mother a lovely young lady on her own awesome journey though this thing called life. After she was born 12 years ago, I joined a group of women and we wrote a play about motherhood. It came out of our common experiences of what it was like to be a new mother...to suddenly have this amazing little soul under your roof...this gorgeous foreign creature born of your heart. And, how incredible the beginning of this new life...And no, I'm not talking about the baby...everybody talks about the baby. I'm talking about ~ the momma~. We often forget that when a baby is born, so too is a mother. And as life-changing and extraordinary as it was, it was also mired with challenges, unmet expectations, lots and lots of spit up, and well...stretchmarks. Literally and metaphorically...from all that growing. This was the kind of stuff noone really talked about in "those books" like What to Expect When you're Expecting. So we tackled the subject with honesty and humour (and lots of wine) and realized there was so much to say. Looking around, we noticed there was this voice missing...the voice that needed to say...wow, this is not what I thought it would be. And this is amazingly beautiful, but this is really f**king hard. And boy do we really need each other. We realized it was a sensitive topic, and that people might think we were Momsters...but after developing the play and putting it on in a real live theater, we were stoked to find that we weren't the only ones who felt that way. In fact, the feedback was overwhelming. I had new mothers in tears, thanking me for expressing exactly what they had been feeling. Some of them hadn't had a moment to themselves out with friends in 6 months since their babies were born. And they were thrilled to be in the land of grownups (with wine!) It seemed not only moms identifited, but poppas too. And grandmas and even non-parents were touched and found something they could identify with in the characters and how they were all on this journey of growth. We also manage to infuse a lot of laughter and in the end it's basically a love story, which was the goal. So, the play was a hit, and every time we have produced it, we have sold out each show. We haven't done it in 6 years, and I think it's time to bring it back and take it to the next level. So my goal this time around is threefold. First to refine it and make it even better. Secondly to have it be seen by a wider audience. And also to use it to "give back" to the worldwide community of Mommas. Because I believe that Motherhood is the ultimate symbol of life and love and it needs to be protected in order for us to thrive. And it's true that if Momma ain't happy, ain't nobody happy!

The upcoming production in San Francisco is just in time for Mother's Day. Come join us for a pampering momma playdate.
Enjoy a flash makeover by the fabulous Makeup Gourmet hiimself and his team of artistes. Shop for awesome makeup products. Have a momosa while having your neck rubbed by a masseuse. Chat with other mommas while enjoying a glass o' vino without a kid sitting on your lap. Then enter the "womb room" for an intimate showing of the popular play "Stretchmarks: Growing Into Motherhood." A play that takes you on a journey of 3 new moms, who get a lesson in what not to expect when you're expecting (or not expecting). 

Starring:
Christine Armand
Shani Marie Harris-Bagwell
Mary Jo Price
and
Trish DeBaun as Mother Nature

Dates: 
May 11, 12, 18, 19 8pm
May 13, 20 1pm matinee 

Tickets: $20 in advance, $25 at the door
You can buy them online here:

https://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/237875

Limited seating, and we usually sell out, so buy your tickets today.
Help save the mommas from the drama! 

For more info, please go to:

www.themommadrama.com 

(Stretchmarks: Growing Into Motherhood was written by Christine Armand, Sarah Cluff, Christine Garofoli, and Jodi Schiller @2003)

~ mompowerment ~

The play not only encourages community and connection through its theme, but it  actually does bring women together. We've had many mother's groups come see us, and even use us for their fundraising events and get togethers. Watching our play people have said is a an overall enlightening experience. People laugh and cry and then they have discussions that  maybe they wouldn't have had before. We've had women say seeing this play sparked many interesting talks and brought important issues to the foreground. The experience bonds mommas together and makes them appreciate the fact that there is this whole great big posse of mommas who have their back. I also plan on using the play as a means of "giving back" to organizations that empower mothers and protect mother earth. This time in particular, I am donating a portion of the proceeds to  www.onemama.org . 

~ what I need ~

A little rebirth never hurt anyone. :-)

I am asking for 5000 to help get the play back on it's feet. This will go towards production costs for the upcoming run. I will be producing, directing, and acting in the play this time around. Production costs include marketing materials, making the website www.themommadrama. com more professional and user friendly. Props, actress fees, facility fees, and technical aspects. (We are putting together a cool projection to use as a back piece.)

I also plan on entering the play into the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland in August, and part of this money raised would go to registration fees and venue rental. Which is pretty costly, but an amazing opportunity to showcase the play on a wider scale. I have participated in the Fringe before, and know how it works. I believe the play would kick ass over there, and would give it global exposure.

I am also developing the idea of using this as a "pop-up" play that could be performed anywhere in the world. We would use skype for casting and rehearsals and take the play to that community with only a few days to MomGyver it together and just make it work. It would be a wild and wonderful adventure. Kind of like motherhood! Then part of the proceeds would go to a local momma-focused charity.

 Your contribution will not only be funding an entertaining and meaningful artistic project, but it will also help to create a positive supportive platform for mothering communities and also giving back to worthy causes world wide.  

~ other ways you can help a momma out ~

Please spread the word about the play, and if you are in the Bay Area, please treat your favorite Momma to a day of entertainment and pampering. If you live afar, and would like the play to come to your momma community, please contact me for a play date. Also if you know of any organizations/causes that have  mothers and mother earth as their focus, and you think it would be a good fit for our play...please let me know. 

Help us save the Momma drama! (the good kind) 

This Momma thanks you from the bottom of her heART.

We would use skype for casting and rehearsals and take the play to that community with only a few days to MomGyver it together and just make it work. It would be a wild and wonderful adventure. Kind of like motherhood! Then part of the proceeds would go to a local momma-focused charity.
 Your contribution will not only be funding an entertaining and meaningful artistic project, but it will also help to create a positive supportive platform for mothering communities and also giving back to worthy causes world wide.  


~ other ways you can help a momma out ~
Please spread the word about the play, and if you are in the Bay Area, please treat your favorite Momma to a day of entertainment and pampering. If you live afar, and would like the play to come to your momma community, please contact me for a play date. Also if you know of any organizations/causes that have  mothers and mother earth as their focus, and you think it would be a good fit for our play...please let me know. 
Help us save the Momma drama! (the good kind) 
This Momma thanks you from the bottom of her heART.

story:
By Adopting a performer you will be rewarding 35 of our dedicated, brilliant and hard-working performers for their many hours of time, at Brighton's only all night arts festival, White Night, in the prestigious Brighton Dome.

Read on to see exactly how and why your kind contributions will be valued especially in these times of financial hardship for the arts...


Shambush! Our Story 

 We are a Theatre company based in Brighton England. For the past three years we have created intimate, fun and shambolic experiences that grab audiences by the proverbials and drag them into the manic and colourful world of Shambush! We are four artists all trained in different areas who have combined our efforts to take the stuffiness out of live art and give our audiences joyous experiences they'll never forget. 

 We are lucky enough to be surrounded by lots and lots of talented friends who are more than willing to pitch in and help us make every audience member feel like they are the center of the Shambush world. 

 With arts funding cuts all over the world, more and more talented performers are being asked to give their time, often for years, without getting the financial credit they deserve for the hard work they're putting in. 

The Impact 

This unbalanced system always frustrated us and we would declare "When we make it big... we'll pay our performers, no more of this working for free malarkey, that's a mug's game, people deserve to be paid what their worth. Otherwise acting, performing and art becomes an expensive hobby that only the rich can partake in. No fair! " we said "Viva la revolution! Interns need to put bread on the table too!"  

 At the moment we don't see a way out of this cycle of unpaid internships and yearn for a not long forgotten world of paid apprenticeships, where people could work their way up the ladder but never be expected to live without a basic wage. The arts world is full of good will and there are so many talented young, and not so young, performers out there who will give up their time and share their creativity... surely they should be rewarded? 

What We Need & What You Get 

 We have recently been given our biggest commission yet! Every year Brighton holds a festival called White Nights and Brighton's biggest venue, The Dome, have asked us to make a piece that spans the length and breadth of their building. The theme 'Utopia Game show' has inspired us to create a glitzy game show whirlwind of glitter and prizes. In order for us to achieve this we need at least 30 performers. They are on board and have kindly offered to give us their time. The budget that the venue can afford will cover the building of sets and buying of costumes and props, but we have only been able to budget expenses of £10 (around $7US) for each performer, ourselves included. We would love to be able to stick to our mantra and pay people what they are worth and help stop this cycle of unpaid labour in the entertainment industry. The arts are important and at a time of crisis like this, when do people need entertaining more? 

 So we would like to offer you the chance to adopt a performer! 

 Your donation will put food on your performer's table and a smile on their (very expressive) face! 

 In return you will receive a personal letter of thanks from us with a picture of your performer and a unique "I helped Shambush feed a performer and all I got was this lousy badge" badge! (for donations under $25 we'll email you the cut out and keep badge to print and wear with pride!)

 Your name will be in the credits for the show and you will have free lifetime membership and entry to the Shambush! world events. You will also receive our eternal gratitude and that of struggling performers everywhere, who know they can make a difference and brighten up our lives if someone would only give them the chance. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

 If you like our adopt a performer campaign please encourage your friends to join in, give as little or as much as you can spare and enjoy the warm fuzzy feeling! You never know you may see your performer on the silver screen one day and you can guarantee they'll be adopting a new generation of performers themselves. I know we will be!

story:
Our Project

CunamacuÃ©, founded in 2010, is a music and dance ensemble which promotes the continuity of Afro-Peruvian culture using its music and dance as a vehicle for self-expression.


CunamacuÃ© will be going on tour to PerÃº in August of this year.  We have been invited to perform at the 2nd Annual Festival Cultural KutukÃ¡ in CaÃ±ete, PerÃº. The festival is aimed at rescuing the culture, and highlighting the importance of people of African descent in PerÃº via lectures, demonstrations, and performances.  


Festival Cultural KutukÃ¡:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I5mugOrd_8Q


And we'll also perform at Museo Nacional Afroperuano (National Afro-Peruvian Museum) in Lima:

http://guiavirtual.pe/museo-nacional-afroperuano


We are very excited at this opportunity!!  The company based in the U.S., will be traveling to Peru to perform in the Afro-Peruvian idiom in its place of origin, how cool is that?!  The trip will be an enriching experience as we learn more about the culture form its source and engage in cultural exchanges through dance.  We will come back to the U.S. refreshed, ready to create more music and dance to share with you all!



With your help we can make it happen

Your generous contribution will help pay for travel expenses (i.e. airfare), and artists' fees.


Thank you for your support,

CunamacuÃ©


www.cunamacue.org

http://www.facebook.com/Cunamacue

story:
About The Play:

This fast paced roller coaster ride about self-discovery, with more than a few parallels to the student/mentor relationship of Marlon Brando and Stella Adler is a dark comedy that exposes how greatness can be nurtured when raw unfocused talent meets an unyielding force of nature.

             October 10-13 and 16-21 @8:00 pm

             October 14 and 21 @3:00 pm

             October 13 @ 2:00 pm

Where: 

             Roy Arias Theater Center/Stage 2

             300 West 43rd Street ,4th Floor

             New York, New York 10036

             (between 8th and 9th Avenues)

 

 Beer and wine can be purchased at the 5th floor lounge and can be taken back to your seat! Cheers!

 

About Legacy Stage:

We are proud to present our first production,The Acting Lesson by Wesley St John,from October 10-21st,Off Broadway,in the heart of the NYC Theater District.  This is the premier production for our company that has a season of 4 shows planned.

 Our Goals:

  • Uncover and develop great works by unknown writers,   
  • Remount rare works of established playwrights with a new spin.   
  • Gather feedback and interact with our audiences.  
  • Help bridge the gap from pre-professional to professional careers for actors, playwrights, directors and designers in NYC.
  • Develop audiences for theater with outreach productions for all ages.
  • Entertain!!!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $9289 to complete financing for our current production, cover our company start up costs and secure funding for our next three productions including The Gray List by Allan Provost, Ring Round The Moon by Jean Anouilh and an origional work still TBD.

Your Donation today will help cover the following:

    Salery Stipend for cast and crew: $1500.00

    Set and costumes: $700.00

    Programs,posters, postcards and perks: $500.00

    Theater Rental: $3700.00

    Operating costs still not raised for our remaining season: $2900.00

You will get to be a founding contributor to our company for which you will always be recognized in all future productions. You get the satisfaction of knowing that you have just contributed to a project that supports talented playwrights, directors, actors and designers who otherwise would not be able to develop their skills on the professional stage in NYC. You get our everlasting THANKS!

Some Not Silly Questions:

What if I contribute on the Mama Rose or James Tyrone level after October 21st when the Acting Lesson closes. What about my comps?

We are raising funds for an entire season which will be from this October into October of 2013. Your comp tickets will be applied to our next show , The Gray LIst by Alan Provost, which will most likely be in March. We will keep you posted.( It is a fabulous show and a few of the pics from that production are on this site.)

What if I live in Siberia but I want to contribute. Will I get a pen and poster etc? What about my comps?

Yep! We will be happy to send it to you along with a note of thanks! You may donate your comps which we will pass on to a senior, student or struggling artist living on a fixed income who otherwise would not be able to see the show.

Do I get a tax write off for my contribution?

Not Yet. We are in the process of obtaining non-profit status but do not have it yet.

I donated last night but my name is not in the program! 

Our programs are printed in advance, However we will try to update our patron list throughout the play. Hopefully we will keep up but please give us a few days to keep our list current.

Is this venue handicapped accessible? 

Yes! 

Is this play for children? 

Anyone over 13 years would enjoy this play. There are adult themes but very little bad language and alot to be learned about the theater.

More information:

Please visit us @www.legacystageensemble.org for all of the details or drop us an email @ legacystage@gmail.com

THANKS!!!

story:
JANUARY 2013

This Campaign may have ended, but the opportunity to keep stories alive has not...

DONATE now at

https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=3219 

 

************************************************************************

Who We Are

Village Playback Theatre is an innovative company dedicated to telling the stories of people who struggle to be heard. For over a decade, our company has listened to audience members' personal stories and crafted them into improvised performances that make a powerful impact on both the tellers and their communities. Based in New York City, we provide a meaningful theater experience for many people whose access may be limited.

We perform on location: in hospitals and schools, community centers and senior centers, day treatment programs and prisons. We have performed for audiences coping with mental illness, addictions, homelessness, histories of incarceration and physical and cognitive disabilities. No matter the setting, seeing a story "played back" can bring a tremendous sense of validation and belonging.

Playback Theatre is a form that draws from improvisation and traditional storytelling. Created in 1975 in the United States, it is now practiced around the world in over 50 countries.

We all have a need to be heard, but a fear of being judged or viewed as “having something wrong” can make it difficult to speak.  A genuine invitation to talk, in front of an attentive listener, makes it easier. We believe everyone deserves the chance to be simply asked "What's your story?"

What We Need

This year, we've decided to focus our work on reaching out to the mentally ill in our community, and we need your help to make it happen.   We’d like to increase the impact of our work this year by going for depth, not breadth, and have dedicated ourselves to finding new and meaningful ways to reach out to individuals struggling with mental illness, their families, and care providers. It’s work we’re passionate about, but it comes with some challenges. Funding for services for the mentally ill in our city is critically low. Many of the organizations that could most benefit from a VPT performance are least able to hire us. We want to make sure we can reach as many people as possible.

Additionally, VPT is growing. We want to reach more people, so we’ve hired more actors and musicians. We also want to make sure we’re as well trained and well equipped as we can be to undertake the work we’ve planned for ourselves, which means training our members, and learning new performance techniques. Here are some of our company goals for this year:

  • Provide pro-bono performances for organizations serving the mentally ill, their families, and their care providers.
  • Send each of our members to Anti-Racism Training to increase our understanding of struggles and bias that affect many in our audiences.
  • Secure new space for regular rehearsals: our rehearsal space, once provided for us at no cost, has been lost due building damages.

Looking at these plans, we believe we can accomplish our goals with a minimum budget of $8,000. If we don't make our goal, all funds raised will still go directly to our work this season, but our scope will be more limited: less shows for underserved communities, less training for our actors, less equipment. We'll maintain our focus, but we'd love to pursue this season's goals to the fullest. 

The Impact

The funds raised in this campaign will have a direct effect on the lives of people with mental illness in our community. One in five Americans have had their lives touched by mental illness, and yet for many people it remains an invisible disease: the fear of stigma and misunderstanding prevents sufferers from telling their stories. Through Playback Theatre, we can send the message that these stories are valuable and deserve to be heard. 

Playback Theatre increases empathy for others and provide a new perspective on an experience. Often, storytellers feel comfortable "opening up" in a way they may not feel comfortable expressing themselves elsewhere. Playback brings people together and strengthens the bonds of communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in a position to donate, we understand...there are other ways to get involved that would still be a big help! Please assist us in spreading the word about our campaign by telling friends, families, coworkers--anyone you think might be interested in our work. Giving us a shout out on social media is also much appreciated: Indiegogo gives you some tools for sharing right here on the site to make it easy.

Thanks so much for your interest and your generosity. We hope you'll join our Village this season!

We hope you'll join our Village this season!

story:
EXPRESS YOURSELF IN NEW YORK

Events in Real Time has been invited to bring our show Express Yourself to the Incubator Arts Project in New York and we need your help to get there!

Why support us?

This is an incredible opportunity for a group of dedicated artists. Shows presented at the Incubator are often reviewed in the New York Times, Village Voice, and other prominent publications. The venue, St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery, has an incredible artistic history. And brand new audiences, critics, and presenters would have the opportunity to see our work for the very first time.

Plus, we love this show and we want to share it with as many people as possible. After two years of in-studio development and presentations in Toronto, Express Yourself has garnered strong reviews (see a few excepts below) and the Jury Prize for Risk and Innovation at the 2011 SummerWorks Festival, Canada's largest juried theatre festival. It feels like the right moment to take the next step.

What are you supporting?

The Incubator is giving us their amazing space, technical team, and promotional expertise, but we need to cover travel, accomodation, and expenses for our cast and crew of five: performer Liz Peterson, director Sean O'Neill, stage manager/co-producer Sofia Bohdanowicz, tech director/designer Kimberly Purtell, and co-performer/choreographer Ame Henderson.

Any contribution you can make helps us achieve our goal, and we're offering a few tokens of appreciation to thank you for your generousity. 

More about the show:

"A deeply moving experiment in media and performance... Peterson's casual, affable style is instantly likeable." - Now Magazine (****)

"Wonderfully inventive... A perfect showcase for the multi-talented Peterson, who performs with a sincerity and truth that is palpable."  - Mooney on Theatre

In this rigorous and inventive piece about the dynamics of performance, performer Liz Peterson and director Sean O’Neill push the limits of media and form. Weaving personal confessions, dance, synchronized video, and a pop sensibility, Express Yourself is a stylized depiction of a performance in progress. The show is anchored by a virtuosic performance by Peterson, who navigates the ever-shifting boundaries of the work with disarming vulnerability, humour, and charm.

The creation and production of Express Yourself has been generously supported by the Toronto Arts Council and the Canada Council for the Arts.

Spread the word! 

If you can't afford to donate or you'd like to help us further, we could use your help to get the word out about the campaign! The direct link to our indiegogo page is http://www.indiegogo.com/expressyourself. Even better, post the link on Facebook or Twitter and help spread the word!

It feels like the right moment to take the next step.
What are you supporting?
The Incubator is giving us their amazing space, technical team, and promotional expertise, but we need to cover travel, accomodation, and expenses for our cast and crew of five: performer Liz Peterson, director Sean O'Neill, stage manager/co-producer Sofia Bohdanowicz, tech director/designer Kimberly Purtell, and co-performer/choreographer Ame Henderson.
Any contribution you can make helps us achieve our goal, and we're offering a few tokens of appreciation to thank you for your generousity. 
More about the show:
"A deeply moving experiment in media and performance... Peterson's casual, affable style is instantly likeable." - Now Magazine (****)
"Wonderfully inventive... A perfect showcase for the multi-talented Peterson, who performs with a sincerity and truth that is palpable."  - Mooney on Theatre
In this rigorous and inventive piece about the dynamics of performance, performer Liz Peterson and director Sean O’Neill push the limits of media and form. Weaving personal confessions, dance, synchronized video, and a pop sensibility, Express Yourself is a stylized depiction of a performance in progress. The show is anchored by a virtuosic performance by Peterson, who navigates the ever-shifting boundaries of the work with disarming vulnerability, humour, and charm.
The creation and production of Express Yourself has been generously supported by the Toronto Arts Council and the Canada Council for the Arts.
Spread the word! 
If you can't afford to donate or you'd like to help us further, we could use your help to get the word out about the campaign! The direct link to our indiegogo page is http://www.indiegogo.com/expressyourself. Even better, post the link on Facebook or Twitter and help spread the word!

story:
The 11th Annual Vancouver International Improv Festival takes place October 5-9, 2010 at the beautiful Performance Works Theatre on Granville Island.

It’s been an amazing decade, and we wouldn’t be here without the support of our community, our sponsors, and most of all you, our audience.

This year VIIF, like many BC-based arts organizations, watched our government funding vanish into thin air. BC now only designates $4.50 per person towards arts funding, which is less than 20% of the national average, and the lowest in the country. (For more information, may we recommend Stop BC Arts Cuts?)

Improvisers are, by nature, creatures of action. That’s why, in the spirit of our friends at Ghost Jail Theatre and their fundraising initiative, the Ghost Jail 100, we’re asking for your help with the VIIF 200. We want 200 people to give $20 each, an amount of money that makes up for any provincial funding VIIF might have received this year.

What does your $20 buy? The venue, for one. The refreshments for guests like yourselves. The staff. But moreso: your $20 helps pay the artists’ fees to bring great improvisers to the fest from all over the world. It pays the directors to travel here and teach (both to our guests and to the local theatre and arts community). And it allows those improvisers and directors (and you!) to take what they’ve learned and created back to their own communities across the globe.

In other words, your $20 does something incredible: It recognizes the value of theatre and art in the community, in Canada, and internationally.

But it doesn’t stop there—$20 is a generous donation, but we welcome your contributions at any level. Take a look at the options, and feel free to email us at viif200@gmail.com with any questions you might have.

If you’d prefer to send your donation directly, please make a cheque out to the Vancouver Improv Festival Society and send it with your name and address to:

610 E. 13th Avenue
Vancouver, BC V5T 2L1

Welcome to the VIIF 200.
VIVE LE VIIF!

story:
My name is Liz Femi; I am the writer and performer of the one-woman play,Take Me To The Poorhouse. I am thrilled to share this comedy because it presents universal themes in an African setting. I spent a significant part of my childhood in Nigeria and one of my life-long dreams has been to speak of the African I know, through storytelling.  My hope is that this story will help challenge stereotypes about Africans. This is a children's story for adults, one that reminds us that the child in every person on this planet, matters.

So why a solo show? Solo theatre is magical. This artform first hyponitized me when I watched the exceptional Nilaja Sun perform her critically acclaimed solo show, No Child. A year later, I became the first understudy for Ms. Sun and went on to perform the show for 6 weeks in Vermont. No Child raised the bar on my goals as an artist; I live for the surprise that every project provides and the lingering soulful, communal moments that storytelling evokes.

What We Need & What You Get

We have a fabulous team working to bring the world premiere of this production to the Hollywood Fringe Festival in Los Angeles (June 2013); however, this show is an independent theater production with little to no financial backing. Your financial support ensures that we can bring this unique project to life!

And, guess what? You are doing a double-good-deed. We pledge to donate 10% of all ticket proceeds to Mama Hope, a non-profit with a mission to “Stop the Pity and Unlock the Potential” in several African communities www.mamahope.org. We dig Mama Hope, and we believe their goal resonates with the heart of this project.



Thank you for supporting Take Me To The Poorhouse, and in turn, Mama Hope.


You double-do-gooder! ;-)

Your contribution will assist with essential components of our new production:

  • Festival Fees
  • Venue 
  • Rehearsal space 
  • Production (light, sound, costume, set)
  • Travel and Accommodation (crew)
  • Public Relations
  • Marketing: 
  • Crew fees 
    • director
    • assistant
    • producers
    • designers (sound, light, costume)
    • videographer
    • photographer
    • stage manager
    • company representative


Production Team

Liz Femi

Liz Femi is an actress, writer, and educator in Los Angeles. Born in the UK, raised in Nigeria and the U.S., her work is enhanced by her international background.  She has appeared in numerous noteworthy projects on stage and screen including: No Child, Eclipsed (World Premiere), The Convert, and the short film Faith & Dreams.Notable TV and film work includes: a supporting role in Things Never Said, starring Shanola Hampton of Showtime’s Shameless and directed by Charles Murray (V, Criminal Minds), and a pilot for Adventures with Shondrella, starring Shondrella Avery of Napoleon Dynamite and The Secret Life of Bees. Liz also co-hosts Action English on China’s national entertainment network CCTV6Liz studied at the UR International Theatre Program and holds an MFA in Acting from the A.R.T. Institute at Harvard University. www.lizfemi.comFollow Liz on Twitter

Jane Morris, Director and Co-Developer

Founder of the Second City ETC stage in Chicago, Jane is a writer, performer and director. She has taught improvisation for the Second City and in her own venues for the past 20 years. Jane and her husband Jeff Michalski have owned and operated UpFront Comedy and the Comedy Underground in Santa Monica and is currently the owner and managing director of the fanaticSalon in Culver City

Jane has a long list of film and television credits. She currently teaches writing for performance at the fanaticSalon. http://janemorriswritework.blogspot.com/

Sara Fenton, Assistant Director
James Jolly, Producer
Hope Olaide, Producer
Adam Kern, Associate Producer
Koshie Mills, Press/Media
Willie Pena, Tech Guru

 

 

 

 

REVIEWS (For NO CHILD)


“Wilson’s performance was a marvel… in a twinkle, she transforms…no simple parlor trick: all 16 characters, the funny and the shocking, rang true. Wilson brought a raw depth to the character …who continued to fight the good fight but slowly wearied of the struggle”-BENNINGTON BANNER


“It is a wonderfully fluid 70-minute tour-de-force for an actress and Liz Femi does not disappoint…she makes it all so effortless…”–BRATTLEBORO REFORMER

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us make some noise! Simply click the “Share This Campaign" link above. It’s that simple. Thank you for your generous support :-)

story:
The Story:

Thank You, Everything! introduces us to an entirely different world to which most people are never exposed. Reunited on the road after 10 years by the comeback of the rock-band they followed in their youth, Greg, Marty, Stream, and Gabriella struggle to redefine their lives, friendships, and dreams in a world that threatens to grow up before they do.


The Show:


THANK YOU, EVERYTHING!
by Ed Krystosek
Produced by Caitlin Oates
Directed by Diana Raiselis

February 24 @ 8 PM
February 25 @ 8/11 PM
February 26 @ 8/11 PM

Northwestern University
Louis Room
Norris University Center
1999 Campus Drive
Evanston, IL 60208


Who We Are:

Thank You, Everything! is being produced in association with Vertigo Productions, the only student theatre board at Northwestern University to produce student-written work. Vertigo gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk.

Many Vertigo shows have gone on to professional theatre companies such as NYC’s Manhattan Repertory Theatre and Lincoln Center Theatre, as well as Chicago’s About Face Theatre and Lookingglass Theatre Company; the board’s unique position opens multiple avenues of various artistic endeavors, providing invaluable theatrical experience for over thirty students!


What We Need From You!

Because Vertigo is a self-sufficient, nonprofit organization, we do not receive any funding from the university to bring this play to life. In order to make our show happen, however, we face exciting challenges such as building both a full-sized RV and a Volkswagen bus. We must raise a total of $3000 to accomplish this.

 

This is where we need your help! We would greatly appreciate any sort of tax-deductible donation you could give to the performance of Thank You, Everything! and would like to offer you the opportunity to be recognized in our program as a sponsor of the show. The generosity of our friends and family is crucial to our success; we’d love to make this the best show Northwestern has ever seen! No amount is too small.

story:
Our Story

Judas Iscariot has been awaiting a trial for 2000 years. And today he gets it. In a courtroom that mixes myth with history, set halfway between Heaven and Hell, in a place called Hope, the witnesses are called- Mother Teresa, Pontius Pilate, Sigmund Freud, a foul-mouthed Saint Monica, a high-school football coach, a handful of Jesusâ€™ disciples and of course, Satan- to decide eternal questions or forgiveness, mercy and damnation.

Wildly funny and scathingly provocative, The Last Days of Judas Iscariot is a searing look at historyâ€™s most infamous double-cross. Part court-room drama, part urban re-telling of myth, the play places Judas Iscariot on trial for betraying Christ. As the trial goes on, we are forced to re- examine old truths and consider what it means to forgive.

Directed by Pound of Flesh Theatreâ€™s Artistic Director Stephen Drover, The Last Days of Judas Iscariot boasts some of Vancouverâ€™s most sought-after actors: Bob Frazer, Marci T. House, Anthony F. Ingram, Kyle Jespersen, Carl Kennedy, Michael Kopsa, Kevin McNulty, Dawn Petten, Ron Reed, Todd Thomson, Katherine Venour, Adrienne Wong, Marcus Youssef,  and Beatrice Zeilinger.

Pound of Flesh Theatre was founded in 2004 to produce alternative interpretations of classical stories. It has since gone on to create exciting productions, workshops, classes and opportunities for artists and audiences to engage with classical text and narrative. It holds a unique position inâ€¨the Vancouver artistic community as the only company mandated to explore classical stories as filtered through contemporary sensibilities.


The Last Days of Judas Iscariot by Stephen Adly Guirgis. Produced by Pound of Flesh Theatre, in association with Pacific Theatre and Neworld Theatre. Presented by Rumble Productions and the Cultch as a part of Rumbleâ€™s 2012 Tremors Festival, the show will run â€¨April 10-21, 2012â€¨at the Cultchâ€™s Historic Theatre.                                                     

www.poundofflesh.net


The Impact

The Last Days of Judas Iscariot is a funny, scathing, imaginative and uncompromising theatrical investigation of morality and its relationship to the Catholic history and iconography that occupies such a large part of North American religious imagination. It manages to enact this in a way that is at once deeply challenging, and hugely accessible - largely as a result of its humour and its counterintuitive mixing of numerous historical figures testifying at Judas' trial. It is proving to be a major contribution to 21st Century drama and has been given critically-acclaimed productions in London, New York, Toronto and across North America. Vancouver deserves to be treated to this calibre of theatre. Bringing together top-notch artists and producers â€“ as this project proposes â€“ is the best way to ensure the highest quality production for Vancouver audiences.


An excerpt from the play demonstrates its popular appeal and its ability to attract the spiritually squeamish towards issues of faith, justice and eternal forgiveness:


PONTIUS PILATE:
â€¨I did what I had to do to preserve the d**n peace! Why?! Cuz that was my d**n job! I did my job! I did my d**n job and now you wanna call me a liar?! Question my veracity and my character?! I am a Roman, lady! One hundred percent, 24/7, we never close! Underneath my b** s** is stamped: VERITAS! And that means TRUTH! And that means my honor is defined by my integrity and my integrity is defined by my truth! And I defy you -- here and now -- to produce one shred of evidence to support your wild and defamatory claims! Sh*t! You better check the resume two times before you start tryin' ta sweep your dirt under a Roman's rug! I am clean like dove and ready for love, missy! I live in Heaven! Where you live at, girlfriend?! Sh*t! I'll tell you what though: when you get your head straightened out, gimme a call some time if you want to -- I'll take you down to the Aqueduct for a pizza and a tussle. Show you my tattoos.... Any more questions?


In Short

This is a fantastic play. But it's a very big one (15 actors!) and is very costly for a small, independent company to produce. Pound of Flesh Theatre is committed to mounting the best professional staging it can. Your donation is the way to make this happen. You can help us build a top-notch set, dress the actors in well-designed costumes and secure all the little things needed to make a great show live. No amount is too small (many props cost only 5 bucks!). You'll become a part of an important team telling an important story.  


It doesn't take 30 pieces of silver. Just a vote of confidence and a few shekels. â€¨Thanks for your support. Blessings.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? No problem! You'd be helping out a lot just by helping us spread the word! Email your friends, or simply just click the Facebook or Twitter buttons below! 


Pound of Flesh Theatre is a registered charity and non-profit organization. Donations over $20 will are tax-deductible and will be issued a tax receipt.
