story:
What Is This?

A new presentation of David Auburn's play Proof, winner of the 2001 Pulitzer Prize and 2001 Tony Award for Best Playis being shown in New York City December 7th through December 9th of 2012. Proof tells the story of Catherine, a brilliant young woman who wrestles with not only inheriting her father's mathematical genius, but also potentially his mental instability. The story also goes into issues of a family that is in many ways distant from each other, the question of authenticity in one's work, and the choices one makes in figuring out their identity. This version brings the back porch of the Chicago household that becomes the center of a dramatic series of events, and transports it to an initimate setting where potent storytelling is present for all audience members to witness.

Who Is Involved With This?

This production is being produced and directed by myself, Jordan Friedman, a young theatrical director residing in New York City. I have a passion for creating theatre and telling stories with the dramatic text, the work of designers and other production staff, and the effort put in by all of the actors. I also believe that things that may appear simple on the surface can contain complexity when observed in depth, and as a result there can be truly powerful and poignant moments in theatre. This notion is something I always keep in mind when pursuing my work. This is my first full-length production in New York City, and I am very passioniate, excited, and determine to make this worthwhile for all. There are also very talented designers and actors working to help shape and define the world of Proof.

 Why Should You Contribute?

You should contribute to this campaign because in order to keep the theatrical culture and pulse alive not only in New York City but within the entire world, new artists need to have their talent be shown and new creative sparks need to fly. If young theatre does not get the opportunity to be seen, then the entire theatrical art cannot generate new followers and new potential artists. By contributing to this campaign, you are providing audience members an opportunity to see theatre that respects the intelligence of everybody involved, and can be the gateway to a bright future for both the artists and the audiences. My craft is something that I take very seriously, and I would greatly appreciate the support those who also value theatre seriously, whether you are an artist or an audience member.

What Are These Funds Going Towards?

The money raised on this campaign will contribute towards the various expenses involved in bringing Proof to life. These include:

*Helping to cover expenses involved in royalties for producing the show.

*Contributing to the rental of our performance space.

*Providing designers the budget to use all of their talent and create the best scenery, lights, costumes, and sounds that can be generated.

*Marketing the show through a variety of media and techniques and reaching out to as many potential audience members as possible.

*Compensating the actors and production staff for all of the effort that they put towards in this production.

Doing this in New York City is not the easiest task, so every and any contribution to help achieve those goals is appreciated more than words can express.

How Can You Help?

The most direct method of helping this production and everybody involved in it is to contribute to this campaign. Any amount is appreciated, although depending on the specific amount you can claim rewards for your efforts such as being featured in our programs, special video messages from the cast and crew, an invitation to one of our rehearsals, and even a producer credit. If you can not make a monetary contribution, you can still provide invaluable support by sharing this campaign to as many people as possible and share the word and idea of creating exciting theatre in New York City.

In Conclusion:

On a personal level, I would like to sincerely thank everybody who reads this campaign and is willing to provide support either directly or indirectly in creating art that people truly believe in. The assistance that is provided is invaluable to me and everybody working on this show. If you choose to donate to this show or help spread the word, I will give everything I have to make sure your effort goes towards something very meaningful.
story_txt:
What Is This?
A new presentation of David Auburn's play Proof, winner of the 2001 Pulitzer Prize and 2001 Tony Award for Best Playis being shown in New York City December 7th through December 9th of 2012. Proof tells the story of Catherine, a brilliant young woman who wrestles with not only inheriting her father's mathematical genius, but also potentially his mental instability. The story also goes into issues of a family that is in many ways distant from each other, the question of authenticity in one's work, and the choices one makes in figuring out their identity. This version brings the back porch of the Chicago household that becomes the center of a dramatic series of events, and transports it to an initimate setting where potent storytelling is present for all audience members to witness. 
Who Is Involved With This?
This production is being produced and directed by myself, Jordan Friedman, a young theatrical director residing in New York City. I have a passion for creating theatre and telling stories with the dramatic text, the work of designers and other production staff, and the effort put in by all of the actors. I also believe that things that may appear simple on the surface can contain complexity when observed in depth, and as a result there can be truly powerful and poignant moments in theatre. This notion is something I always keep in mind when pursuing my work. This is my first full-length production in New York City, and I am very passioniate, excited, and determine to make this worthwhile for all. There are also very talented designers and actors working to help shape and define the world of Proof. 

 Why Should You Contribute?

You should contribute to this campaign because in order to keep the theatrical culture and pulse alive not only in New York City but within the entire world, new artists need to have their talent be shown and new creative sparks need to fly. If young theatre does not get the opportunity to be seen, then the entire theatrical art cannot generate new followers and new potential artists. By contributing to this campaign, you are providing audience members an opportunity to see theatre that respects the intelligence of everybody involved, and can be the gateway to a bright future for both the artists and the audiences. My craft is something that I take very seriously, and I would greatly appreciate the support those who also value theatre seriously, whether you are an artist or an audience member.
What Are These Funds Going Towards?
The money raised on this campaign will contribute towards the various expenses involved in bringing Proof to life. These include:
*Helping to cover expenses involved in royalties for producing the show.
*Contributing to the rental of our performance space.
*Providing designers the budget to use all of their talent and create the best scenery, lights, costumes, and sounds that can be generated.
*Marketing the show through a variety of media and techniques and reaching out to as many potential audience members as possible.
*Compensating the actors and production staff for all of the effort that they put towards in this production.
Doing this in New York City is not the easiest task, so every and any contribution to help achieve those goals is appreciated more than words can express. 
How Can You Help?
 The most direct method of helping this production and everybody involved in it is to contribute to this campaign. Any amount is appreciated, although depending on the specific amount you can claim rewards for your efforts such as being featured in our programs, special video messages from the cast and crew, an invitation to one of our rehearsals, and even a producer credit. If you can not make a monetary contribution, you can still provide invaluable support by sharing this campaign to as many people as possible and share the word and idea of creating exciting theatre in New York City.
In Conclusion:
On a personal level, I would like to sincerely thank everybody who reads this campaign and is willing to provide support either directly or indirectly in creating art that people truly believe in. The assistance that is provided is invaluable to me and everybody working on this show. If you choose to donate to this show or help spread the word, I will give everything I have to make sure your effort goes towards something very meaningful.

story:
Filmed by Kennedy Yanko



PIECE Theatre is fiscally sponsored by a 501(c)3…

SO

YOUR DONATION

IS

TAX-DEDUCTIBLE!

 

Contributions in behalf of PIECE Theatre may be made payable to WPAA

 

WHO WE ARE

 

HISTORY

 

The three co-founders of PIECE Theatre each hold a unique journey from New Haven to New York. 

 

One moved to Japan to study Theatre and led a successful transition from actor to director before finishing his degree. Another forwent the degree altogether, moved into the tech room of the world famous LIVING Theatre, and grounded his acting career in the deep roots of activism. And the third finished his degree early and travelled the world – a playwright moonlighting as a volunteer vagabond – eventually creating drama education programs for the youth in both South Africa and the South Pacific.

 

During their journeys, these three New Haven boys kept in touch and continued searching for opportunities to collaborate on theatre projects. As a result, before the formation of PIECE Theatre, they had tested their bonds, beliefs and aspirations by collaborating in three off-Broadway productions of original work. The 2011-2012 season will be the first they share together, firmly united under a single banner.

 

PIECE Theatre is a New York City based Theatre Company that exists to create new works about our shared humanity.

 



MISSION

 

PIECE is an ensemble-based theatre company located in New York City. We are dedicated to the exploration and innovation of storytelling because we believe expression binds our fragmented humanity. It is through consistent and collaborative endeavors to share stories with each other that we attempt to piece ourselves together. PIECE Theatre creates new works, while running storytelling education programs for both children and adults, with a clear mission: to always trust the theatrical process as it illuminates the puzzle of our existence one piece at a time.



 

 

OUR PROJECT

 

Since its inception in 2007, we have performed this play in art galleries, parks, cemeteries, living rooms, public access television stations, and off-Broadway theaters.

 

PIECE Theatre is proud to bring CRACKED (Upon a Time) back to New York City.

 

With your help, CRACKED (Upon a Time) will finally have the showcase we believe it deserves: a two week run this October at TheaterLab - Manhattan’s premiere theatre salon for experimental theatre.

 

 

CRACKED (Upon a Time)

by

Josiah Houston

 

Three chairs sit at the foot of a graveyard. Alfred's chair, Percy's chair, and the Death Seat. Alfred, an older man, is writing into a large black leather bound book. But in the end it is Percy, an old man, who labors upon the blank page. In the Game of Life the potent ramblings and hysterical bickering between these ancient companions explore memory, allusion, love, luck, fear, trust, choices to be made, time to be passed, and the desire to avoid ending before they conclude that - EVERYMAN MUST GO THROUGH LIFE ON HIS OWN.

 



 

WE NEED YOUR HELP

 

Our Expenses:

Cost of an average, mid-sized rehearsal studio in Manhattan: $35

3 nights a week for 3 hours for 4 weeks: $1,260

Two weekends of 8 shows in a 60 seat theater downtown: $2300

Props for one low budget show: $400

Wigs & Costumes: $300

Promotional Materials: $300

Copies of full length script for actors and crew. $100

501(c)(3) filing: $400

 

This project has been a part of our lives for many years and it is time to show the world what we've been working on. 

Your donations will afford us the opportunity to rent a dynamic theater space and promote our project in one of the most competitive theatre cities in the world.  

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Without your donations, this project would be impossible. 

 

 

PIECE Theatre is a sponsored project of Wallingford Public Access Association (WPAA), a 501(c)3 non-profit media content distribution organization. Contributions in behalf of PIECE Theatre may be made payable to WPAA and are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.



 

 

KEEP CONNECTED!

 

Check out our website, www.theatreinpieces.org, where you can keep updated on all our latest news, join our mailing list, and learn about our theatre company.

 

Check us out on Facebook at www.facebook.com/PIECE.Theatre

 

Follow us on Twitter at twitter.com/piecetheatre

 

Or on Tumblr at www.piecetheatre.tumblr.com

 

You can Email us at theatreinpieces@gmail.com

 

SPREAD THE WORD AND DON’T FORGET

 

PIECE Theatre is fiscally sponsored by a 501(c)3…

SO

YOUR DONATION

IS

TAX-DEDUCTIBLE!

story:
Welcome!

Indiegogo Campaign for Last Import - Behind the Veil. 

My passion project, I have been building my solo show for the past three years. As the first actress in my family (and the first Iranian actress to graduate Columbia's MFA acting program in 2009), I feel passionately that stories of resilience deserve a voice and an audience. 

Last Import is of Import

Resilience is instrumental to sustainable living and finding forgiveness in the most challenging of circumstances. The characters in Last Import are tangible and sometimes surreal; all of them are women and girls who have experienced challenges and learned to transcend them using their imaginations and creativity. The human spirit is one that rises to the occassion, when given the chance. The stories are touching, funny, provocative, childlike and fantastical. 

10 Characters, 10 Dances, 10 Multi-medium Projections

Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

The show can happen with your support. Last Import is the culmination of three years of soul-searching and writing the stories of women and girls that I know intimately, the likes of which are rare in these times. 

What We Need & What You Get

For the San Francisco production of Last Import, I need to raise 2600 dollars. 

Funds cover: travel expenses, costuming, set, space rental, accomodations, stage managemer, PR, and transportation. Any and all funds received will go towards the production.

All contributors will be acknowledged (unless otherwise requested) in the playbill for the show as Angel Investors.

For donations of 500 dollars or more, contributors receive a signed original painting and are provided with a producer credit in the play. My art has been featured at galleries in New York City (Cafe Grumpy Art Show, Theater for the New City Art Show, Dock Studios (Bushwick), and in Vermont in Spring 2013). 

Other Ways You Can Help

Yes, you can! Donated supplies, transportation, mileage for travel, gift certificates, and any other suggestions are welcome. This production is timely and meaningful and has come to fruition because of the support of people like you. 

Thank you and I look forward to your contribution!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Nicole Gilbertson. I am a senior at Columbia College Chicago where I study Dance. In my final semester of college, I am in the process of making my final work and Choreogrpahic Project called, Chronomentrophobia.

Chronomentrophobia takes the audience on a surreal experience led by extraterrestrial creatures within their last minutes of life. The piece studies the meaning of the word Chronomentrophobia: the fear of time.

What We Need & What You Get

The choreography is finished, the score is set, the lights are designed...and now we need costumes. This project needs $300 in total for the creation of these costumes. This includes the basics, accesories, and fabrics.

All who help this project will receive a thank you card!

The Impact

Your contribution will make this piece a reality. Without these costumes, the dancers cannot externally potray their characters, nor will they feel expressive in their own "skin." Alonside choreography, score, lights, and performance, this work cannot be completed without these costumes.

Thank you for visiting this page and don't forget to contribute - $1, $20, or whatever - all amounts are appreciated!

Thank you,

Nicole Gilbertson

story:
The Story

Circle Mirror Transformation is presented by WAVE Productions.

WAVE is a self-supporting, not-for-profit student theatre company operating primarily on Northwestern University's Evanston Campus. WAVE exists to share the stories of the past and present in order to open the door to a better future. In addition to having five main stage shows per season, WAVE supports and creates special events that stretch the boundaries of what theatre can be. 

Circle Mirror Transformation, by the Pulitzer prize-winning Annie Baker, takes us through a summer Creative Drama class in a Vermont town. It is a petri dish of human life, exploring loneliness and togetherness, awkwardness and freedom, pain and reconciliation, the things we hold in, and what happens when we let them out. Our aesthetic is finding beauty in simplicity.

Join Our Circle

As with all productions, Circle Mirror Transformation presents unique challenges. Because the show is realistic, it is very important to us that the world we create looks authentic. This means we have to take extra care in constructing the set so that it is polished and does not look theatrical. Your donations will help with the purchase and rental of different items so that the director's and designers' vision can be fully realized into a high quality production that takes place in the Louis Room, one of Northwestern's performance spaces. Some of our costs include:

  • Costumes (six different characters; wardrobe changes for each week of the show's plot line)
  • Purchasing mirrors and a dance bar to transform our space into a dance studio
  • Rental of lighting and sound equipment 
  • Printing materials for advertising throughout Evanston and Chicago so that we can reach a wide, diverse audience 

Mirror the Magic 

Follow along on our official Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/pages/WAVE-Productions-presents-Circle-Mirror-Transformation/790027854372820

Come see the production December 4th, 5th, and 6th in the Louis Room of Norris University Center. The cast and production team of Circle Mirror Transformation  are so grateful for your support, be it monetary or otherwise. Thank you so much for viewing our campaign. 

Transform Our World

Together, we can bring this riveting story to life and reach the Northwestern and Evanston communities. This is a story about a group of lost, isolated souls coming together to share their lives with each other. About finding hope and love in the most unexpected of places. About taking risks in order to grow as human beings. We are proud to share this story as learners and givers in a world where magic happens everyday.

story:
Lust and Liberty's Spring Awakening is premiering in 12 days!
Get your tickets now: https://www.artful.ly/store/events/5071
Check out our website for more details: http://lustandliberty.org

About Lust & Liberty:

Lust & Liberty is a theater company based out of NYC. We experiment with classic plays and new works in an attempt to challenge naturalism and turn our expression into theater.


About Spring Awakening:

Working with a German-English translator, Lydia Light, we have had the opportunity to work with a brand new translation of this classic play. Written at the turn of the century, Spring Awakening captures the struggle of German youth to understand and explore their sexuality while living in a culture of silence. One of the ways we are examining this divide between the youth and their oppressive society is by teaming up with puppet maker, Mindy Leanse, who is creating German Expressionist inspired puppets to play most of the adult roles. As well as these puppets, the show will contain a backdrop for shadow puppetry. The costumes are inspired by the time period while the set is minimalist, with only a few props and set pieces.  A composer is joining the team to create original music for the production. The show’s design is purposefully playing with the use of modern technology and time-period costumes and props in order to bring the conversation of the show into the immediate present. We want the audience aware of fact that they are watching theater and of the difficult questions we are asking about our current society. How do we cultivate and spread the acceptance of our children for their differences? How can we stop intolerant adults from killing our youth? Where does this injustice come from? We hope that through this production we can challenge our audience to reflect on the role tolerance plays in our society and how far we still need to strive to allow the generations after us to be free of injustice.


How We Will Use The Money:

WITH OUR PRODUCTION JUST AROUND THE CORNER, WE HOPE TO BE ABLE TO PAY OUR ARTISTS (BOTH ON AND OFF STAGE) FOR THEIR TIME AND HARD WORK. YOUR DONATION WILL GOT TOWARDS STIPENDING OUR TECHNICAL CREW AS WELL AS ADDING TO STIPENDS THE ACTORS WILL RECIEVE AT THE END OF THE PROCESS. WE HOPE YOU CAN COME SEE THE SHOW AS WELL- YOUR DONATION WILL HELP MAKE THIS PROJECT A REALITY, AND WE REALLY WANT TO SHARE IT WITH YOU.

story:
I'm staging this production of HAIR along with 17 unbelievably talented cast members and loads of helping hands. We open on September 1st for four limited seating shows at the Access Theater (380 Broadway) in NYC!

Some history about HAIR, if ya didn't know...

HAIR (book and lyrics by Gerome Ragni and James Rado, music by Galt MacDermot) premiered on Broadway in April 1968 and turned the theater world upside down. It was groundbreaking for it's lack of structure, controversial themes, and killer music (including a number of songs that became radio hits). As cheesy as it sounds, and especially in an election year with all of the craziness going on in our world today, it's as relevant now as it was almost fifty years ago.

Here's the Wikipedia blurb on the plot, because they say it better than I can:

"Hair tells the story of the "tribe", a group of politically active, long-haired hippies of the "Age of Aquarius" living a bohemian life in New York City and fighting against conscription into the Vietnam War. Claude, his good friend Berger, their roommate Sheila and their friends struggle to balance their young lives, loves, and the sexual revolution with their rebellion against the war and their conservative parents and society. Ultimately, Claude must decide whether to resist the draft as his friends have done, or to succumb to the pressures of his parents (and conservative America) to serve in Vietnam, compromising his pacifistic principles and risking his life."

Here's a brief list of what your donation will go towards:

Venue rental, performance rights, rehearsal space, musicians, event insurance, fireguard certification (don't even get me started), costumes, props, set pieces, advertising, minimum one wig and probably a million flowers and bottles of water, and much more.

Please help us!! You'll make a dream come true and also support independent theater all at the same time. It doesn't get much better than that, really.

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE!

[This play is being produced in arrangement with Tams-Witmark Music Library Inc. 560 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022. They're the bees knees.]

If you have any questions about the production, how you can help, or why you should help, send an e-mail to kmdejesus@gmail.com and I'll tell you all you need to know!
story_txt: I'm staging this production of HAIR along with 17 unbelievably talented cast members and loads of helping hands. We open on September 1st for four limited seating shows at the Access Theater (380 Broadway) in NYC!Some history about HAIR, if ya didn't know...HAIR (book and lyrics by Gerome Ragni and James Rado, music by Galt MacDermot) premiered on Broadway in April 1968 and turned the theater world upside down. It was groundbreaking for it's lack of structure, controversial themes, and killer music (including a number of songs that became radio hits). As cheesy as it sounds, and especially in an election year with all of the craziness going on in our world today, it's as relevant now as it was almost fifty years ago.Here's the Wikipedia blurb on the plot, because they say it better than I can:"Hair tells the story of the "tribe", a group of politically active, long-haired hippies of the "Age of Aquarius" living a bohemian life in New York City and fighting against conscription into the Vietnam War. Claude, his good friend Berger, their roommate Sheila and their friends struggle to balance their young lives, loves, and the sexual revolution with their rebellion against the war and their conservative parents and society. Ultimately, Claude must decide whether to resist the draft as his friends have done, or to succumb to the pressures of his parents (and conservative America) to serve in Vietnam, compromising his pacifistic principles and risking his life."Here's a brief list of what your donation will go towards:Venue rental, performance rights, rehearsal space, musicians, event insurance, fireguard certification (don't even get me started), costumes, props, set pieces, advertising, minimum one wig and probably a million flowers and bottles of water, and much more.Please help us!! You'll make a dream come true and also support independent theater all at the same time. It doesn't get much better than that, really.THANK YOU IN ADVANCE![This play is being produced in arrangement with Tams-Witmark Music Library Inc. 560 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022. They're the bees knees.]If you have any questions about the production, how you can help, or why you should help, send an e-mail to kmdejesus@gmail.com and I'll tell you all you need to know!

story:
Short Summary

Dance YYC was created out of frustration - among emerging artists in particular. This online platform provides local creatives to share their workshops, shows and events while allowing access to participants in an organized and unsaturated manner. After years of working on and growing Dance YYC to encompass different needs.

Shortly after establishment in 2017, there was a vision for a Dance YYC app. 3 years of research, community input and several grant applications later, we are blessed to have received the Digital Strategic Fund from Canada Council for the Arts to get the planning process started!

Add another year of designing and planning with Terraform Corporation & we are ready to officially move into development for launch! This app is a platform for professionals to offer services (in-app booking, purchases and portfolio), provide emerging artists the opportunities to learn, share and grow while connecting the movement arts to the broader community. All without deciphering algorithms and hashtags!

What Do We Need?

To launch this app we need $125,000, this will cover costs related to:

  • Planning/Wireframes
  • Graphic design
  • Development efforts
  • Testing 
  • Project management 
  • Deployment and Publishing 

The Impact

The Dance YYC app has everything needed to elevate the movement arts community for emerging artists, professionals, enthusiasts, organizations, studios and collaborators. Replacing the algorithms with organization provides a functionality that is severely lacking in social apps like Facebook and Instagram.

To see a breakdown of the incredible features (and a sneak-peek), click here!

Follow our Instagram to see our

'Featured Feature Friday'!

 
 
 

 

 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If financial contribution is unfeasible for you at this time, please share this project campaign with anyone who has interesting in elevating the movement arts community in Calgary and surrounding areas!

story:
Who is Daisy Productions?

Daisy Productions is a Toronto-based theatre company whose goal is to provide a stage (and audience!) for up-and-coming performers and writers.

Daisy Productions was founded in the summer of 2010 in Waterloo, Ontario, by model and actress Kelly Taylor, largely due to the lack of opportunities in Waterloo Region for new playwrights to showcase their work. The company opened with the original comedy "The Other Side of the Rhyme" written by local playwright and actress Alyssa Wright. "Rhyme" went up at Kitchener-Waterloo Little Theatre, a 70-seat house, and nearly sold out every performance. With the success in Waterloo, Daisy Productions took the show to Toronto in the winter of 2011, reaching a bigger stage and audience with a 200-seat venue in North York.

After relocating to Toronto, Daisy Productions has put on several more productions including the cabaret-style variety night "Dare to Dream" at the Black Swan Tavern, which featured actors performing their favourite songs from various musicals, as well as original comedy sketches by Waterloo and Toronto writers. 

"You find yourself smitten with how game [to perform] the company is" - Film Army review of Dare to Dream

Our mandate is to continue to foster new writing and performing talent, and we would love your support to help discover and nurture these talented young adults. The road of adventures is endless for Daisy, and we can't wait to see where it takes us next!

What's "Threesome" About?

"Threesome" features three one-act plays by Canadian talent:

  • "Writer's Block" by Eleanor Kelly
  • "The Structure of my Man" by John MacDougall
  • "Donny's Day" by David Findley

After reviewing a whole pile of script submissions, these three were selected for their strong characterizations and memorable story-lines. Oh, and for their gut-wrenchingly hilarious moments. We believe in the talent of these playwrights and want to introduce people to their work.

More than that, though, "Threesome" is also our largest endeavor to date - our largest overall cast, the most time spent in rehearsal, and a more popular and better-accessible theatre space. Overall, a bigger project means a need for a larger stage and of course a proper rehearsal space. Our goal is to raise and make enough money to pay for both as well as ensure that our actors and writers are rewarded for sharing their talents with the audience. A larger venue means a broader spectrum of exposure for these writers and actors who have shown so much talent and such a willingness to give freely in the past. 

"Writer's Block" deals with the trials and tribulations facing writers, and the frustrations of not-quite-fictional characters whose lives hang in the balance.

"The Structure of my Man" takes a good hard look at the battle of the sexes - what do women really want in a man, and what do men find most attractive in a woman? May the best one win!

"Donny's Day" is a heartwarming tale about one man's struggle to get his life together, despite the shocking ineptitude and apathy of nearly everyone in his support system around him.

"Threesome" opens Thursday, January 23rd, 2014, at Unit 102 Theatre (376 Dufferin St) in Toronto.

How Your Support Will Help

Producing independent theatre in Toronto that breaks even or generates a profit at the end of its run is often challenging at the best of times. By contributing your support to this campaign, you will help the company pay for its rehearsal and performance spaces, leaving more funding to go back to the actors, writers, and toward future productions. 

Our rehearsal space will cost approximately $1500, for our four months of rehearsal prior to the show. That is a cost we are paying out before we even sell a single ticket, and is one of the lowest-priced spaces we could find in Toronto.

Our performance venue is another $800+ to rent. We hope that ticket sales will cover this cost and other parts of our budget, but won't know for sure until after the show finishes.

We've budgeted $250 to go into props and costumes. This is a low minimum, and involves begging and borrowing a lot from generous friends. 

We are putting approximately $100 into marketing and printing. Again, this is a low amount and we're doing as much through DIY as we can.

We would like to pay each of our talent a minimum of $50 at the end of the run. Actually, we'd like to be able to pay them a lot more than that. However, what we can give as an honorarium will depend on the success of ticket sales and our ability to match our overall budget. Right now, everyone working on the show is doing so on a volunteer basis.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Send people to this campaign! Invite them to the show! We welcome all generous benefactors and all forms of support.

story:
THE GIRL IN THE ENCHANTED FOREST is the story of Cassie and her teddy bear Pretend who travel to The Enchanted Forest where imagination is ruled by all. Here they meet all kinds of characters who help her a long her journey to discover what Christmas and any holiday is really about. 


I originally wrote this play for a Toy Drive that helped low income families have gifts for Christmas. I wanted to share the idea that weather or not you receive gifts or toys, that our imagination is an amazing gift we all have and the real prize is the friends and family we have. 


Hello, my name is Daniel "Danny" Muñoz. I have been working in theater for over a decade and have worked on many productions ranging from classical plays like Shakespeare to Original plays . I have worked very hard and have gained a lot of experience such as directing, stage managing, designing tech, producing, acting, and playwriting. 


This production is very important to me because it will be our last play in our current space, inside The Alexandria in downtown Los Angeles. I have been a member of Company of Angels since 2008, and really have made great friends and a second family with them. This theater company has been around for over 50 years so  I want to celebrate the work Company of Angels has done by creating a wonderful and memorable show and go out with a bang!

Where is it all going?

 I am hoping to raise 2,500 dollars that will help make this production the best it can be! All of the donations will go right into the production. With your support you'll be helping us with:

-SET (We are looking to create an enchanted forest inside the theater in a creative and abstract way. Your donations allow us to do so).

-LIGHTS- (Able to have cool lights and gels that help create the environment and mood of the play)

-COSTUMES- (Majority of the characters live in The Enchanted Forest  so their costumes and attire would reflect that).

MAKE UP- (Since several characters are part forest creatures, make up with help create the finishing touches on the looks of each character)

SOUND- (Able to have the best sound and music for ambiance and enhance experience).

PROPS- (Adding the props to create the reality of the enchanted forest and help tell the story to our best ability).

With each contribution, you receive some awesome perks. I have my dear and talented friend Cesar Carmona volunteering his Artwork he created for the show as a way to say thanks! You can also get our awesome Flyer created by another dear and talented friend Michael Ryan with our wonderful and amazing cast and crews autographs. Best perks are having tickets to the actual show so you can see for yourself what you have helped create.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you so much for taking the time to look at this campaign.  No worries if you are unable to contribute any donations, however, if you would like to help, getting the word out and sharing this with friends and family will help us so much! Thanks you and let's make some art!

story:
Help Our Dream of Owning a Studio Happen by Pledging Your Support

     The late Shirley Gaines established Seekers of Knowledge in Whiteville North Carolina in 1995. In 1998 the torch was passed  on to Mrs. Gaines's daughter Cynthia Gaines who later decided to bring the program to Boston Massachusetts; with the expansion of the participants and the programs growth, Seekers of Knowledge went from a program to a full non- profit organization. In September, dance teacher and choreographer Amy Constantino will become the director and Seekers of Knowledge will continue to excel as a full dance and arts organization. Located in the Dorchester section of Boston, Seekers of Knowledge has served over 800 girls from the Roxbury, Dorchester, Mattapan, Hype Park, and Roslindale communities. 

      Seekers of Knowledge supports the development of girls ages 6-18 through  the art of creative expression, academic support, and social emotional development. Education and discipline in the arts are essential components to building and uplifting entire communities and their children. Seekers of Knowledge aims to promote and preserve this idea and provide for our girls several avenues to growth and success. "Art is a nation’s most precious heritage. For it is in our works of art that we reveal to ourselves and to others the inner vision which guides us as a nation" Lyndon Johnson

       

              Seekers of Knowledge has Developed into 3 Main Areas:

 

  1. Developing and empowering young ladies through the art of creative expression.
  2. Providing a safe environment for young ladies to grow  socially, emotionally, and academically.
  3. Creating and performing unique, educational, and empowering productions.

 Seekers of Knowledge Provides:

  •  Professional training in dance including; ballet,  jazz, modern, contemporary, African, and stepping techniques
  • Artistic knowledge and expression through several  avenues such as Journal writing, public speaking, theatre, and arts  and crafts
  • Performance opportunities for young girls to educate,  entertain, and uplift the Boston community
  • Knowledge in current issues facing young ladies from  their communities through community service and education

  • Academic support and social responsibility

  • Cultural awareness through exchanges with national  and international organizations

  Over the years Seekers of Knowledge has turned into  not just an organization, but a unique family. Each member is cherished  for their individual talents through which they are empowered by the  mission of SOK.

Currently SOK functions out of community centers and unfortunately we have to move from location to location in order to function. You can help fuel this organization by pledging your support to help get Seekers of Knowledge  our very own dance studio. With our own studio, the possibilities are endless and all of our dreams and ideas will be made possible! In return, we will give you inside access to Seekers as it unfolds. We will share and include you in our future goals and you will forever be apart of a life changing organization. Be part of our story!!!

Check out how Seekers has already made an impact in the youth we serve! Read what our Seeker parents have to say about what we have done for their daughters. With your contribution we can make an even bigger difference in these girls lives!

Carneisha  in organization for  5 years "My daughter has a lot of confidence in herself , I would say to anyone interested in this organization that it is good for girls. The organization helps them have confidence in themselves and builds their self-esteem, It also encourages them so that they can put their minds to do anything they want to do in life. Seekers of Knowledge is like family."
Carol Davis
Boston, Mass

 

 Maliyah In organization for 3 years  "My daughter Maliyah has been part of the Seekers family for three years now and Seekers has helped her in becoming more self-confident in herself.  When my daughter states that she looks forward to going to Seekers, that says alot. When I think of Seekers of Knowledge, I think Empower."
  Melinda Stewart
Boston, Mass
 
Nichele in organization for 2 years "Thank you for providing such a valuable service. My daughter Nichele was a little shy and I noticed that the more performances she takes part in with Seekers of Knowledge the more motivated she becomes. I think Seekers of Knowledge is a great enrichment organization. I recommend you to all my associates. Thanks again"
Cherel Lockhart-Laronde
Boston, Mass

Jala in 2011 Summer Arts Series "My daughter Jala was very shy and timid when she came to seekers.  Her father and I tend to be really overprotective and wary of where we will send her to camp. She is an only child and sometimes has a hard time opening up to new things.  When we visited Seekers before she started we were so impressed with all that it had to offer.  Jala loved Seekers from the very first day! By the end of camp she grew more confident, she learned how to dance in a new way, she created new bonds and she got rid of many fears.  Seekers helped my child find her inner strength on so many levels and I thank them for that!"
Alicia Settles

 
Gabreila in organization for 2 years "My Gabriela used to be afraid to sing, speak, or dance in front of crowds, now she does it with a smile on her face. I would recommend families to Seekers because it helps girls to develop. The organization teaches the girls how to develop friendships, confidence, and etiquette."
Keely Clark-Mills
Boston, Mass
 
 
 Nashari  in organization  for 3 years

 " Shari always talks to her classmates about Seekers; her 1st grade teacher called home and told me that Shari had the whole 1st grade class doing the Dougie..... She asked Shari where she learned it from, she told her teacher Seekers. Her teacher said whatever program she is in it is helping her to be a well-rounded young lady. If I had to recommend any young lady to this organization, I would tell them that their daughter would be forever changed if they're in a shell they'll come out of it in this organization. Seekers of Knowledge has helped my daughter to open up and not be afraid to try new things."
Tacquice Scott
Boston, Mass

 

 

 

The Impact You Will Make

Our girls benefit from Seekers of Knowledge in numerous ways. Girls that participate in this organization often do not have enough resources and funds to obtain quality dance education from private studios. With the training they are receiving at Seekers, they will be able to continue an education and a career in the fields of dance and art. Seekers also takes a huge amount of pride in providing a safe space where our girls can be part of a positive and productive organization..

All of our funds raised will go towards purchasing a studio space in Dorchester and hiring professional teachers.

Seekers of Knowledge has helped my daughter to open up and not be afraid to try new things." Tacquice ScottBoston, Mass   The Impact You Will Make
Our girls benefit from Seekers of Knowledge in numerous ways. Girls that participate in this organization often do not have enough resources and funds to obtain quality dance education from private studios. With the training they are receiving at Seekers, they will be able to continue an education and a career in the fields of dance and art. Seekers also takes a huge amount of pride in providing a safe space where our girls can be part of a positive and productive organization.. 
All of our funds raised will go towards purchasing a studio space in Dorchester and hiring professional teachers.

story:
Help us take our annual production from rehearsal to the stage!

We are a small non-profit organization looking for help covering costs for our benefit production this year (it takes a lot of money to put on a production with a cast of over 20 dancers and actors.)   With our expenses underwritten, we can provide our beneficiary the full proceeds of the show, and with six shows planned, we are in a position to give some real help to those dealing with Alzheimer's Disease.  Donations are tax deductible, and you can feel good about promoting the arts while supporting a wonderful cause!  Read on to learn more about us, our show, and how you can help.

Dance from the Heart presents our 2013 annual benefit production, Domari.   Through a kaleidoscope of dance forms, Domari recounts the story of Marion Carruthers and her interaction with a group of Romani who arrive in Scotland in 1530. When attacked by a visiting Laird, Marion takes refuge with these “Gypsies” until King Henry’s Egyptians Act drives them from Scotland.  Forced to marry against her will and thus remain behind, Marion must entrust the Romani and her best friend with her newborn daughter as they wander through Europe.  More than twenty years later, the Romani return in search of Marion and a place to call home only to face a harsher version of the Egyptians Act that divides their camp and threatens their lives. 

A story of friendship, family, prejudice, tolerance, acceptance, and love.

Domari will be performed at the Berry Center Theater on November 1, 2, 8 & 9.

All proceeds of this production go to Baylor College of Medicine's Alzheimer's Disease and Memory Disorders Center (ADMDC), whose focus is on the translation of discoveries made in the laboratory into improved methods of disease prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

 

As we continue through our daily lives dancing, working, caring for our friends and families, we do so with appreciation of those we have lost who were most precious to us.

All of us at Dance from the Heart have been impacted by the loss of loved ones who shaped our lives and influenced on who we are and the choices we make.

Our desire to help others has been reinforced by the understanding of how impactful those losses are. We strive to do what we can, in some small measure, to lessen the burden for others.

On behalf of all of those close to our hearts, past, present and future, we sincerely thank you for your support.

For more information about additional ways to support please email us at  info@dfth.org!

story:
I wanted to take a moment to share with you a vision of mine that has manifested into The Philadelphia Youth Dance Fest (PYDF) and ask for your help in continuing to make this vision a reality.     

The Philadelphia Youth Dance Fest, a pre-professional dance festival, is designed to share, unite, and celebrate dance in a supportive and professional atmosphere. Over 200 students ranging from ages 13-18 years are given an opportunity to perform in a professional venue. They are offered a variety of master classes from different genres of dance to further enhance their knowledge of dance culture. It is an occasion that will allow them an opportunity to learn from their peers and gain a sense of community.

I had been envisioning a festival like this for several years before making the decision, last year, to produce it.  I noticed that there were so many pre-professional companies in the area, but nothing to bring them together.  After a successful run last year, the festival has now doubled in size with over 200 students and 16 companies participating this year!!!

This year's festival will be held at the Arts Bank at University of the Arts on March 7 and 8, 2015 and will offer master classes for the students in Contemporary Technique, Ballroom Dance, and African Dance.

Companies are traveling from as far as Butler, PA, Chester, PA, Lancaster County, PA, Wilmington DE, Dover, DE, as well as our very own Philadelphia and it’s suburbs to dance in this festival.

The performances will include the companies of Babylon School of Dance, Butler Center for the Performing Arts, Beat Addikts United, Chester Valley Dance Academy, COBALT Dance Company, Dance Elite, Dancefusion’s fusion2, Delaware Ballet, Delaware Valley Dance Academy, Institute of Dance Artistry, International Ballet Theater, Janice’s DanceWorks, Metropolitan Ballet Company, Opus 2 Project, Philadelphia Dance Theatre, and Wissahickon Dance Academy.

Would you please consider making a tax deductible donation to The Philadelphia Youth Dance Fest (PYDF), an annual festival that unites and enriches young dancers.  

With your support: 

- We can rent the theatre for the Youth companies to perform two shows in a professional venue. 

- Students are able to participate in master classes of different dance genres.

-We can pay teachers of high caliber training to pass along their knowledge of dance 

- Scholarships will be offered to students with financial hardships.

This master class program develops a well-rounded dancer. They gain an appreciation for new forms of dance from different cultural backgrounds.The students have the opportunity to take class with peers from the other dance studios. This establishes new friendships and role models. 

With your support, we look forward to expanding the master class program each year!

Your donation to the Philadelphia Youth Dance Fest, in any capacity, is deeply appreciated! The reality for arts organizations, of any size, is that they are substantially supported by individuals!

With deepest thanks and wishes of health and happiness….

Gratefully,

Melissa Chisena

PYDF Director/Producer

story:
Adventure Through Space and Time

We're a group of college kids from the University of Florida who want to create the most fantastic Doctor Who based musical the world has ever seen. The fourth annual Whosical, Whosical the Musical: A Game of Time, is stoked as smoke to be showing it's stuff at Swampcon: Total Annihilation on February 7th. The Doctor, the Winchesters, and so many more characters are ready to take the stage by storm. But we need your help to make our show happen

What We Need

Whosical the Musical is free to the public, which means our budget doesn't quite reach to the stars. We have the support of SwampCon and the University of Florida Student Government, but set, costumes, and props cost a lot of money. Our current budget of $250 dollars only stretches so far. We want to bring the Doctor and his world to life, and every member of our cast and crew gives everything they can every day. But at the end of that day, we need your help to make this show everything that we know it can be.

Goals

To reach our potential, we need at least $50. $50 would make us so happy, we could sing. And we will. If this Indiegogo reaches that bare minimum goal, we will release a soundtrack of the show alongside all of our perks. 
$200 - Our show can have playbills! Most of our props last year were made out of cardboard, paint, and the devotion only a college student on coffee can give at three in the morning. Playbills would be a dream come true. And if you contribute at least $5, you will be in that playbill. 

Update #1

We made $200! Those shiny li'l playbills up there? We got em! Your generosity blew us straight out of the water, and landed all of you wonderful contributors in the playbills for the show. But why stop here? This is the little show that could, and we're gonna keep chugging. We've added a couple of extra stretch goals below, cause this train needs tracks. Alright, no more metaphors. I promise.
$400 - We would make a platform out of wood and our undying appreciation, throw it on the stage, and shout how much we love you all. A platform will elevate our actors so that even the Inuyasha cosplayer way in the back row who came in late because his panel ran long can see our show.
$600 - You know what our Doctor doesn't have? A proper trenchcoat. You know what he will have if we reach this goal? The most amazing, incredible, proper trench coat the world has ever seen.

Update #2

Stunned. As we pull this campaign to a close, all I can say is that we have been completely stunned by everyone's generosity. The outpouring of support from friends, family, and strangers on the internet surpassed anything we expected from this campaign. You allowed us to let our imaginations run wild. You let us think big. Plans we couldn't dream of fulfilling became possible thanks to you. Okay, now I'm starting to tear up a bit. Hold it in, man!
We accomplished every goal on this page, save for the $1000 goal, which we only missed due to timing and scheduling issues. Thanks to this Indiegogo and a surprisingly effective bake sale, we have playbills, a platform, and a proper trenchcoat for our Doctor. This year's Whosical was made possible thanks to contributers like you. Thank you.
$1000 - This is a big one. The day of the show is the first day that we get to see the stage, use the equipment, and test out the play in that space. Because that is one big space. and it costs a TON of money to rent out. Like, so much money. But if we get so much money, say, $1000, then we can use the stage before hand! We can have time to practice on that stage and learn how to use that tech a couple days before, and that will help our show out tremendously. If we reach this stretch goal, we will rent out the performance space and the tech (microphones, lights) a day or two before the show so we can have a chance to practice with it.

Our History

We started running this show in 2012. Every year, we write new scripts, audition new actors, and bring our dreams to life. This is the biggest and brightest show we've ever pulled off, and we can't wait to show you what we've been working on since last summer. Help us to make this the greatest year the Whosical has ever seen.

story:
Summary

We are putting up a production of Tennessee Williams most autobiographical and beloved play 'The Glass Menagerie' at the Sherry Theater in the NOHO Arts District on July 16th, 17th, 18th, 23rd, 24th and 25th 2015.  It's a dream come true being given the chance to put up this most beautiful play of Modern American Theater. Getting the rights to perform this play has been three years in the making.  Now we are hoping to raise $5000 to make our vision of 'The Glass Menagerie' come true and add to the enrichment of the Los Angeles theater world.  You don't wanna miss this one.  It will be a dream!  
Your donation can help us make this happen!  Please support us!  
Dates: July 16th, 17th, 18th, 23rd, 24th and 25th 
Time: 8PM
Location: The Sherry Theater, 11052 Magnolia Blvd, North Hollywood, CA 91601
Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/events/853638038041911/

Synopsis:

Amanda Wingfield is a faded, tragic remnant of Southern gentility who lives in poverty in a dingy St. Louis apartment with her son, Tom, and her daughter, Laura. Amanda strives to give meaning and direction to her life and the lives of her children, though her methods are ineffective and irritating. Tom is driven nearly to distraction by his mother's nagging and seeks escape in alcohol and the world of the movies. Laura also lives in her illusions. She is crippled, and this defect, intensified by her mother's anxiety to see her married, has driven her more and more into herself. The crux of the action comes when Tom invites a young man of his acquaintance to take dinner with the family. Jim, the caller, is a nice ordinary fellow who is at once pounced upon by Amanda as a possible husband for Laura. In spite of her crude and obvious efforts to entrap the young man, he and Laura manage to get along very nicely, and momentarily Laura is lifted out of herself into a new world. But this crashes when, toward the end, Jim explains that he is already engaged. The world of illusion that Amanda and Laura have striven to create in order to make life bearable collapses about them. Tom, too, at the end of his tether, at last leaves home.

A drama of great tenderness, charm and beauty, THE GLASS MENAGERIE is one of the most famous plays of the modern theatre.


Director:  Ciera Danielle

Ciera Danielle is an award winning actress and filmmaker. As an actor, she has worked professionally for over a decade now, most recently in James Franco's (127 Hours) "Child of God", starring opposite Dale Dickey (Winters Bone) in the upcoming "Bella" and starring opposite Lou Diamond Phillips (La Bamba) in "The Last Train", which she also produced. It was her directorial debut in the feature film "Daisy's", which she also wrote and starred in, which began her dynamic filmmaking career. "Daisy's" went on to win numerous awards, including Best Feature Film, Best Screenplay and Best Actress, and was the inspiration for the founding of Ciera's production company, Love & Lavoro Films. She is an artist first and foremost and is elated at the opportunity to direct a work of art like The Glass Menagerie.


Cast:

Role: Laura Wingfield:  

Katharina Magdalena is from Salzburg, Austria. After graduating from The Stella Adler Acadamy of Acting, she continued studying the Meisner Technique at Playhouse West. She lives in Los Angeles where she continuously works in film and theater. Katharina has been cast as Marie Antoinette, the lead in the feature film THE COLOR OF FLESH slated to film next year.  She has also recently been cast to portray the blind Austrian pianist Maria Theresa von Paradis, the female lead in the THE COMFORT OF DARKNESS slated to film in December 2015.  Playing Laura in THE GLASS MENAGERIE is a dream come true.  She thanks you for your support. 


Role: Jim O'Connor 

Don Jeanes is from Houston, Texas. After graduating from college Don spent two years in New York performing in several Off off Broadway productions. He now lives in Los Angeles where he continuously works in film, television, commercials and print. He has appeared on Days of our Lives, CSI: NY, Criminal Minds, The Exes and in the feature film Pandorum. Don is most well know for playing Neil Armstrong in Transformers: Dark of the Moon and as the horse trainer in the 2013, 2014, and 2015 Budweiser Clydesdale Super Bowl commercials. He thanks you for your support. 


Role: Amanda Wingfield                                                                                                              

Jane Macfie                                                                                                                                 Theater: Broadway: Long Day's Journey into Night and Ah, Wilderness, with Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst, West Coast: Tartuffe, Pericles, Blithe Spirit – (A Noise Within), Hay Fever, How the Other Half Loves (Robby Award), Major Barbara,  Born Yesterday (South Coast Rep.),Title role in Hamlet, Much Ado About Nothing, As You Like It, Private Lives, Blithe Spirit, the Man Who Came to Dinner, Steel Magnolias (Grove Theater Center), Sir Peter Hall’s Romeo and Juliet (Ahmanson Theatre) etc.  Founding member Pasadena Shakespeare Company. Film: Daddy’s Little Angel, High Water. Television: Doris (recurring) – the Mindy Project, Officer Penny Pike in The Wedding Band, House of Lies, Strong Medicine (recurring), Frasier, Profiler, Maloney, Get Real. MFA Yale School of Drama. 


Role: Tom Wingfield  

Tyler Jack Rice is from Chicago, Illinois. After studying theatre at Drake University, he continued his studies in San Fransisco at the Academy of Art University. He then moved to Los Angeles where he began his training at Playhouse West. He continues to work in film and can be seen in Where Fate Meets, American Backwoods: Slewhampshire, The Pocketeers, Worm and Poor Boys, which won him the Best Performance Award at the Mockfest Film Festival.  He thanks you for your support


What We Need & What You Get

Our company is seeking $5,000 for the realization of this project.  The budget will be used for:

  • Rights to perform the play

    Theater Rental

    Rehearsal Space

    Set Design

    Costumes

    Postcards/Poster

  • We offer a very unique perk.  If you invest $25 you will receive one ticket to the play.  The tickets cost $20 if you purchase them the day off, but this way you can help us get pre-sales and raise our funds that way.  And if you intended to come and see us in the play anyway, you just basically bought your ticket in advance and helped us out with a $5 donation.  If you invest $50 you will get two tickets and you will help us out with a $10 donation.  If you invest anything $75 or higher you will be invited to our special preview performance, followed by a Q&A and a chance to meet the actors.  We will be serving Hors d'oeuvres and wine.  Every supporter will be thanked in the program.  Also if you contribute more than $500 you will get an Executive Producer credit in the program.
  • We will make the play happen with however much funding we get.  $5000 would allow us to have enough funds to create the set design of our dreams.  If we have any less we will still try to come as close as possible to our original vision.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and share our campaign on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter by using Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much!

Love and Light to you!

Warm Regards,

Ciera, Katharina, Don, Jane and Tyler

Colleen Dewhurst, West Coast: Tartuffe, Pericles, Blithe Spirit – (A Noise
Within), Hay Fever, How the Other Half Loves (Robby Award), Major Barbara,  Born Yesterday (South Coast Rep.),Title role in Hamlet, Much Ado About
Nothing, As You Like It, Private Lives, Blithe Spirit, the Man Who Came to
Dinner, Steel Magnolias (Grove Theater Center), Sir Peter
Hall’s Romeo and Juliet (Ahmanson Theatre) etc.  Founding member Pasadena
Shakespeare Company. Film: Daddy’s Little
Angel, High Water. Television: Doris (recurring) – the Mindy Project, Officer
Penny Pike in The Wedding Band, House of Lies, Strong Medicine (recurring),
Frasier, Profiler, Maloney, Get Real. MFA Yale School of Drama. 

Role: Tom Wingfield  


Tyler Jack Rice is from Chicago, Illinois. After studying theatre at Drake University, he continued his studies in San Fransisco at the Academy of Art University. He then moved to Los Angeles where he began his training at Playhouse West. He continues to work in film and can be seen in Where Fate Meets, American Backwoods: Slewhampshire, The Pocketeers, Worm and Poor Boys, which won him the Best Performance Award at the Mockfest Film Festival.  He thanks you for your support

   What We Need & What You Get Our
company is
seeking $5,000
for the realization of this project.  The
budget will be used for:


Rights
to perform the play
Theater
Rental
Rehearsal
Space
Set
Design
Costumes
Postcards/Poster

We offer a very unique perk.  If you invest $25 you will receive one ticket to the play.  The tickets cost $20 if you purchase them the day off, but this way you can help us get pre-sales and raise our funds that way.  And if you intended to come and see us in the play anyway, you just basically bought your ticket in advance and helped us out with a $5 donation.  If you invest $50 you will get two tickets and you will help us out with a $10 donation.  If you invest anything $75 or higher you will be invited to our special preview performance, followed by a Q&A and a chance to meet the actors.  We will be serving Hors d'oeuvres and wine.  Every supporter will be thanked in the program.  Also if you contribute more than $500 you will get an Executive Producer credit in the program.

We will make the play happen with however much funding we get.  $5000 would allow us to have enough funds to create the set design of our dreams.  If we have any less we will still try to come as close as possible to our original vision.


    Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word and share our campaign on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter by using Indiegogo share tools!
Thank you so much!
Love and Light to you!
Warm Regards,
Ciera, Katharina, Don, Jane and Tyler

story:
Othie: A Woman's Adaptation of Othello is a twist on a story that many of us are familiar with. By switching the genders of Othello and Desdemona we are able to really delve into the way we as a society often sexualize and vilify women in power, especially women in color. It is the goal of the show to explore how society can play on insecurities of women and force to them to believe things about themselves and others,  and the sometime unfortunate results of those thoughts.

This production will serve as a large learning experience for me and many other college students. The project will allow me to combine both my Drama and Psychology majors along as making my producing and directing debut. Other students will be involved in the show, developing their theatre education as this will be a complete student production. Though I am doing this as theatre project at my college I am receiving no financial support from my school and need your help to make this dream a reality! 

The production itself will be free admission with a suggested donation, the proceeds will be given to the Women's Opportunity Center of Ithaca. 

LOOK FOR "OTHIE" TO ARRIVE MID-APRIL!

Adapted and Directed by: Brittany Carey

Assistant Director and Choreographer: Ashton Muniz

Stage Manager: Sam Salloway

Media and Marketing Manager: Cara Frisina

Lead Designer: Tyler Hampton

Assistant Choreographer: Emily Viancourt 

Project Advisor: Angela Brannerman

Project Mentor: Godfrey Simmons

Thank you for your support!

story:
Three Scientists. One Experiment. No Clue.

TheScientistsPlay.com

THE SCIENTISTS, created by Mark Costello, Sean Daniels, Eric Mercado, & Evan Watkins, is a historical farce (with music) based on true events, with a "three stooges" twist.  The World Premiere production will hit the road in Summer 2014--but only with YOUR HELP!



Desperate to be the new wunderkind of the scientific community, Dr. Hermann Ebbinghaus will do anything to present at the 1889 World’s Fair in Paris. But when his aspirations of fame and fortune are foiled by his mentor-turned-nemesis Dr. Louis Pasteur, Ebbinghaus calls on his best pals Mssr. Longrais and Herr Weiss to propel him to scientific glory. Fueled by a steady stream of cocktails, fantasies of Marie Curie, and a few songs, our three unlikely heroes stumble upon a bona fide breakthrough that puts their dream within their grasp. If only they could remember to put down the scotch.

After a number of successful readings in NYC, we are ready to share the story of these lovable buffoons with audiences nationwide with performances in:

Portland, ME: June 27-29 as a part of the PortFringe Festival
Chicago IL: August 28-September 7 as a part of the Chicago Fringe Festival
Rochester NY: September 25-27 as a part of the Rochester Fringe Festival 
(Read more!)


Photo by Bailey Carr

Every performance of The Scientists is guaranteed to be unique as each city will feature a local guest star as the saucy vixen, Marie Curie! The show also features Elizabeth Spano as the nefarious Dr. Louis Pasteur, original music by Peter MacDuffie and costumes by Alinne Fernandes. Stage managed by Sarah Shutt, and produced by Meredith Dixon.

We are hard at work testing our tubes and bunsening our burners to bring this show to life. With your generous support we can get our heroes out of the history books, on to the stage, and into Marie Curie's bloomers!


We need your help to get us to the 1889 World's Fair!

As you can imagine, laboratories are expensive. Your donation will pay for:

A Roof Over Our Head: Unfortunately rehearsal spaces and venues won't accept kisses from Marie as payment.  30% of our budget is expected to cover rehearsal, festival, & administrative fees.
Making Us Look Good: As dapper as we are, corsets, soft lighting, and a picturesque backdrop will only enhance our natural beauty. 10% of our budget is expected to cover the design of the show.
Planes,Trains, Automobiles: We're covering a lot of ground, and traveling by carriage is impractical. 40% of our budget is expected to cover travel.
Butts In Seats: After all, the only thing worse than an empty glass, is an empty theatre. 20% of our budget is expected to cover audience development.
Our Unending Gratitude


WHAT YOU CAN DO

1) Donate Now! Click on the "Contribute Now" button at the top of the page to give via credit card or PayPal and claim your perk! (Don't forget you can double the size of your gift if your employer has a corporate match program. Email us for more info.)

2) Connect with us! Are we visiting your town? Do you also have a crush on Marie Curie? Can you make a good cocktail with a beaker? We want to hear from you! Follow us on social media!

3) Spread the word! We can only wire so many telegrams ourselves.

(Online donation not your drink of choice? We can accept gifts via check or donated goods. Contact us at thescientistsplay@gmail.com) 


Photo by Bailey Carr


Sean Daniels, Mark Costello, Eric Mercado, and Evan Watkins are the co-founders of MERKINS, DANIELLO & SONS, a Brooklyn based collective of theater makers who met at NYU studying devised theatre. They are dedicated to creating comical, compelling, and thought-provoking theater. Their most recent project “Not Without My Gallbladder” opened to acclaim at the 2013 Planet Connections Theatre Festivity in NYC, receiving 8 awards nominations and winning Best Direction and Best Lead Actress in a Musical. 

Individually their work has been seen at HERE Arts Center, Abrons Arts Center, Theater for the New City, 3-Legged Dog, New York Theater Workshop, the Wings Theater, the Gene Frankel, the Flea, the Robert Moss, the Incubator, 9th Space, PS122 (with Wooster Group’s “Avant Garde-Arama”), Galapagos Art Space, Underground Arts (in Philly), The Tank, the Connelly, the Howl! Festival at Theater 80 St. Marks, Baruch College, and the DR2.

Thanks for your support! For more information and updates on The Scientists, visit our website at www.TheScientistsPlay.com

story:
Who is Project: Motion Modern Dance Collective?  

Project: Motion is a Memphis-based not-for-profit modern dance collective devoted to the creation and presentation of innovative, well-crafted dance works that inspire, stimulate and engage audiences on an intellectual, emotional and physical level. Project: Motion fosters artistic collaborations and provides a forum for local dance artists to experiment, develop skills and hone artistic vision in a nurturing and challenging environment. We are Memphis’ longest running modern dance collective!

What is Bloodlines + Bylines?

Project: Motion Modern Dance Collective digs deep into the stories that shape us with its upcoming May show. The modern dance collective returns to the Evergreen Theatre for a moving experience of all-new dance works mined from true Memphis stories.

Guest artist and writer, Anna Esquivel, masterfully weaves stories of family harvested from writing and movement workshops Project: Motion held at Knowledge Quest Memphis, Madonna Learning Center, and Town Village at Audubon Park in the Fall of 2014. In Bloodlines + Bylines, Project: Motion premieres original choreography based on these stories from Bethany Wells Bak, Rebecca Cochran, Emily Hefley, Louisa Koeppel, and Wayne M. Smith. As a fascinating twist, the works will be presented in an open stage without wings, removing the boundaries between onstage and offstage so that dancers are performing continually throughout the show.

What We Need

  • Dancer and Choreographer Fees
  • Set Materials and Costumes
  • Theater, Rehearsal, and Venue Rental Fees
The Impact

Founded in 1987 by Ann Halligan Donahue and Judith Tribo Wombwell, Project: Motion was established to serve as a vehicle for the creation, exploration and presentation of quality modern dance on a professional level in the mid-south region. 28 years later, Project: Motion continues to be an increasingly important catalyst for creative exchange, innovation and expression in the modern dance/theatre community of Memphis.

In addition to our various performances throughout the city, Project: Motion continues its commitment to engage our community by offering a wide range of technique classes taught by rotating instructors that are offered twice a week. Project: Motion dances for the Memphis community and we covet the active support of the community in the creation and presentation of dance. 
IT TAKES A VILLAGE TO RAISE A DANCE AND WE COVET YOUR SUPPORT!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make some noise about our campaign by sharing with friends.
  • Show your support for Project: Motion at Bloodlines + Bylines, May 15-17th
  • Come get a MOVE ON with us through our classes offered to the community.
  • Go to www.projectmotiondance.org and check us out!

story:
Help Storm Warnings Spread the Word!

Storm Warnings Repertory Theatre is presenting our first performance of the season, So Far Away, written and directed by Paul Dervis. 

By purchasing your tickets through our Indiegogo campaign, you will help us pay for our advertising costs. 

As a special thank  you for your support, we are offering two tickets for the price of one.
story_txt:
Help Storm Warnings Spread the Word!

 Storm Warnings Repertory Theatre is presenting our first performance of 
the season, So Far Away, written and directed by Paul Dervis.  By 
purchasing your tickets through our Indiegogo campaign, you will help us pay for our advertising costs.  
As a special thank  you for your support, we are offering two tickets for the price of one.

story:
welcome to the club. yup, you did it.

we’re really glad you've joined.

the premise of brooklyn theatre club is simple: staged readings where the main parts are performed by members of the btc company, while small roles and ensemble singing are cast amongst our attendees (with musical materials provided, of course). theatre fans enjoy the show, the more adventurous join along, and everyone involved becomes one hell of a cast party.

part musical theatre, part drunken singalong. all fun and all together.

if you enjoy theatre or silliness or partying as much as we do, you’ll understand what brooklyn theatre club is all about. our audience is part of the show because the songs always sound better when everyone sings along.

our indiegogo and your help will raise the funds needed to produce the first year of programming of brooklyn theatre club and beyond. it will help us acquire the rights to five shows this year and cover the additional expenses needed to build the name and reputation of our budding theatre company.

this year's season of brooklyn theatre club programming equals 4 shows plus a halloween fundraiser. theatre rights clock in at about $1000/show. 

5 shows over 1 year = $5000

our $4000 goal will get us started on this expensive process.

next question on your lips might be: why not just go rogue and do the shows without the rights?

WELL, we want to see brooklyn theatre club with its name in lights. and like any other legitimate theatre, be it broadway, off-brodaway, or off-off-off-off-broadway-across-the-bridge like us, we need to obtain the rights to these shows so that we can promote as much as possible and and reach the widest audience.

show profits will go towards saving for a venue space of our own in brooklyn (our clubhouse!) so that we can produce more shows and a wider range of performance art. we also hope to pay our actors with these profits. unlike some other theatre companies, we will not make our club members pay dues for their participation. instead, we hope to pay our talent for the time and effort they put into their professional performances with the club.

from our start with les miserables (a 23rd birthday party)

and the mystery of edwin drood (the inspiration)

to you’re a good man charlie brown (the test run),

our friends and supporters have already responded so well to the idea of brooklyn theatre club. our indiegogo goal will help take this idea out of rooftops and apartments where we have previously performed and instead bring this idea to the masses.

every member of our audience is a member of the club, and in that simple philosophy, we want new friends of all performing backgrounds (even those who only shine in the shower). we want to create an environment where everyone gets the chance to perform - professionals, amateurs, and drunk warblers alike.

we don’t want competition or judgment.

we don't want member dues.

we want to get together with our old and new friends and sing through a show, just like how we were founded.

in a borough that changes every day, our goal is to bring something special back to it. we are so passionate about the club and we can’t wait for you to come sing along.

BTC4EVZ great thanks,
