story:
UPDATE (9/6/14): The new fundraising goal is $2,750 to ensure my ability to buy more speakers and music for an even better experience at your next competition!

---

Hello! My name is Daniel Libatique. I am a competitive ballroom dancer specializing in the American Smooth and Rhythm styles at the Open level in both. I have also been a musician for over 17 years, with experience in playing instruments (piano, guitar, mandolin, violin, banjo, and bass) and singing in theatrical shows and choirs.

I want to become a competitive ballroom DJ for the northeast collegiate competitive circuit, the one where I rose from Newcomer to Open, and give competitors music that will inspire and energize them. 

The circuit has given me so much, and now I want to give back in the form of the music collection that I have spent the last five years cultivating and which continues to be updated with fresh, new music nearly every day. My collection has found its way into practice sessions, supervised rounds, rehearsals, and phones and iPods all across the country, and I believe that my collection can go further and add energy and excitement to competitions where that energy and excitement has been lacking.

What is this campaign for?

The objective of this campaign is to raise money for three major expenses involved in becoming a competitive DJ:

1. A speaker system. To pump out the requisite amount of sound for a normal collegiate ballroom competition, I will need (at least) two speakers, two stands, a mixer, a microphone, and the requisite cables and warranties. Based on my research, the cost for this equipment will hover somewhere between $1,000-$1,500, making it the largest expense and the main reason for this fundraising campaign.

2. Music funds. Much of my collection lives on clients like Spotify that let you play the music but do not allow you to edit the songs. With the funds through this campaign, I could actually purchase current dancesport CDs and download even more music in order to edit and regularize tempi, remove strange measures with dropped beats, and ensure proper introductions for songs.

3. Travel funds. If payment for DJ services is rendered after the event, I would need money before the fact to reserve a Zipcar or rental car to transport my equipment (and myself) to and from the competition. Any funds not dedicated to the speaker system or music funds can live in a replenishable fund set aside for this purpose.

If I do not meet my goal, the money raised will be augmented gradually by savings until I have enough money to purchase the speaker system and a significant amount of music.

If I do not reach my goal, the money will be gradually augmented by savings until I have enough funds for the speaker system and a significant amount of music.

What You Get

Different levels of contribution earn different prizes! Any individual, whether an amateur, a professional, a social dancer, or simply a dance fan, or group, especially collegiate teams and executive boards, can contribute!

$5 - Thank you!

$10 - A shout-out in my next vlog at youtube.com/danielpauperrimus.

$25 - A personalized playlist of 4/5 songs for whatever purpose you choose (including personalized rounds in any of the four competitive styles).

$50 - A voiceover commentary on your performance at a competition of your choosing (one style, and video must be provided — syllabus dancers preferred) and a personalized playlist of 4/5 songs (Two [2] playlists if you opt out of the commentary, do not compete, or are a group or organization).

$75 - Two voiceover commentaries on your performance at a competition of your choosing (two styles, and video must be provided — syllabus dancers preferred) and two personalized playlists of 4/5 songs each (Four [4] playlists if you  opt out of the commentaries, do not compete, or are a group or organization).

$200 - Discounted DJ services at your next competition* ($200 off the normal rate) and all prizes at the $10 and 75 levels.

$400 - Complimentary DJ services at your next competition* and all prizes at the $10 and 75 levels. (6 available)

*I aim to be fully ready to DJ competitions by Spring 2015. If you would like to book me before then, we can discuss further.

    Spread the Word!

    Please make sure to spread the word about this campaign, especially if you know competitors in the northeast collegiate circuit who would potentially benefit from an up-to-date, exciting, inspiring collection of music being played at their next competition!

    Thank you for stopping by, and see you on the dance floor!

I have also been a musician for over 17 years, with experience in playing instruments (piano, guitar, mandolin, violin, banjo, and bass) and singing in theatrical shows and choirs.
I want to become a competitive ballroom DJ for the northeast collegiate competitive circuit, the one where I rose from Newcomer to Open, and give competitors music that will inspire and energize them. 
The circuit has given me so much, and now I want to give back in the form of the music collection that I have spent the last five years cultivating and which continues to be updated with fresh, new music nearly every day. My collection has found its way into practice sessions, supervised rounds, rehearsals, and phones and iPods all across the country, and I believe that my collection can go further and add energy and excitement to competitions where that energy and excitement has been lacking.
What is this campaign for?
The objective of this campaign is to raise money for three major expenses involved in becoming a competitive DJ:
1. A speaker system. To pump out the requisite amount of sound for a normal collegiate ballroom competition, I will need (at least) two speakers, two stands, a mixer, a microphone, and the requisite cables and warranties. Based on my research, the cost for this equipment will hover somewhere between $1,000-$1,500, making it the largest expense and the main reason for this fundraising campaign.2. Music funds. Much of my collection lives on clients like Spotify that let you play the music but do not allow you to edit the songs. With the funds through this campaign, I could actually purchase current dancesport CDs and download even more music in order to edit and regularize tempi, remove strange measures with dropped beats, and ensure proper introductions for songs.3. Travel funds. If payment for DJ services is rendered after the event, I would need money before the fact to reserve a Zipcar or rental car to transport my equipment (and myself) to and from the competition. Any funds not dedicated to the speaker system or music funds can live in a replenishable fund set aside for this purpose.
If I do not meet my goal, the money raised will be augmented gradually by savings until I have enough money to purchase the speaker system and a significant amount of music.
If I do not reach my goal, the money will be gradually augmented by savings until I have enough funds for the speaker system and a significant amount of music.

What You Get
Different levels of contribution earn different prizes! Any individual, whether an amateur, a professional, a social dancer, or simply a dance fan, or group, especially collegiate teams and executive boards, can contribute!
$5 - Thank you!
$10 - A shout-out in my next vlog at youtube.com/danielpauperrimus.


$25 - A personalized playlist of 4/5 songs for whatever purpose you choose (including personalized rounds in any of the four competitive styles).
$50 - A voiceover commentary on your performance at a competition of your choosing (one style, and video must be provided — syllabus dancers preferred) and a personalized playlist of 4/5 songs (Two [2] playlists if you opt out of the commentary, do not compete, or are a group or organization).
$75 - Two voiceover commentaries on your performance at a competition of your choosing (two styles, and video must be provided — syllabus dancers preferred) and two personalized playlists of 4/5 songs each (Four [4] playlists if you  opt out of the commentaries, do not compete, or are a group or organization).
$200 - Discounted DJ services at your next competition* ($200 off the normal rate) and all prizes at the $10 and 75 levels.
$400 - Complimentary DJ services at your next competition* and all prizes at the $10 and 75 levels. (6 available)
*I aim to be fully ready to DJ competitions by Spring 2015. If you would like to book me before then, we can discuss further.


  Spread the Word!
Please make sure to spread the word about this campaign, especially if you know competitors in the northeast collegiate circuit who would potentially benefit from an up-to-date, exciting, inspiring collection of music being played at their next competition!
Thank you for stopping by, and see you on the dance floor!

story:
THE BLUE JAR

Artistic Abandon NYC presents an original dance theatre production, THE BLUE JAR. It is a story of adventure and romance. A story of intimate moments and the wonder of nature. A story about infinite longing.

It's about a girl, Helena who loses something, and spends a lifetime trying to find it again. Helena and the cast of THE BLUE JAR take the audience on a journey where they discover the cure for anything is salt water: sweat, tears, or the sea.

We produced the World Premiere of THE BLUE JAR at The Cherry Lane Theatre this past February to sold out audiences.  We performed and premiered original choreography, music, and story that took months of development.

Our challenge now is to continue to develop our workshop production of THE BLUE JAR into an even bluer and fuller story. Our goal is to produce a residency this Fall at a stage in NYC. 

Creating an original show takes work. It takes time. It takes money. It takes a community of individuals supporting and curating the next generation of art and performance.


Artistic Abandon NYC

Artistic Abandon NYC is a New York City based platform for performance celebrating freedom of expression and artistic collaboration. Artists are committed to creating fearlessly and inspiring others to do the same, as they continue their journey to make their passion their profession.


As performers living in the city, it has become apparent that there are far more performers than there are performance opportunities. Many artists in these circumstances grow to doubt their art and give up on their dream. Artistic Abandon NYC is committed to inspiring artists to create their own work and performances through collaboration and community. With your contribution, we will create a new performance opportunity and artistic community that inspires artists to collaborate and create art fearlessly.

Why We Need Your Support

The Blue Jar will be held at The Cherry Lane Theatre in the West Village, NYC. (www.cherrylanetheatre.org). Cherry Lane is home to the Obie Award-winning mentor project and New York's longest continuously running Off-Broadway theatre.

The cost for renting this venue, paying technicians, creating set pieces, costumes, and renting rehearsal space is $5,000. Our creative team and performers have donated their time and talent to this project.

Your financial support will create a sustainable space for artists to perform and audiences to be inspired.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t financially contribute, you can help!

Like us on Facebook at: facebook.com/ArtisticAbandonNYC

Follow us on Instagram @ArtisticAbandonNYC + Twitter @ArtAbanNYC

If interested in volunteering or know someone who'd like to support, please email us at ArtisticAbandonNYC@gmail.com

For all the salt in the sea,

Kate

story:
Loop Theatre is a mixed ability Physical Theatre company that has been making and performing work all around Glasgow since 2012.

Our aim is to open the Arts to those with learning difficulties, to be more inclusive by providing accessibility and assistance so they can participate in theatre work, creating a more diverse artistic community.

This year we have had the pleasure of working with the Gallery of Modern Art for their Alasdair Gray Exhibition “Up a Snake Down a Ladder”, commissioned work for the Riverside Museum, Peter Vardy, Street Theatre Collaborations with Conflux at this year's Surge Festival and appearing on STV Glasgow's Riverside Show.

Loop relies on the dedication and skills of its professional performers, volunteers and enthusiastic participants. We are fundraising to help facilitate this year’s production Pantoland 2: The Revenge of the Dastardly Devious Duke of Dalmarnock. All donations go directly to the costs of putting on a production; the costumes, props and extra staging needs for our participants as well as providing expenses and support to our fantastic volunteers who make this possible. If we’re in the excellent position of exceeding our target then all extra money will be used for future productions.

PANTOLAND 2: THE REVENGE OF THE DASTARDLY DEVIOUS DUKE OF DALMARNOCK .

We return this year to the Riverside Museums Auld Street for PantoLand 2: The Revenge of the Dastardly Devious Duke of Dalmarnock’s Revenge! It’s that time of year again in PantoLand as the snowflakes start to fall and its residents prepare for its most magical time. However, something wicked this way comes, as The Dastardly Devious Duke of Dalmarnock prowls the cobbled streets with his wily right hand man . Can the Queen protect the Kingdom? Or will she be distracted by her own beauty… again. Will the fairy godmother find what she wants? And will she give them a fair price? And of course, will Dave the Devious Dastardly Duke of Dalmarnock be able to run amok or will he and his mischievous man servant be thwarted.

Last year we had an amazing time in PantoLand and many of you did too. Please help keep this fantastic world alive for another year and allow us to make another weird and wonderful show for you.


Also for our any curious contributers there will be free give aways and lots of other fun stuffbcoming your way if you keep updated! 

Find out more about us at our website.

story:
What is Theatrum Orbis Terrarum?

Theatre 3, the physical theatre ensemble that created MixTape, has a surprise in store for you. The next show we are bringing to the ETCETERA late-night series at Live Theatre Workshop is called Theatrum Orbis Terrarum. It’s all about our community, and sharing stories, music, and beer!

In order to bring our community together over a few drinks, we need to procure the proper licenses and insurance. By contributing to this Indiegogo campaign, you will help us to purchase the necessary liability insurance to make this event possible.

Theatre 3 specializes in ensemble-created performances.The artists of Theatre 3 bring a passion for character, love for the physical, and spirit of exploration and discovery to all of their work. The ensemble’s mission is to embrace joy and the human experience to create original, imaginative works that serve and engage the community through collaboration and the expansion of the possibilities of performance.

That’s exactly what Theatrum Orbis Terrarum is designed to do!

 

What We Need & What You Get

In short:

  • We need to raise $600 to be able to fund 4 original episodes of Theatrum Orbis Terrarum over 4 weekends.
  • The members of Theatrum Orbis Terrarum--Iznik, Swerf, and Alulu Ortelius--have agreed to reward your contributions with gifts of their many and various skills: paper folding, musical playing, food cooking, and the lifting of heavy objects.
  • All the money we raise will go towards our expenses for this project.

 

The Impact

Tucson has many different communities and many exciting people. Our goal is to bring them all together to tell stories, sing songs, dance dances, and imbibe--TOGETHER. And Theatrum Oribs Terrarum is just the thing to do it.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The smallest amount will really help! But if you don’t have extra cash, you can still contribute:

  • Help us spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Indiegogo.
  • Tell your friends about the show. Tell your enemies about the show. (Maybe if you drink a beer together you won’t be enemies anymore.)
  • Come see the show--four original episodes!
  • Come see the show and drink a beer.
  • Come see the show and drink a beer and bring your friends!

 

Thank you!

 

Special thanks to Dylan Page, videographer! Special thanks to Paige Tamarkin, Theatre 3 Production Assistant!

story:
My name is Spencer Miller and I am a founding member of Unsolicited Artists Theatre Troupe, a small new theatre troupe from Memphis TN. Our troupe of actors has been given the opportunity to bring our new show “Landfall” to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and we are looking for support. 
         
      Let me tell you a little bit about our theatre troupe: We are a small group of actors that is focused on developing new works from young talent around our city. Our past two shows that we have toured to festivals have involved not only students and graduates from The University of Memphis’ Department of Theatre and Dance, but also students from different high schools in the city. All of our productions are new works that have been cultivated from the nurturing city we are from and to show the stories and storytellers of our community to the rest of the world. Also, we are very committed to our craft and always ready to go the extra mile with every bit of support that we are given. 
        
      Next let me tell you about our new show “Landfall”: It is a modern-age fairy-tale about the North Star being tricked out of the sky and stumbling into a family’s life changing them forever. With the use of mask acting coupled with beautiful movement and song we weave a heart-warming story about love, friendship, and how the world needs to work together to survive. This family friendly play uses young actors as well seasoned college graduates to bring a story to life while helping our troupe to learn and grow with every performance. 

       You can be a part of making this dream of ours to perform in one of the most prestigious festivals in the world happen. We are already working hard to try to raise the funds to take us to the festival but we are in still need of support. Our fundraising goal is fifteen thousand dollars and we are working as hard as we can to make that goal happen.  Every donation matters. 
Thank you for your time,
Spencer Glenn Miller
And 
Unsolicited Artists Theatre Troupe
Spencermllr@aol.com

story:
Growing Up Moni what the?

Growing up Moni is a comedic semi-autobiographical one-woman show written by Monica Mustelier. 

 

I love this! What's it about?

Growing Up Moni is a multimedia show with a collection of stories about growing up as a first generation Canadian where most things get lost in translation. 

 

Is it like Stars Wars? 

Yes.

 

Can you say something highfalutin and academicals about it?

Growing Up Moni is an inappropriate socially and racially charged piece that questions our morals and what is funny. Is that a watermelon on stage?  

 

Can I see it?

YES YOU CAN! The Vancouver Fringe Festival at the Havana Theater, Sept. 6-14 2013 and in Toronto (dates TBA).

 

What we need:

Green backs, dollas, bones, coin, scratch, booty, C-notes, dinero and your laundry money.

 

We need to raise $5500 by March 1st for artist and festival fees, costumes, props, travel and expenses for cast and crew. Your donation, large and small, will help us light the lights bringing our show to life.

 

What we have: 

Blood, sweat and tears.

A gorgeous and talented crew of highly creative and funny people: award winning set designer/carpenter, dramaturge, DOP, editor and producer all donating their time and energy.

 

We've got some beauty gifts for you.

"You"- What really? What are they?!!!

~Tickets to the show!! Any donation of $25 or more gets you a ticket to see Growing Up Moni either in Vancouver or Toronto.

~You become a producer and executive producer of the show. And you can prove it because your name is on the playbill. WOW!

~Bottles of wine

~DVD’s with a selected collection of award winning short films and favrites written by      Monica Mustelier

~CD’s of music that’s inspired by the show.

~Our biggest and warmest thank-you’s on our Facebook page

www.facebook.com/FunnyGalProductions and twitter. 

~Personally signed show propaganda and Nadia Burkoff headshots

~photo shoot session with talented Toronto photographer Joanna Haughton

 

Other ways you can help:

 Tell the WORLD! We'd love it if you…

- Liked us on FB http://www.facebook.com/FunnyGalProductions

- Posted about our IndieGogo campaign www.indiegogo.com/Growing-Up-Moni

- Spread the word the old fashioned way: email, phone and in person with your friends and family

 

Thank you a billion times for your support! You are the wind beneath our wings...

story:
A little about the Company…

Moraporvida Contemporary Dance is a multicultural, repertory dance company that is from the Rocky Mountain region of Denver Colorado.

The Company was formed by Artistic Director Jacob Mora in 2002. Jacob quickly began gaining recognition for the company with his powerful and unique choreography.  The company prides itself on the fusion of many dance forms and ideas exploring, dissecting and exposing social, emotional and cultural constructs.

 “Por Vida” is Spanish meaning “For Life” and acts as a personal statement and declaration that we are the people we are by nature and not choice.  Moraporvida is a testament for the life we have been given and for the courage to fight for your hearts desires.  When you feel the only choice is to do what is in your heart, you do it for life.

A bit more about the project The Last Click...

The Last Click is the newest work for the Moraporvida Contemporary Dance Company. Choreographed by Jacob Mora, the company brings a new group of company members to a physical and emotional piece of work.  Using a blend of old radio shows, progressive sounds and electronic songs the score alone triggers intrigue, nostalgia and contemplation. With themes dealing in regret, hope and desire, the Last Click premieres Nov 7, and 8 at the Performing Arts Complex at PCS.

What we need, and what we are sharing...

We are raising funds to cover the costs of….

  • Theatre Cost
  • Lighting Design
  • Insurance
  • Dancer Stipends
  • Marketing
  • Costumes
  • Photography/Videography

We've created a range of great rewards to thank you for your support. Check them out on the right of the page. All contributions are tax deductible!

How you can help us on this journey?

•  Support us with a gift of any amount

•  Let the world know we’re coming for them! Share our campaign and show with your friends and family through social media, email and word of mouth.

•  Stay connected – follow us in social media and sign up for notifications on classes and performances.

Thank you for your support!

story:
wha gwaan: a brief history of pomme

pomme is french for apple is a play that is written, performed and produced by us - liza paul and bahia watson. and it’s not about apples - it’s about pum.

pum (n): short for pum pum. west indian for a woman’s private parts.

after meeting at a storytelling residency in 2010, we started writing together and developed pomme is french for apple, and have been performing it ever since. we’ve played festivals across canada, like femfest, the just-for-laughs produced JFL42, the winter at the young festival and the toronto fringe (best of fringe, patrons’ pick, critics’ pick). we’ve even received a standing ovation at the legendary nuyorican poets’ cafe in new york city.

and now we’ve been invited to (drumroll, please)... the edinburgh festival fringe!!! it’s the biggest arts festival in the entire world! it’s almost a month long! thousands of shows and thousands of performers - including us. amaaaaazing! then we realized how much is costs... NUFF. which is a lot. which is why we need your help to go to edinburgh and represent #pumlife.


ummmmm... what is #pumlife?

pomme is french for apple is a fresh, funny, irreverent and distinctly west indian look at womanhood in all its glory - its perils, its pleasures and all kinda madness in between. comprised of a series of fast-paced vignettes and original songs, we play an international cast of outrageous characters - even pums have speaking roles. all to celebrate ourselves, laugh at ourselves, share ourselves, as caribbean women, as full, dynamic women, as human beings - this is all #pumlife. 


gotta give it up to get some

so far we've raised almost $30K - not bad, right? but this festival is crazy expensive: although it's prestigious, it's not what we'd call a lucrative opportunity, since they don't pay for anything, and all the prices are in great british pounds.  we need $20K more to make it happen.

when you give to us, you get not only the deep satisfaction that comes with doing good deeds and supporting artists who have worked like donkeys for years, you also get dope stuff. you could be featured on our gratitude wall, obtain the secret recipe to uncle bunny's famous rum punch (an ancient jamaican family secret), tickets to pomme's fourth birthday party (we can't believe it's been nearly four years already!), orrrr get the chance to have us mix you cocktails and hang out with us. we're lots of fun. you'll see. 

since you have to use paypal for a fixed campaign and we're not so into that, we're going to go with flexible. if we don't reach our goal, we will get to keep whatever we've raised, but indiegogo will keep a higher percentage of whatever we've collected by the time the campaign closes than they would if we hit the mark. you'd still get your perks, though, which is awesome because you deserve them, but it would be kind of sad for us, cuz that $20K goal is the truth - it's what we need to make the whole thing go. 


discovery: people dem love pum

“funny and liberating... pomme belongs to that bracing wave of candid, liberating and gleefully gross female humour unleashed by the likes of 30 Rock, Girls and Bridesmaids” - Globe and Mail

“hilarious and fearless” **** - NOW Magazine

“a real gem... an honest, intelligent and wildly funny play” ***** - Theatromania

these are some of the lovely things people have said about pomme. amazing, right? and it’s all even more amazing because our show is about pums and pums don't get much fair representation in the media these days. they're either being used to sell beer, or being waxed to within an inch of their lives, or they're being abused in yet another weird criminal investigation series where the women are disproportionately the victims of a plethora of weird sex crimes, or they're alluded to as holes for men to put their parts into without any consideration for the human beings they belong to. ew. our pums have way more interesting stories than that to tell. and that's what we've been doing with this show. 

we've written and produced and performed our show to critical acclaim for years with no funding from any outside sources. we've done it for the love and for the audiences who come back and bring their friends and love the show and ask us to keep bringing it back. and now we have this huge opportunity to make our mark on the international stage - and we need help to make it happen.  


join the pum revolution

we are doing our best to be the change we want to see in the world. women are funny, complex, excellent creatures. but it's a sad truth that women, despite making up over half the world's population, are woefully under and misrepresented in the media today. our true voices are not being heard - it is overwhelmingly men who are at the helm of theatre companies and media conglomerates and film studios and they are the ones making the decisions about the way we appear to the world at large. we're not so into that. we love all the strong women who have come before us and made it possible for us to stand onstage dressed up like giant pums and talk about the things that matter to us (all in good humour, of course - pums are too funny not to catch jokes) and we want to follow in their footsteps and honour the fact that we stand on their shoulders and make room for all the beautiful brown and red and yellow and black and every colour of girls who have stories of their own to share. life is way more interesting than the version we're being sold. we want to remind people that women are smart, funny, creatures, too. and we want to make people laugh. life is too absurd not to bust a gut about it. 


the struggle is (too) real

arts funding is not an easy thing to come by. we've done really well with the help of our pommunity, and we believe that we can meet our goal with the help of people like you who believe in the power of the arts for social change and who are ready for women of colour to have a voice about their bodies, their lives and their experiences on an international stage.  

$50K is a lot of money, but we think we can get there. people tell us after almost every show how much it meant to them, how much they laughed, how much they felt like we'd taken the story of their lives and put it onstage for them to see it reflected back at them. we took a chance when we signed up for the festival without the funding to get us there in place, and we've been hustling hard to get to where we need to be before we go. they say that fortune favours the bold. hopefully fortune sees this venture as bold and not plain foolish. otherwise, it’ll be a long, hungry month. 


#tightlikemypum

if money's tight for you right now but you still want to help, tell all your friends about these two gyals who are trying to get their pomme across the ocean. facebook, twitter, our website - share share share! word of mouth and good reviews are what got us this far. yours can help us keep going. 

thanks so much for taking the time. we appreciate it. nuff.

love love love from the bottom of our pums

bahia + liza
story_txt:
wha gwaan: a brief history of pomme


pomme is french for apple is a play that is written, performed and produced by us - liza paul
and bahia watson. and it’s not about apples - it’s about pum. 
pum (n): short for pum
pum. west indian for a woman’s private parts. 
after meeting at a storytelling residency in
2010, we started writing together and developed pomme is french for apple, and have been performing it ever since. we’ve played festivals
across canada, like femfest, the just-for-laughs produced JFL42, the winter at the
young festival and the toronto fringe (best of fringe, patrons’ pick, critics’
pick). we’ve even received a standing ovation at the legendary nuyorican poets’
cafe in new york city. 
and now we’ve been invited
to (drumroll, please)... the edinburgh festival fringe!!! it’s the biggest arts
festival in the entire world! it’s almost a month long! thousands of shows and
thousands of performers - including us. amaaaaazing! then we realized how much
is costs... NUFF. which is a lot. which is why we need your help to go to edinburgh and
represent #pumlife.

story:
Short Summary

An Israeli Orthodox woman living in Gush Etzion and a Hamas woman living in Gaza and each of them has a 16 year old daughter.  One motzei Shabbat there is a suicide bombing and the Israeli daughter is killed.  The Hamas daughter is the suicide bomber.  Both mothers are broken, each in a different way.  It is the story of how each of these separate worlds collide, as the two mothers ultimately come together, in a shattering climax.

Stephanie Liss is a multi award winning television writer and playwright.  Among her movies for television , 'Second Serve - the Renee Richards Story,' starring Vanessa Redgrave, and for which Redgrave was nominated for an Emmy, the Emmy nominated,'David  - the David Rothenberg Story,' for which Stephanie was nominated for a writers Guild Award, and "Hidden In Silence,' a Holocaust movie for Lifetime, for which Stephanie won the writers Guild Award, and the Berlin Film Festival for outstanding television writing.

Equally known as an acclaimed playwright, Stephanie's plays have been produced at theaters such as The MET in Los Angeles, the Jewish Arts Festival at San Diego Rep and has had readings at the highly esteemed 92nd St. Y in New York.  

In addition to her writing, Stephanie is known as an outspoken proponent and advocate for Israel, and issues regarding Jews today.  Her work reflects the deep love she feels for Israel and interviews wither have appeared in such publications as Los Angeles Times, Written By Magazine, Jewish Journal, Chicago Tribune and she has appeared on such news outlets as CNN.

Genesis Theatrical Productions is a Chicago based theater company whose mission is to empower and educate members of society through dynamic new theatrical works that emphasize social justice and communal responsibility.  The theater also works to emphasize the role of women in theater as actress, playwright, director or designer.  Genesis was recently awarded a 2015 50/50 Applause Award by the International Centre for Women Playwrights for its work in developing and producing works by women playwrights.

What We Need & What You Get

We hope to raise $30,000 to help defray the costs of this important and powerful  theatrical work.  We are offering wonderful perks to those who can help us.

Our Budget breaks down as follows:

Salaries-Artistic, Technical, Front of House- 51% - This includes 4 actors, a director, designers (Set, Lighting, Costume, Props), the playwright and royalties, stage manager, house manager, technical director, light and sound board oeprators.

Rental Costs- 31% for both rehearsal and performance space

Materials - 5% including set, costume and prop materials

Publicity - 6% includes publicist, photographer, poster/flyer/postcard design and printing, paid ads.

Other - 7% - including box office services, videotaping, script copying, program printing, insurance and miscellaneous

    The Impact

    During this time and during the aftermath of the most recent outbreak of hostilities  it is vital that this play be presented to change hearts and minds about Israel and the challenges it faces from the terrorists of Hamas.

      Risks & Challenges

      The initial run of the show was boycotted by a number of artists because it was seen as too pro-Israel.  Despite this attitude, the play was presented resulting in powerful and life changing results for many members of the audience.

story:
THE THEATRICAL EXPERIENCE

Sex. Violence. Media. Facebook. What is our modern-day revolution? Heiner Müller wrote Hamletmachine in Germany in 1977 but the question is still pertinent today.  

Müller's play already takes Shakespeare's Hamlet  and rips it to shreds; this April, we will make it a fully interactive experience in search of answers to questions like:

  • What does it mean to stage a revolution today, and what do we have to fight against?
  • What constitutes revolt in the age of Facebook?
  • How does the ever-changing nature of gender politics affect this discussion and what is the role of the media in the conversation?

Performances will take place April 11th-13th at Columbia's Schapiro Studio.  Admission will be free.


WHAT WE NEED

Fortunately, we are able to offer the Hamletmachine experience free of charge, unfortunately it is not free to us.  Although the play can be mounted fairly inexpensively, we do need $500 to accomplish the following:

  1. Acquiring and assembling all of the physical pieces needed to shape the walk-through installation space. 
  2. Costuming the cast.
  3. Marketing the work.
  4. Paying our people - we have an outrageously talented team of artistic professionals who, frankly, are worth their weight in gold.  

If you find the questions posed as the discussion proposed by Hamletmachine to be relevant and important, this is your opportunity to support the conversation! You'll be rewarded with an unbeatable set of perks, including the chance to pick the director's brain.  And baked goods (if you're less interested in brain-pickings, do it for the baked goods).


THE TEAM

If the vision didn't convince you, maybe our team will:

Dara Malina - Director
Emily Comisar & Meghan Dixon - Producers
Katharina Cromme - Dramaturg
Kate Dial - Stage Manager
Christopher Metzger - Costume Designer
Sara Sciabbarrasi - Set Designer
Nolan Lem - Sound Designer
Mike McGee - Lighting Designer
Christopher Petrinovic - Technical Director
Matthew Reber - Projections/Media Designer

Hamletmachine will be performed by:
Keelie Sheridan
Marty Keiser*
Kenard Jackson
Josette Canilao
Ava Kelly 

*Appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

story:
Open Jar Institute in NYC

For I know the plans I have for you,” declares the Lord, “plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future. (Jeremiah 29:11)

     I think Erma Bombeck said it best: "When I stand before God at the end of my life, I would hope that I would not have a single bit of talent left and could say, 'I used everything you gave me.'" And that is what I want to accomplish...

      For those of you who don't know me, my name is Wesley Barnes and I am a Junior at Concordia University Irvine. At CUI I am majoring in Theatre with minors in Communication Studies and Musical Theatre. It is my dream to work professionally as a performing artist and mentor youth in all aspects of the arts. Ultimately I would love to be able to open my own performing arts center for youth, giving them the opportunity to experience the arts, because if I didn't I don't know where I would be today. 

      In late February I was a representative for my school at the American College Theatre Festival. While at this festival I decided to audition for an experience called The Open Jar Institute. When I auditioned for this program i did it just for the experience of the audition and I thought that it would be fun. Two weeks later I was informed that I was accepted to the summer program!

    I know you may be wondering: "What is Open Jar?"

The Open jar institute is a summer intensive that chooses 60 College students (nation wide) to spend a week in NYC taking Master Classes and Workshops with some of Broadways Working professionals (performers, directors, casting directors, Agents etc...). When you are not taking classes or workshops during the day, at night you go and see the Broadway shows with the artist you were working with earlier that day! 

This is the opportunity of a lifetime. It isn't every day that you get an opportunity like this. This means so much to me because of the fact that there aren't many opportunities out there quite like this one. The fact that I was chosen for one of these slots is amazing! I am all about learning all that I can because I know that there is always room to grow, and that's exactly what this will help me do. This experience would be so beneficial for me, but the only way it can happen is with your support!

The details...

The cost for me to attend this summer intensive is $2,500 and this amount does not include transportation from Los Angeles to NYC and back! The $500 down payment has already been paid. The tuition money goes to holding my place for the intensive, housing, food, and material fees for the intensive. 

If the goal is not reached, I will still accept your generous donations so that I can use it for the same reason, except I will try to take out a loan to pay for the rest of the cost, all though I would love it if I didn't have to resort to that! So please support and donate!!!

The Impact you can have!

You can have such an impact on my life in so many ways by making a donation to this experience. By donating money:

  • You get to help a young man keep making strides to reach the many goals that he has for his life.
  • You will be helping me get to a place where I will be able to work with and learn from the professionals who work in the field that I want to go into. 
  • I will get to make relationships with people who could get me potential work in the near or distant future.
  • You are helping to give me the opportunity to learn more about my craft so that I can give back to others. 
  • This event will help me to become a better performer and individual. 
  • You will make a difference in my life because without you this will not be possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that not everyone is in the position to donate at the moment, but there are still ways that you can help!

  • When you are in the position to give, please do so! All donations are appreciated not matter or big or small! You will be blessed in return!
  • Spread the word! This event means a lot to me and can really make a difference. So please share this page with your friends, family, relatives, co-workers, etc. 
  • Post to your Facebook, twitter, blogs, e-mails and things of that nature. There is also a share function on this page to take advantage of! 
  • Thank you and God Bless!

Post to your Facebook, twitter, blogs, e-mails and things of that nature. There is also a share function on this page to take advantage of! 
Thank you and God Bless!

story:
The louderARTS Project is an arts collective committed to developing constructive and challenging spaces for artists to create, critique, present, and teach poetry. Now in our sixteenth year, we stay committed to creating a diverse literary and artistic environment for both artists and audience alike.

The poetry slam has been a core format of ours since 1998, and we're especially excited about the team that will be representing us at the National Poetry Slam in Oakland this August: Brendan Wolff, Chanel Dupree, Thomas Fucaloro, and Gabriel Ramirez.

NPS 2014: OAKLAND, CA

Taking place from August 5th to 9th, the National Poetry Slam is a magical annual gathering of hundreds of poets from all over the U.S. and Canada, a diverse mix of voices rarely seen at any other national literary festival.

louderARTS has a proud history of representing NYC at NPS since 1998, but we need our community's help to get our wonderfully diverse team of poets all the way to Oakland!

WHAT WE NEED

Getting to Oakland entails NPS registration, travel, and housing for five people (the team + one organizer) for six days. Estimating a cost of $1250 per person, we will need to raise around $5000 to make the magic happen.

WHO WE ARE

louderARTS is a 100% volunteer organization. Ours is a labor of love and service, firmly anchored in our belief in the power of poetry, art and language to shift the conversations in culture. The generosity of our features, poets, artists, sponsors, and community of audience members is what has allowed us to do the work that we do.

All the funds we raise go towards our work and our programs. Our gain is the deep satisfaction derived from the work that we do.

Over the course of the campaign, we'll get to know each of the poets on the team individually, hoping to further inspire you to help us get them to Oakland!
story_txt:
The louderARTS Project is an arts collective committed to developing constructive and challenging spaces for artists to create, critique, present, and teach poetry. Now in our sixteenth year, we stay committed to creating a diverse literary and artistic environment for both artists and audience alike.
The poetry slam has been a core format of ours since 1998, and we're especially excited about the team that will be representing us at the National Poetry Slam in Oakland this August: Brendan Wolff, Chanel Dupree, Thomas Fucaloro, and Gabriel Ramirez.
NPS 2014: OAKLAND, CA

story:
Basically what's happening is:

I've been living in Austin and producing theatre here for the last 7 years. My company does darkly comedic plays about homicidal domiciles and reality TV shows where people compete to have the powers of Jesus.

I just got word that I've been granted a partial scholarship for this writers' colony in Vermont (http://www.vermontstudiocenter.org/). It's the largest writers' residency program in the States and a huge, awesome opportunity for which thousands of people compete annually and 144 are accepted. A writers' colony is a place where emerging writers can go to focus on their writing and not have to worry about scribbling 14 pages of dialog on a smoke break during a lunch shift at TGIFriday's. Solely focusing on playwrighting will be my job for a month, and that's invaluable. Having a residency like this on a resume is huge for a young playwright because it gives potential producers and investors proof that you're professional and serious about what you're doing. I basically get a chance to do what kids in MFA programs do and, as a college dropout, this is rad.

This comes at a cost, though. I can cover the other expenses like travel, rent for my apartment in February, Sasquatch repellent, and getting a sensible coat but I need help covering the remaining portion of tuition which is $1,800. I cannot do this without your support.

What I'll be doing in Vermont:


Besides resisting the urge to spend a month just making snow angels (a luxury the 10-month summer in Texas doesn't afford), I'll be working on revisions of two of my plays (Sometimes Callie and Jonas Die and Holier Than Thou) as well as a new play that bitch-slaps the gay political art of the 80s and 90s. Also maybe something with dinosaurs in it.


What's in it for you:

I'll write you a play. Seriously. I'm basically taking from donors ideas of things that they'd love to see in a show and tailor-making a hodgepodge pastiche of crazy that will, despite logic, have a coherent through-line. ANYTHING you've ever wanted to see on stage can happen in this piece, and everyone who donates will receive an invite to the staged reading/ boozefest we'll host next year in Austin (that will also be recorded for your out-of-town viewing pleasure.) This will be a good warm-up for me and a chance for you to basically commission whatever the hell you want to see. This is not one of the several projects I'll be working on at the center.

story:
Northwestern University's Jewish Theatre Ensemble is proud to present a brilliant piece of theatre by David Mamet: ROMANCE.

This fast-paced farce delves into politics, religion, relationships, and so much more, all the while doing so with over-the-top intellectual hilarity.

We need YOUR help in order to make this show a success. This show is entirely student-produced which means we must raise all of our own funds. All of the money raised will go to expenses such as lights, sound, publicity, costumes, props, etc.


Thank you so much for your time and support! We are sincerely grateful.

We need YOUR help in order to make this show a success. This show is entirely student-produced which means we must raise all of our own funds. All of the money raised will go to expenses such as lights, sound, publicity, costumes, props, etc.Thank you so much for your time and support! We are sincerely grateful.

story:
Gentle Spirit is a 40 minute long narrative style Contemporary Dance film based on the Novella “A Gentle Creature” (Russian: ÐšÑ€Ð¾Ñ‚ÐºÐ°Ñ, Krotkaya) by Fyodor Dostoyevsky. We're making a film that uses choreography and emotion to drive the narrative rather than dialogue.

We have finished the editing and are now up to the final stages of post production which is the music and sound mix, colour correction and grading and digital cinema print production. As the film was shot in a professional format, full High Definition, it is going to require some post production work to make sure we get the best out of the format. It also now runs 40 minutes long which has increased a few costs in post production.

We've begged, borrowed, bartered, maxed out the credit cards and worked for free to get the film this far but now it requires some specialist skills to finish it to the highest standard.

What the money will be used for

Colour correction and grading. Sound mix. Commissioned original music and music licensing.

We're fortunate to now have an award winning sound designer on board and a great colourist who will bring out the best of the film in these final stages of production.

We're hoping to have it finished in two months ready for submission to festivals Worldwide such as Cinedans Amsterdam, Dance Camera West, The Melbourne International film festival, The Atlanta film festival as well as the St Kilda film festival. There's some key Dance Film Festivals we'd like to get it shown in as well as traditional film festivals either in the short film catagories or experimental (although we think it can stand proud with other more "standard" narrative films).

Production blog: www.gentlespirit.com.au

Thanks for reading this far and we hope you'll join us to finish the film and we also hope to see you at a festival soon.

 

The Directors
Vivienne Rogis and Damian Heffernan

Vivienne graduated from the Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts in 1994. She was a founding member, performer and rehearsal director for the Perth based, dance company Physical Architecture is Dancing from 1994 - 1997. From 1997-2011 Vivienne worked with Elizabeth Cameron Dalman and Mirramu Dance Company as performer, choreographer and Assistant Artistic Director. Vivienne was also involved in the development of youth dance programs at The Australian Choreographic Centre Hatchery from 1997-2011, continuing her work with the organisation through its transition to QL2 Dance. She was also Assistant to the Artistic Director for Quantum Leap, which is the performance company of QL2 Dance. Vivienne has created numerous independent stage works and began her work in dance on screen in 2003.

Damian is an filmmaker and multimedia producer with broad experience in all forms of media production. In addition to succesful theatre productions of A Midsummer night's dream and large scale outdoor theatrical events he has produced music videos, multimedia elements for live dance performances, training videos and various documentaries and drama films.

About the Novella

“A Gentle Creature” (Russian: ÐšÑ€Ð¾Ñ‚ÐºÐ°Ñ, Krotkaya), sometimes also translated as "Gentle Spirit" or “The Meek One”, is a short novel written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky in 1876. The piece comes with the subtitle of “A Fantastic Story”.

Despite Dostoyevsky’s statement that “every line and every word of the story” was clear to him, it took several years (seven to be exact) for it to assume its final form. A sudden jolt was needed to propel it to the “writing-down” stage. This shock was provided by the newspaper account in the first part of April, 1876, of the suicide of a poor seamstress, Maria Borisova, who threw herself out of a window, clutching an icon in her hands. Dostoyevsky’s reaction to this tragedy was a short comment in the October issue of The Diary of a Writer. Sparked by this suicide, the final version of the story germinated in an incredibly short time: Most of it was finished by November 19, 1876 and appeared in the November issue of The Diary.

story:
SO WHAT THE HECK IS PARTY IN THE USA?

DAVID MCGEE: I'm not sure.

JOSHUA WILLIAM GELB: Well, I'll tell you.

DM:If you must.

JWG: Awesome. So. This July, I'm going to be returning to the always awesome Incubator Arts Project (the former Ontological) with a new, totally trippy comedy by this brilliant writer to my left --

DM: I'm on your right, dude. Wait, no, you're on my right. Meaning I'm... on... WHERE AM I?

JWG: -- a trippy comedy about dropping acid, baking strudel, and saving the world from financial ruin. The play is called PARTY IN THE USA and it's based on some exceptionally trippy experiences I had while temping for Deutsche Bank in the fall of 2008.

DM: Fall of 2008, eh? I seem to remember something important happening then.

JWG: Something like, say, the complete collapse of the world economy?

DM: Oh, right, that. I was thinking of these really delicious pancakes I had.

JWG: ...

DM: THEY WERE REALLY DELICIOUS. FULL OF BLUEBERRIES AND HOPE.

JWG: Anyway, if you go to our absurdly bonkers website you can read all about how this guy (pointing to himself) dropped acid and broke into the Plaza Hotel the very week that Lehmann Brothers collapsed.

DM: What a weird synchronicity of events. Could be a great premise for a madcap theatrical romp. 

JWG: Like the drug-induced collapse of a guy's mental stability as a metaphor for the collapse of the American economy?

DM: Huh?

JWG: So. Taking the audience into the mind of a full-blown acid trip, PARTY IN THE USA is going to be this explosive theatrical sensory overload! Dancing! Video projections! Free beer!

DM: OW I just spilled Bud Light Lime in my left eye.

SO THEN...

DM: What were we talking about?

JWG: Bloody marys! (To the waitress) Can we get another round of bloody marys?

DM: No! The Indiegogo Campaign! 

JWG: Oh, right! The Indiegogo Campaign! We've roped together a fantastic team of actors, designers and other theater makers and are pretty much convinced that this is going to be just the most super-fun-crazy thing we've ever created. But we need your help! 

DM: Tell them about the Bud Light Lime. Don't tell them I spilled it in my left eye.

JWG: Yes, Bud Light Lime -- you know, the taste of 2008? -- Bud Light Lime has actually agreed to sponsor us! Which means there will be free beer for everyone when you come to see the show! 

DM: So we've got the beer covered!

JWG: Right! We've got the beer covered. There will be beer. Plenty of beer. But theater is expensive, after all (THANKS A LOT, OBAMA) and while the beer is as good as provided for by the fine people at Anheuser Busch, there is still a lot more to take into consideration. 

DM: Stipends for performers and our production team!

JWG: Rehearsal space.

DM: Which is stupidly expensive.

JWG: Transportation. Design costs. Insurance.

DM: Money to make those really cool coasters you've been talking about.

JWG: Because postcards have gotten sort of played out. 

DM: Plus you can use them as projectile weapons.

JWG: Lighting Rentals. 

DM: PYEW PYEW PYEW

JWG: Stop throwing coasters at me.

DM: Fine.

JWG: And dumplings. Remember how many dumplings you wrote into the script? That now we have to buy every single night?

DM: I know a great dumpling place.

JWG: I could use a dumpling right now.

DM: You are a dumpling right now.

JWG: YOU ARE.

UM...?

DM: Wait! No! The Indiegogo Campaign!

JWG: Right! Yes! The Indiegogo Campaign! -- So, we've got a fair amount of the budget already raised. 

DM: We do?

JWG: About half.

DM: Really?

JWG: Yes, half. Sort of. I mean, hypothetically. In reality, a donor has promised something of a match donation to us if we can raise 4,500 through crowdfunding.

DM: Oh. So when we say we have half of the budget raised, that's sort of wishful thinking. 

JWG: Right. 

DM: SORT OF LIKE THE WORLD ECONOMY AM I RIGHT?

JWG: ...

DM: ...

JWG: So [turning to face the computer screen] this is where YOU come in.

DM:  All you good people of the internet, with your philanthropic urges and tendencies, and deep, deep pocketbooks.

JWG: Looking for the right outlet through which to fulfill your most generous desires. 

DM: Well look no further.

JWG: No further, I say!

DM: Help make PARTY IN THE USA possible.

JWG: 20 bucks, 30 bucks...

DM: Whatever you can give.

JWG: 5 million bucks.

DM: A buck fifty.

JWG: ONE BILLION DOLLARS.

DM: A buck fifty one. A buck fifty two, even.

JWG: A lifetime supply of dumplings.

DM: Twelve Canadian dollars. Whatever it is, we'd love your help! So give what you can, and then, come July, get yourself to the Incubator to see the supremely trippy work you've supported.

JWG: And when you see the show you can drink all the Bud Light Lime you want!

DM: Exactly.

JWG: Where are those bloody marys?

DM: I DRANK THEM. I DRANK THEM UP.

JWG: ...

DM: ...

JWG: OK BYE.

story:
Who We Are

 

Jazz Choreography Enterprises, Inc., is a nonprofit, 501(c)(3) corporation.

 

Jazz Choreography Enterprises (JCE) is dedicated to showing New York audiences that the great American art of jazz dance is alive and kicking.  To that end we produce the New York Jazz Choreography Project, a celebration of jazz dance featuring original works of jazz in various styles by emerging and established choreographers.  Since 2007, the Artistic Directors Marian Hyun and Merete Muenter have presented more than 50 choreographers and 150 dancers from the U.S. , South Africa, Germany, and Japan. 

 

On April 27th and 28th, JCE will present the New York Jazz Choreography Project at Manhattan Movement & Arts Center (MMAC).  Through these performances, 14 choreographers will have a chance to show their work in front of live audiences, and our audiences will be able to see jazz dance in a variety of styles, created by young choreographers just starting their careers and veteran choreographers such as Luigi, the 88-year-old jazz legend.    

 

Why We Need Your Help

 

These productions are expensive!  This year we were forced to change our venue for the April performances—while we were fortunate to get the performance space at MMAC, it costs twice as much as the original venue.  With 14 choreographers, more than 50 dancers, and the many people who want to see their work, we need to rent enough space to accommodate everyone.  But we are committed to presenting an affordable, high quality performance of original jazz dance, and we can do it with your help.

 

Your contributions would go toward our venue, event insurance, music licenses, and the all-too-small stipends for our choreographers. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you can’t contribute financially, you can still help JCE by sharing this campaign with as many people as you can.  You can also “like” the Jazz Choreography Enterprises page on Facebook.

story:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

An Iconic Photograph...

Still Available!
A Very Special Offer From Tom Caravaglia
 
Tom Caravaglia, one of the most well-known and respected dance photographers in New York, has offered a special 12"x16" print of this 2007 photograph taken of Janis's work, Shun-Woa featuring Kun-Yang Lin. It will be signed by both Tom, Janis, and Kun-Yang. What a special offer!! This photograph, one of only three prints, is valued at $1000 and will go to the first person who donates $250 between now and the closing of this campaign on Thursday, October 17.


All other contributions are extremely welcome!

Only $330 needed to reach our goal.


Janis is "honored to be honored" by the 92Y Harkness Dance Center in NYC. 

Review and Interview Links!:

http://www.markkappeldance.com/newsnotes_dance_blog

http://www.dance-enthusiast.com/features/view/Dancing-Up-Close-to-Janis-Brenner-and-Her-Artistic-Throughlines-DanceUpCloseVideo-2013-10-09#.UlfpG1KoCyg.gmail

Your generous support will go DIRECTLY to the salaries of the exceptional company dancers and the fees of our acclaimed guest musicians! With guest artists coming into NY from Sweden and Philadelphia, along with local guest artists who have also worked with Janis and been mentored by her, as well as presenting a JB&D Premiere, putting together this unique concert season is quite complicated and of course, expensive.

Our 2 "One-of-a kind" Events at the 92Y Harkness Dance Center need your support!

"FRIDAYS at NOON", OCTOBER 11: Artistic Throughlines, Global Connections

Janis Brenner has often paid tribute to her acclaimed mentors and the artists who’ve inspired her. Now 92Y asks her to switch direction and present artists whom she has mentored from around the world. Janis met Helena Franzén in 1986 in Stockholm and encouraged her to choreograph. Helena, an acclaimed artist throughout her native Scandinavia, presents the U.S. premiere of her solo, "Trigger Point." Kun-Yang Lin met Janis in his native Taiwan in the late ‘80s and later danced in her company for eight years. Now based in Philadelphia, he shows his solo, "Moon Dance" performed by Jennifer Rose. Kyla Barkin and Aaron Selissen perform a duet from Barkin’s piece, "Reflexive." Janis met Kyla at UCLA in the early ‘90s and she and Selissen are long-time members of the  company. Lilja Ruriksdottir, the first Icelandic dancer to attend Juilliard (where she first worked with Janis in 2011) presents her dance "Wait", with Juilliard dancers John Harnage and Maggie Segale and an original percussion score by Juilliard grad Jan Stoneman. Janis herself contributes the premiere of "Where-How-Why Trilogy." The new dance consists of three solos, performed by exceptional company members Esme Boyce, Sumaya Jackson, and Janis, which explore questions of place, relevance and the reasons for continuing on an artistic path. For more information and to purchase tickets, go to: http://www.92y.org/Event/FAN-Janis-Brenner-Dancers. 

"DIG DANCE", OCTOBER 11-13: JB&D with a Special Guest each night

These performances feature the “meticulous artistry” (Deborah Jowitt, The Village Voice) of Janis Brenner and her full company. Come see Kyla Barkin! Esme Boyce! Sumaya Jackson! Christopher Ralph! Kendra Samson! Aaron Selissen! and Lilja Ruriksdottir!

Janis premieres "Where-How-Why Trilogy", a group of three solos set to music by David Lang, Joni Mitchell and the electronic music band Tosca. And she revives her 2011 work, "The Mind-Stuff Variations", a complex dance with a live commissioned score by in-demand composer Jerome Begin, inspired by moving spontaneously and simultaneously using words to describe that movement. As she and the company created the dance, Janis came across work by psychologist William James, written 100 years ago, about Mind-Stuff Theory and what she read fit perfectly with what she was trying to do in the studio—to be in the moment while also accessing thought, memory and sensation. The resulting dance is sometimes witty and often emotionally fraught. Friday’s performance will also include the excerpt from Kyla Barkin’s "Reflexive", Saturday night’s will include "Wait" by Lilja Ruriksdottir and Sunday matinee will include Helena Franzén’s "Trigger Point." For more information and to purchase tickets, go to: http://www.92y.org/Event/Janis-Brenner-Dancers. 

JANIS BRENNER is an award-winning dancer/choreographer/singer/teacher and is Artistic Director of Janis Brenner & Dancers in NYC. Known for her “meticulous artistry” (Deborah Jowitt, The Village Voice), she has toured in 33 countries and is recognized as a “singular performer” with a multifaceted artistic range. Honors/grants include: NY Dance & Performance Award (a"Bessie") for her performance in Meredith Monk’s The Politics of Quiet, Lester Horton Award for Choreography in L.A., NY Foundation for the Arts Fellowship, The Fund for US Artists at International Festivals, the U.S. State Department, Asian Cultural Council, The Trust for Mutual Understanding, UNESCO, US Embassies in Moscow, Jakarta and Dakar, and a commission for the interdisciplinary work, The Memory Project, from the Whitney Museum of American Art. Her work has been commissioned/restaged on more than 45 companies and colleges worldwide and she performed with Meredith Monk and Vocal Ensemble from 1990 - 2005 (recording on ECM Records). Ms. Brenner was with the Murray Louis Dance Company from 1977-84, working with Rudolf Nureyev, Placido Domingo, Dave Brubeck Quartet, Joseph Papp, Bat Sheva Dance Company in Israel, and Alwin Nikolais. Janis Brenner & Dancers has performed throughout the U.S., Asia, Russia and Europe since 1989 and has been presented by leading NY organizations. The company is known for the caliber of its dancers, its wide-ranging national and international guest residencies as well as its “emotionally authentic” and musically diverse work. Brenner has been on faculty at The Juilliard School since 2009. www.janisbrenner.com

What We Need & What You Will Get

We need to raise $3,500 by October 13. These specific funds will go directly to pay the company dancers and guest musicians.

  • Choose a donation level and Look to the Right for our unique perks. We're excited to offer name listings on our Facebook page and website and in the 92Y program! Janis and Theo Bleckmann's acclaimed Mars Cantata CD signed by the artists! Complimentary tickets to the performances! Free Voice Lessons from Janis! Two Tickets to a taping of the Rachael Rae Show!

The Impact

"Profoundly moving..." Eva Yaa Asantewaa, Infinite Body 2011

Our interdisciplinary dance company has been in existence for more than 25 years. We have had the honor and opportunity to travel all over the world and to make an impact in countries as diverse as Indonesia, Russia/Siberia, Taiwan, Sweden, and throughout the US, often serving as Cultural Ambassadors. In NY, we have presented some of the most unique, interdisciplinary and talked-about concert seasons in the past decade. Read many of our reviews at: http://www.janisbrenner.com/#!articles   

This 92Y season will be yet another innovative event bringing together even more of our extended family of dance artists from diverse backgrounds, countries and ages; all having worked with Janis to extend their own visions.

Other Ways You Can Help

Friends, If you just can’t contribute, you can still help us:

  • Get the word out about our NY season by posting to your own facebook page or send our indiegogo campaign to your own email list of friends and dance/music/art supporters.
  • We Remind you to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Top photo credit of Janis, Kyla and Esme: Julie Lemberger

Second & Third photo credits of Janis, Esme and Luke Murphy : Tom Caravaglia
story_txt:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------An Iconic Photograph...

Still Available!A Very Special Offer From Tom Caravaglia Tom Caravaglia, one of the most well-known and respected dance photographers in New York, has offered a special 12"x16" print of this 2007 photograph taken of Janis's work, Shun-Woa featuring Kun-Yang Lin. It will be signed by both Tom, Janis, and Kun-Yang. What a special offer!! This photograph, one of only three prints, is valued at $1000 and will go to the first person who donates $250 between now and the closing of this campaign on Thursday, October 17.
All other contributions are extremely welcome! 
Only $330 needed to reach our goal.
Janis is "honored to be honored" by the 92Y Harkness Dance Center in NYC.

story:
About us

Due to all of the life experiences I have had, I had the revolutionary idea to tie dance in with community service.  Therefore, I am creating the rePUBLIC of daNCe so that students can put their mark on the world and experience diversity to enhance one's mind and spirit.  Through a variety of experiences, I have learned that "...you shouldn't go through life with a catcher’s mitt on both hands. You need to be able to throw something back."  ~Maya Angelou. 

The rePUBLIC of daNCe believes in creating access to a comprehensive dance education that provides vital skills to prepare young dancers for collegiate and/or professional careers in dance while simultaneously giving back to the community.

An Opportunity for Reinvention

The rePUBLIC of daNCe is looking for the Opportunity to Reinvent dance studio education, but needs some assistance to become an official 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization so we can start our Brick-and-Mortar Campaign to build us a home, making this dream a reality.

What We Need

Federal Nonprofit Filing Fee: $850

Printing: ~$23.58

Faxing: ~$26.06

Lawyer Fee: $100

Grand Total: $999.64

We have already been approved as a nonprofit organization within the state of North Carolina!! The Federal approval is the last step to us becoming a recognized nonprofit organization.

Feel free to check us out on FB, or at republicofdance.org

The Impact

This is the biggest obstacle we are facing right now.

Once we reach our goal, and find a home, the rePUBLIC of daNCe promises to always provide an affordable, high quality, good value, inspiring and life-changing dance education. We believe that by doing this, we can give the gift of hope; we can empower both ourselves and others to achieve both our own dreams and theirs; and we can create a world that values hard work, discipline, gratitude, perseverance and creativity.

We realize that not everyone is able to contribute, but we could still use your help! Please like us on Facebook, share us with your friends and family, follow us on LinkedIn and visit our webpage. The more people who can learn about the rePUBLIC of daNCe, the better!

story:
YOU Can Help Us Keep the Show Going! 

"Mime stands out from other forms of entertainment because of the imagination and creativity required to perform it.... Richmond, who is charming as well as handsome, has had a remarkable career.... A true legend [at the age of 85], Richmond Shepard’s show is a must-see if you appreciate the world of mime." --Constance Radut, TheaterScene.net

We got great reviews, and cheers from enchanted audiences, but after only four weeks our remarkable category-defying show, Richmond Shepard's "You Want to Be a What?!? A Memoir in Mime" closed at the end of September. 

Partly because of an inconvenient time slot (Tuesdays at 9:15pm), and partly because mime is misunderstood (some friends expected to see us trapped in imaginary boxes!!), we were not able to break even for most performances. 

But those who made it out loved the show and we have gotten many requests to do encore performances.

So we are working with our amazingly supportive friends at Don't Tell Mama to schedule more shows at convenient times -- but we need your help!!

Why Mime Matters

Mime -- the technique of physically expressing objects, character, emotion, and storyline -- is most familiar these days in improv comedy, which uses no props.

Its techniques of strongly emotive facial and bodily expression are used in many performance arts, from theater, to stage combat, to dance -- and even song! (Richmond coached the LA Civic Light Opera company for for many years to enhance their physical expression). 

A mime's bodily isolations may also be familiar to us through hip-hop, tribal bellydance, and other forms of theatrical dance.

But in its pure, strongest form, a mime creates whole worlds -- character, place, emotion, storyline, everything -- through evocative physical expression. 

Its techniques are difficult to learn and can take decades to master.

And Richmond Shepard is the master of this art form in America. 

Drawing on over six decades of experience -- having created America's first Mime Troupe back in 1951 (where Lily Tomlin got her start!) -- Richmond begins this show with some anecdotes from his impressive history, then illustrates the body articulation and illusions on which polished, professional mime must be based.

Through this introduction and the succeeding vignettes, which range from comedy to pathos to social commentary (accompanied by fellow mimes Marcus Watson and Carol Tandava Henning, with music and narration by Nick Wolfson), the audience begins to understand the depth, range, and theatrical possibilities that mime is capable of.

To quote Eva Heinemann of Hi! Drama:  "This charming look at Mime was perfect on the intimate stage and surroundings of Don’t Tell Mama. Who knows you might even appreciate Mime for the first time."

Check out our other reviews on Theater Pizzazz, Theater Scene, and Nite Life Exchange!

Producing a Show in NYC is Expensive!

Even though Don't Tell Mama is one of Manhattan's most prestigious cabarets, their rental agreement is very reasonable and their staff is top notch. So we want to stick with them for encore performances.

Based on the room charge, drink minimum, and miscellaneous expenses, we would need to raise $350 for each additional show.

Our goal is to produce up to four performances by the end of 2014 -- totaling $1400. 

Each time a milestone of $350 is reached, we will work with both the venue and YOU, our generous donors, to find the best new performance date(s) for everyone!

Your tax-deductible donation can go towards tickets to a performance, or if you can't attend, we offer many wonderful thank-you gifts, including:

  • A DVD of the September 2014 performance of "You Want to Be a What?!?"
  • Your choice of Richmond's instructional or performance DVDs.
  • Richmond's instructional books on mime and improvisation
  • Richmond's collection of stories, essays, and fables:  HYPHEN: A Spiritual Adventure Between Two Dates

Any remaining funds will help defray costs for the September run and go towards mounting additional performances.

Risks & Challenges

As is often the case in NYC's jam-packed entertainment scene, coordination and scheduling is a huge challenge. 

But as funds become available to produce additional shows, we will make every effort to find dates and times that can accommodate as many of you as we possibly can!!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are not able to donate, but still want to support this show and Richmond's marvelous work, please let us know! 

    • As always, SPREADING THE WORD helps the most. Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, or just go tell some friends!
    • And please use Indiegogo share tools for maximum effect.

    Many thanks for your support -- and we look forward to miming with you in the future!

    Photos by Tom Henning.

 Many thanks for your support -- and we look forward to miming with you in the future!Photos by Tom Henning.

story:
Short Summary

The WVMTF is going Off-Broadway this year!

Mission Statement

Invoking the spirit of one of the most creative areas in New York history, the West Village Musical Theatre Festival is a catalyst to regenerating what made the musical theater industry great: new works of art that owe their significance to storytelling and emotion.

Purpose

In a world where accountants make artistic decisions and money is often the only obstacle, the West Village Musical Theatre Festival seeks to celebrate artists and work that may not otherwise have a chance to come to fruition.  The WVMTF offers a chance for writers and composers to have a real hands-on professional production with minimal cost. 

Format

The 2012 WVMTF will run Wednesday, June 13th through Sunday, June 17th, showcasing four series of six shows each, for a total of 24 unique shows.  Each series will be sold as a separate event, and will contain six back-to-back shows that are fifteen minutes in length.  Series A and C will be “Shorts”, shows that are fifteen minutes from start to finish.  Series B and D will be “Snapshots”, or shows that are fifteen minutes of a larger work.

SHOWS

SERIES A - SHORTS
The Councilwoman
Gary Goldfarb: Master Escapist
The Bed
Choices
Face to Facebook
Angry Birds
 
SERIES B - SNAPSHOTS
Geeked and Loaded
Tambo
Honor and Family
Greenwich Village Love Story
 
SERIES C - WORKSHOPS
Visiting Day
Preschool! A Pint-Sized Musical
A Day in the Night
That's Just Super
Day at the White House
Best/Worst Day Ever
 
SERIES D - SNAPSHOTS
Modern Myth
Secondhand Shakespeare
Bielke
Mah Jongg the Musical
Cowboys Don't Sing

Check out the website (www.WVMTF.com) for info on series showtimes and more! 

What We Need & What You Get

All productions and festivals have expenses, ours is no different.

Because the WVMTF is going Off-Broadway this year, we're upgrading our equipment.  In order to provide the best for the best, we're looking to invest in wireless microphones.  These extra funds will also help cover events, insurance, technical staff and other important aspects of our successful production.

Please help us reach our goal! 

The Impact

The WVMTF is a place where creative artists can begin to put their work on its feet, develop an idea, network with other emerging professionals, and come to understand the process of producing a show in New York.

All donations made in support of specific show have REAL REWARDS for the teams!

  • Teams that sign up for our fiscal sponsorship program will have up to 90% of your donation regranted directly to the team.
  • For every $500 raised in support of a show, that team will receive a Village Voucher.
  • Each week the WVMTF will reward 4 hours of studio rehearsal space to the team that has garnered the most support that week.
  • At the end of the campaign, whichever team has the most support will receive 6 hours of recording studio time to have their piece professionally recorded.
Help us build our community!

Other Ways You Can Help

Friend/Follow us on Facebook and Twitter, or check out our website for more information!

www.WVMTF.com
