Purpose
In a world where accountants make artistic decisions and money is often the only obstacle, the West Village Musical Theatre Festival seeks to celebrate artists and work that may not otherwise have a chance to come to fruition.  The WVMTF offers a chance for writers and composers to have a real hands-on professional production with minimal cost. 
Format
The 2012 WVMTF will run Wednesday, June 13th through Sunday, June 17th, showcasing four series of six shows each, for a total of 24 unique shows.  Each series will be sold as a separate event, and will contain six back-to-back shows that are fifteen minutes in length.  Series A and C will be “Shorts”, shows that are fifteen minutes from start to finish.  Series B and D will be “Snapshots”, or shows that are fifteen minutes of a larger work.
SHOWS
SERIES A - SHORTS
The Councilwoman
Gary Goldfarb: Master Escapist
The Bed
Choices
Face to Facebook
Angry Birds
 
SERIES B - SNAPSHOTS
Geeked and Loaded
Tambo
Honor and Family
Greenwich Village Love Story
 
SERIES C - WORKSHOPS
Visiting Day
Preschool! A Pint-Sized Musical
A Day in the Night
That's Just Super
Day at the White House
Best/Worst Day Ever
 
SERIES D - SNAPSHOTS
Modern Myth
Secondhand Shakespeare
Bielke
Mah Jongg the Musical
Cowboys Don't Sing
Check out the website (www.WVMTF.com) for info on series showtimes and more! 


What We Need & What You Get
All productions and festivals have expenses, ours is no different.
Because the WVMTF is going Off-Broadway this year, we're upgrading our equipment.  In order to provide the best for the best, we're looking to invest in wireless microphones.  These extra funds will also help cover events, insurance, technical staff and other important aspects of our successful production.
Please help us reach our goal! 


The Impact
The WVMTF is a place where creative artists can begin to put their work on its feet, develop an idea, network with other emerging professionals, and come to understand the process of producing a show in New York.
All donations made in support of specific show have REAL REWARDS for the teams!

Teams that sign up for our fiscal sponsorship program will have up to 90% of your donation regranted directly to the team.
For every $500 raised in support of a show, that team will receive a Village Voucher.
Each week the WVMTF will reward 4 hours of studio rehearsal space to the team that has garnered the most support that week.
At the end of the campaign, whichever team has the most support will receive 6 hours of recording studio time to have their piece professionally recorded.

Help us build our community!


Other Ways You Can Help
Friend/Follow us on Facebook and Twitter, or check out our website for more information!
www.WVMTF.com

story:
It's Christmas, Chanukah, Kwanzaa!!!!! Why Not Give?!!!

2013 is Stone Soup Theatre Project's debut season and we're excited! Please consider giving a little donation to help support a first season that we are proud to announce......

Our first production, Tamer of Horses by William Mastrosimone, will open April 5, 2013 and will be produced at the SENN High School Studio Theatre on Chicago's North-side. With the production we will take on 15 of SENN's Performing Arts students as interns and offer them the opportunity to work with a professional company. We believe Tamer of Horses will be a beautiful first step for us by examining youth violence, education, and personal relationships on stage. We will set up a series of talkbacks, one each week of the production, with local community members who deal with the same issues on the North-side that the production touches on. Truly uniting our community with theatre.

Our Education Director, Hannah Gallagher, has another amazing summer of classes for local students lined up. Our Education Department works hand in hand with our Outreach Department to identify students who have a love for the arts but may not have the resources available to experience them. Classes and workshops (like our productions) will cost little to nothing so everyone in our community can have the opportunity to enjoy theatre.

Fall 2013 we will produce a true "Theatre Project". Artistic Associate Katie Abascal has started to adapt 21; epitome of perseverance to the stage and we are excited to tell the story of Chris Patterson, a former Black P Stone member turned community activist.  Chris is a local North-side community member and his life story is one of courage, pain, hope, fear, and redemption. A former member of a Chicago gang who after serving time in the federal system decided to serve the community he felt he hurt. Chris is a long time friend of Stone Soup; our work with him through "Cure Violence" and "Organization Of the Northeast" has allowed us to connect with community members though theatre. We hope by telling his story we can help audiences relate to the same people who we have started to work with. We are using local actors, activists, writers, and community members to tell the story of one of our own. 

  

We need $5 from 100 people. That's all!!!!!!

This will allow us a little more room in our operating budget for the upcoming year. We get the equivalent of your venti salted caramel mocha and you get a little holiday cheer knowing you are giving theatre to the communities of Northeast Chicago. 

You could spend

$5- for Starbucks on the way to work

$5- on that extra beer

$5- on the Subway Foot-long that always looks better than it tastes

$5- giving a little joy to yourself and others!!!!!!!!

Any gift (even $1) goes to support the work of Stone Soup Theatre Project in our community. Your little bit of cheer will last year round by giving us the capability to work in our neighborhoods. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Though $5 may not sound like a lot we know for some it is more than you can afford to give. Please don't worry! You can give a little joy by sharing our work! Let others know about us, encourage your friends and family to check us out, follow our staff blogs, and like us on Facebook. This support goes a long way as we start to make a name for ourselves!

story:
CARMEN ELEKTRA: Opera Underground

We are a young collective of musicians with a keen interest in theatre, modern opera, and clubbing. We believe that opera can shake off it's aesthetic trappings by embracing popular culture and rejecting cumbersome traditions. To try and prove this, we've been producing 'opera club nights' for the last three years, presenting short, modern and accessible works in unconventional venues amidst DJ sets and multimedia installations, and we want to bring our event concept to the London scene.

http://www.carmen-elektra.com/
 
Britney and Justin: Operatic Heroes?

This launch night in Peckham's Bussey Building, will see the UK premiÃ¨re of Jacob Cooper's Timberbrit - a hallucinogenic, electronic fantasy imagining Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake as doomed lovers. The opera constructs its nightmarish atmospheres by borrowing material from real Britney/Justin songs and digitally manipulating it until almost unrecognisable. The premiere will be complimented by two new experimental operas written especially for the venue, as well as DJ sets, dancing and debauchery - exactly how opera should be enjoyed!

For a taste of Timberbrit, please enjoy the trailer video above, which was made by Sherng-Lee Huang and Phelps Harmon, for the world premiere production of the opera in New York, and features Melissa Hughes as Britney.


Why support Carmen Elektra?


We believe that opera doesn't need huge budgets and expensive stage effects to be powerful and thrilling. In fact, we think opera can really benefit from small-scale productions, intimate settings and the challenge of creating drama on a shoe-string. We want to keep Carmen Elektra: Opera Underground as independent as possible, and not reliant on institutional ties or corporate sponsorship. We have managed to raise enough funds ourselves to get started, but we are looking for a final thousand dollars (or ~Â£637) to help make the project a reality, covering all number of small costs from equipment hire to lighting to publicity campaigns. 


Most of all, your contribution to this production will help Carmen Elektra to establish itself in London and enable many exciting further productions through our unique concept. We have lots of plans for future projects, and promise to keep bringing interesting works to an interested public!


What about me?


As if that wasn't enough, we are offering some irresistible treats for contributors (including the chance to commission a song or hear a private recital)! For more information, look at our perks ----->


How do I help?


Simply donate as much as you want - by card - through this page!


What if I don't have any money?

If you can't donate, we would love it if you could spread our fundraising page all over the web - as far and wide as possible...

story:
Our Story

Home Between Waves is an original performance created by an ensemble of Northwestern undergraduate students, by with and for the NU community.  The performance centers around the "immigrant experience," and the script is based on stories from short literature, natural and behavioral science, and the words and experiences of Northwestern students.  As a devised piece, the process to create this began officially in mid-Fall, after months of research into the subject matter and literature on the part of the director.  In Fall, the director led a cast of six actors in creating a performance based on the materials gathered and their own questions about changing homes. The end result is the story of six strangers who come together to tell three storiesâ€”each of which focuses on a different aspect of an immigrantâ€™s experience. Each of these people has his/her own definition of â€œhome,â€ and in the show, they discover many others. Utilizing movement, music, and original animations created by Northwestern film students, Home Between Waves weaves together these stories with care, rigor, and a spirit of collaboration. 


Devised and Performed by:
Bridget McNamara
Casey Hartley
Jake Degler
Josh Schwartz
Madeline Pereira
Nicola Rinow

Directed by Abby Schwarz
Produced by Bessie Tockstein


The Impact

The magical performance asks the question, is there something universally human about the contested, often polarizing subject of immigration?  What does a Northwestern student who came to Evanston from a rural suburb in Illinois have in common with a Brazillian immigrant whose home was uprooted by a mudslide?  The characters in the show grapple with how to adapt to a new place, how to remember where they came from, and what â€œhomeâ€ means.  The project hopes to engage the campus community in these questions, and has made a concerted effort already to involve students beyond the often insular theatre community.  We have interviewed international students and transfer students, as well as professors whose expertise relates to the topics in the show.  We had a roundtable event bringing many of these individuals together to engage in conversation about these topics.  We will also host a storytelling event, in which people from all over the campus community will share and hear their own stories related to this topic.


What We Need & What You Get

We have been given $250 from Northwestern's Performance Studies Department. Our budget needs to fund primarily space design, props, costumes, publicity, sound and lights. We need your help in order to fund this production to effectively tell our stories and the stories of our community!


In addition to the money we hope to raise with this site, we are planning a "comfort food" bake sale in which the cast and production team will be cooking and selling foods that remind us of home in order to fundraise our show. We also applied for a grant that will hopefully help us get closer to our fundraising goal!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this project! Whether it is attending our production, sharing this website with friends or family, or even just thinking about what home means to you, will help us reach our overall goal. 


HARTLAND ALLIANCE

Donating to this production not only benefits our show, but any extra proceeds we raise will be donated to Hartland Alliance, a non profit organization in Chicago. 

Heartland Alliance advances the human rights and responds to the human needs of endangered populationsâ€”particularly the poor, the isolated, and the displacedâ€”through the provision of comprehensive and respectful services and the promotion of permanent solutions leading to a more just global society.

story:
Coleen's Theatre Practice, attending Ecole Jacques Lecoq

In February I walked with Michael Ondaatje along Queen Street West while the snow fell on our eyelashes.

He asked me: "Do you consider yourself a writer?"  I looked at this great Canadian writer, my eyes aglow, "Yes, yes I do"  I said:  "My first impulse has always been to write".  There was a deep silence as we continued to walk East.  I was alight inside.

So this is my hope, to work towards writing for the stage in a new way by attending a great theatre school in Paris, France.  Here is my letter, my plea, my hope, my joy, and of course my burden, which is: the money I must gain in order to make this all happen.

 

Dear friends and those who believe in the Arts in this country,

I am Coleen Shirin MacPherson.  I am Parsi-Irish, Canadian.  I am a theatre creator (Actor, Director, Playwright) and poet.  I have worked in Toronto for over five years,  creating work with diverse companies like TheatreRUN, Why Not Theatre, Necessary Angel Theatre, Theatre Smith-Gilmour, Theatre Local, Jumblies Theatre, The Children's Peace Theatre and MT Space in Kitchener.  I have formed The Pocketology Collective with Rachel Ellison and created "spontaneous moments between strangers".  I write plays, produce readings, teach children playwriting, act and direct. Most recently I mentored with Canada's renowned theatre director, Daniel Brooks and toured to Shangai's Contemporary Theater Festival with TheatreRUN.  I was on CBC's Here and Now with a short documentary on Pocketology, and a play I co-translated with Adam Paolozza will be published in a book on Contemporary Theatre Anthology in Rome.  I am currently compiling all of my poetry into a book and writing a new play, The Selfsame Hour.  Most recently I performed in Artaud:  Un Portrait en Decomposition at Summerworks Festival with TheatreRUN.

Within this momentum of my career, I find that I need to find calm and go deeper into my practice to truly find what it is I can contribute.  I know that after attending Ecole Jacques Lecoq in Paris, my work will become richer, and I hope to bring this strength and knowledge to the future work I will do in Toronto.  I know that this process of going further into my practice will benefit the public and my future collaborators immensely (that is the hope!)

I am asking for support in my endeavour to attend the school.  Not only will I be able to create the work I am dreaming of making, but I will also be able to mentor children and youth in a more wholistic way.  I have worked with 100s of children across Ontario this year, and I know with further knowledge I can enrich these kids' lives and help to develop a new generation of theatre makers and theatre goers.

Without the funding I was hoping to get from the Canada Council for the Arts, my stay in France and attending the school will be financially precarious. There is the flight, the rent, the cost of living and then tuition.  All of these costs add up, and I hope that I can gain a little extra from you in order to make this less difficult.

The support would not only be going to my education at Ecole Jacques Lecoq, but it will also be an investment in the future of Canadian Theatre and Community Arts in Toronto.  My work spans from Directing, Acting, Playwriting to art installations and community arts projects.  I hope you will consider this a worthwhile investment, and I promise to repay this kindness in the form of my art in the future!  In addition, I have strong connections with the next generation of theatre artists in Toronto, and am beginning to form a theatre company under the name Open Heart Surgery Theatre.  My goal is to return to Canada with new energy and knowledge and develop this company, which will have three branches of creative work:  theatre (original), installation/Media work (sound installations to video projects to relational art happenings) and film work (with theatrical exploration).  I am excited in theatre that transcends space and time.  A lot of my ideas are new, they need time to grow, the seeds are there, but the deeper insight needs to be found.  This is why I am attending the school, and so, I hope you will help in any way to make this a little easier for me.

The School

Jacques Lecoq founded l’École Internationale de Théâtre Jacques Lecoqi n 1956, developing teaching methods that have inspired numerous practitioners of theatre, in which gesture is at the basis of the performance.

It is a school that looks at life, movement and the different areas of theatre (tragedy, comedy, bouffon, clown, burlesque).  You are in contact with other theatre makers from all over the world, and are brought into an interrogation with yourself, as to what you want to say, and what kind of theatre you want to make.   What kind of artist can I be in the times we live in today?  How can I serve the public better?  what kind of work is important and essential to our lives? These are questions that are swirling in my head that I hope to find a glimmer of an answer.

What Other Theatre Artists Say about Coleen:

 

Coleen's desire to study at L'Ecole Jacques Lecoq puts her in a growing group of Canadian Theatre Artists who are searching for a new, unique theatre of creation that is physical and human: a training that explores the source of theatre creation.  I attended this school in the late 70s and it changed my life as a theatre maker and as a person.  The work I have been doing for the past 30 years in Canada grew from my time at the school, studying with Lecoq.  

(Dean Gilmour, Co-Artistic Director of Theatre Smith-Gilmour)

Coleen is at a unique position in her development as a professional artist. She has been working professionally as a writer and performer for some years now and is discovering that her true calling is as a theatre creator. What I mean by this is that what she has to offer to the future of Canadian theatre are not just her skills as a writer/poet (which are prodigious), nor her skills as a perfumer and director. She has a vision of a theatre to be: a theatre of the future. She is hungry to create, to explore hitherto unknown theatrical territory. To achieve this she needs unique training. Training that will help her deepen her technical skills as a writer and performer and help her articulate exactly what she has to say as an artist. Lecoq is the perfect place for this.  

(Adam Paolozza, Artistic Director of TheatreRUN Canada)

 

Funding

I need to raise at least $3700 in order to fulfill the gap from the funding I was hoping to get from The Canada Council for the Arts.  The money will be going directly to tuition and the plane fare required to get to France.  You will be directly investing in an important step in my development as an artist in this country.  I hope that you consider giving something to this campaign.

There are four categories for donations, let me tell you about the perks:

Great Donor:  A donation of $25 will go a long way believe me.  To send my appreciation, you will receive a personalized card and an i-owe-you to future projects in Toronto.

Really Really Great Donor:  A Donation of $50 you will receive a personalized card and an i-owe-you to future projects & a surprise gift card to a series of stores (Starbucks, Home Sense, Home Hardware etc.)

COURSE:  A systematic introduction to the theory and practice of Yoga for beginners or for anyone looking to renew their practice. Step by step approach for developing strength, flexibility, good breathing habits, concentration and relaxation.

The course introduces the 5 Points of Yoga, 12 basic yoga postures (Asanas), Breathing exercises (Pranayama), Relaxation exercises, Introduction to proper diet, Introduction to positive thinking and meditation. A four-week course meeting twice a week.

(Value over $200)

A Donor Beyond Words:  A Donation of $1000 you will get a meal at Enoteca Sociale, a wine bar on Dundas West that has been voted one of the top restaurants in Canada ($100 value).  1288 Dundas Street West, Toronto, Ontario.  If you do not live in Toronto, you will receive a surprise gift in the mail.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word to those that you think would be interested in helping, help build noise about my campaign!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this with the people you know.

THANK YOU FOR TAKING THE TIME TO READ THIS !  

 

Follow My Blog - my journey in Paris and at the school:  http://poesieinspace.tumblr.com

The support would not only be going to my education at Ecole Jacques Lecoq, but it will also be an investment in the future of Canadian Theatre and Community Arts in Toronto.  My work spans from Directing, Acting, Playwriting to art installations and community arts projects.  I hope you will consider this a worthwhile investment, and I promise to repay this kindness in the form of my art in the future!  In addition, I have strong connections with the next generation of theatre artists in Toronto, and am beginning to form a theatre company under the name Open Heart Surgery Theatre.  My goal is to return to Canada with new energy and knowledge and develop this company, which will have three branches of creative work:  theatre (original), installation/Media work (sound installations to video projects to relational art happenings) and film work (with theatrical exploration).  I am excited in theatre that transcends space and time.  A lot of my ideas are new, they need time to grow, the seeds are there, but the deeper insight needs to be found.  This is why I am attending the school, and so, I hope you will help in any way to make this a little easier for me.
The School

Jacques Lecoq founded l’École Internationale de Théâtre Jacques Lecoqi n 1956, developing teaching methods that have inspired numerous practitioners of theatre, in which gesture is at the basis of the performance.

It is a school that looks at life, movement and the different areas of theatre (tragedy, comedy, bouffon, clown, burlesque).  You are in contact with other theatre makers from all over the world, and are brought into an interrogation with yourself, as to what you want to say, and what kind of theatre you want to make.   What kind of artist can I be in the times we live in today?  How can I serve the public better?  what kind of work is important and essential to our lives? These are questions that are swirling in my head that I hope to find a glimmer of an answer.
What Other Theatre Artists Say about Coleen:
 
Coleen's desire to study at L'Ecole Jacques Lecoq puts her in a growing group of Canadian Theatre Artists who are searching for a new, unique theatre of creation that is physical and human: a training that explores the source of theatre creation.  I attended this school in the late 70s and it changed my life as a theatre maker and as a person.  The work I have been doing for the past 30 years in Canada grew from my time at the school, studying with Lecoq.  
(Dean Gilmour, Co-Artistic Director of Theatre Smith-Gilmour)
Coleen is at a unique position in her development as a professional artist. She has been working professionally as a writer and performer for some years now and is discovering that her true calling is as a theatre creator. What I mean by this is that what she has to offer to the future of Canadian theatre are not just her skills as a writer/poet (which are prodigious), nor her skills as a perfumer and director. She has a vision of a theatre to be: a theatre of the future. She is hungry to create, to explore hitherto unknown theatrical territory. To achieve this she needs unique training. Training that will help her deepen her technical skills as a writer and performer and help her articulate exactly what she has to say as an artist. Lecoq is the perfect place for this.  
(Adam Paolozza, Artistic Director of TheatreRUN Canada)
 
Funding
I need to raise at least $3700 in order to fulfill the gap from the funding I was hoping to get from The Canada Council for the Arts.  The money will be going directly to tuition and the plane fare required to get to France.  You will be directly investing in an important step in my development as an artist in this country.  I hope that you consider giving something to this campaign.
There are four categories for donations, let me tell you about the perks:
Great Donor:  A donation of $25 will go a long way believe me.  To send my appreciation, you will receive a personalized card and an i-owe-you to future projects in Toronto.
Really Really Great Donor:  A Donation of $50 you will receive a personalized card and an i-owe-you to future projects & a surprise gift card to a series of stores (Starbucks, Home Sense, Home Hardware etc.)
COURSE:  A systematic introduction to the theory and practice of Yoga for beginners or for anyone looking to renew their practice. Step by step approach for developing strength, flexibility, good breathing habits, concentration and relaxation.
The course introduces the 5 Points of Yoga, 12 basic yoga postures (Asanas), Breathing exercises (Pranayama), Relaxation exercises, Introduction to proper diet, Introduction to positive thinking and meditation. A four-week course meeting twice a week.
(Value over $200)
A Donor Beyond Words:  A Donation of $1000 you will get a meal at Enoteca Sociale, a wine bar on Dundas West that has been voted one of the top restaurants in Canada ($100 value).  1288 Dundas Street West, Toronto, Ontario.  If you do not live in Toronto, you will receive a surprise gift in the mail.
 
Other Ways You Can Help


Please spread the word to those that you think would be interested in helping, help build noise about my campaign!
Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this with the people you know.
THANK YOU FOR TAKING THE TIME TO READ THIS !  
 
Follow My Blog - my journey in Paris and at the school:  http://poesieinspace.tumblr.com

story:
Individual Artist Collective advocates for the professional development of unaffiliated Latino and Latina artists who are seeking to advance their careers in the arts. The collective seeks to bridge the gap between the business and creative development of the artist by building innovative partnerships with large art organizations and funders.

The Individual Artist Collective believes the work of Latina and Latino artists is a vital part of the American theater.  We are an arts group that was inspired by Theatre Communication Group’s 2011 National Conference in Los Angeles and the 2011 Director’s Lab West. Two members of the group attended and made an important observation. Artists of color are not very well represented at these types of events. The reason is unknown. It may be that these artists are busy creating art and don’t apply to these events. It may also be that these events are expensive to attend. Or it may be that we just don’t know that conferences about theatre and the arts exists and therefore we don’t attend.
 
The Individual Artist Collective decided to take it upon themselves to ensure their participation at events where theatre is being discussed and created. We need to be at the table or our contributions are invisible.

Our goal is to raise $3,000 to send seven of our members to the 2012 TCG Conference. This year’s conference is in Boston and we are going to be there to share our work with the rest of the country. We have been chosen to present a panel at the conference and we are raising funds to pay for the airfare to send seven members from the collective to attend the conference.  Our registrations fees are paid for, now we need help getting there.  
 
The Individual Artist Collective has received supoort from other artists such Playwrights Tanya Saracho and Luis Alfaro, Asssociate Producer Diane Rodriguez and LA Director of Cultural Affairs Olga Garay, and artists Lalo Alcaraz and Joe Hernandez-Kolski.
If you can’t contribute in a monetary fashion, that doesn’t mean you can’t help.  Please help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
 
For more details about the Individual Artist Collective go to http://individualartist.tumblr.com/.
 
Follow us on twitter @indieac.

story:
Short Summary

Theatre a la Sauvage is an independent theatre company comprised of 5 female Concordia University students. Our show Gaulier Made Me Cry is a collective creation, telling the story of how a thirteen day workshop with clown master Phillippe Gaulier made Kendall cry!

This 30 minute play will be showing at the Montreal Fringe festival in June 2012. Your contributions will help turn this show into the delectable riot we know it can be!

Money raised will go towards refunding any costs of the show including the festival fee for stage space, design elements and promotion materials. Our goal is to break even, so our students budgets aren't left too barren. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of the costs of this performance:

Fringe fee - $460

Press Realease Kit - $100

Printing (posters and promo cards) - $150

Design - $350 (this includes a floor and a lot of shaving cream to make the pies which will be thrown throughout the show)

We are hoping to break even from these costs. So even if we don't reach our goal, the money will be put towards refunding each member evenly for their contributions to the show.

In thanks for your generous contributions we have put together some creative gifts that are relevant to Gaulier Made Me Cry:

$1-$24: Good karma! 

$25-$49: A DVD copy of the show! If you can't make it to Montreal to see it live or simply to be able to watch it over and over again.

$50-$99: A handmade commemorative handkerchief. We will be making unique silk screened handkerchiefs to we away tears of laughter and pie!

$100+: A unique video game made by Sebastien Duval. You can choose to throw pies at Kendall the clown, orpersonalize the game to throw pies at someone you know!

The Impact

This show is hugely important in our budding careers, as all five of us are either very recent or soon-to-be graduates of the Concordia theatre program. This fringe show offers us real life experience in our field of interest and a stepping stone into the world of professional theatre.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate money we understand! Please help us out by promoting our show to your friends and family! Post our video online and visit our blog

(http://theatrealasauvage.tumblr.com)

Tickets to the show are only 6$ and 5$ for students and QDF members (+2$ service fee)

story:
Our Story

 

My name is Charles Shetcliffe, I am thirty years old, from the UK and am studying theatre and comedy in Paris, France. I am studying at the Ecole Phillipe Gaulier, which is an international school, specialising in Clown and Bouffon. Some previous students include Sacha Baron Cohen (Ali G/Borat), Helena Bonham Carter, Emma Thompson and Cal McCrystal (directed The Mighty Boosh). I have been performing for over 10 years and worked with companies such as The Invisible Circus, The Wonderclub, Arcadia, Ratupadrainpipe, InService Productions and other independent theatre makers. I have also trained ballet and performed in various shows throughout my teens. I recently found a passion for street performing and am enjoying acrobatics, fire eating and body burning.

 

In 2008 I was diagnosed with Huntington's disease; a genetic disorder that I inherited from my father, who died early last year from it. Huntington's disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative genetic disorder that affects muscle coordination and leads to cognitive decline and dementia. The earliest symptoms are a general lack of coordination and an unsteady gait. As the disease advances, uncoordinated, jerky body movements become more apparent, along with a decline in mental abilities and behavioural and psychiatric problems. Physical abilities are gradually impeded until coordinated movement becomes very difficult. Mental abilities generally decline into dementia. Complications such as pneumonia, heart disease, and physical injury from falls reduce life expectancy to around twenty years after symptoms begin. There is no cure for HD, and full-time care is required in the later stages of the disease.

 

For the past year I have been studying at Ecole Phillipe Gaulier, and it is incredible to see the changes in the lives of the students and myself.  It inspires me that when I get older the opportunities exist to still perform and make people laugh on stage.  I am interested in creating the space for all to be idiots, to be beautiful idiots and shine a glorious light of humour on the things that make us human, and provide this opportunity to others from all walks of life. And that is why the school is an inspiration to me, because it embodies those principals, and it is a crucial part of the journey in making this a reality. I will bring this transformation to the Huntingdon's community. I will start by performing a bouffon show and running workshops for people affected by Huntington's disease in the UK. We will then build a new show, with the HD community, that will be performed across the country in 2013.

 

At this point in the mission we are looking for the remaining funds of three thousand pounds (4660 dollars). This will pay for the fees and allow me to finish studying at the school. It will kick start A Ship of Fool's Theatre Company which will be a force for change in the world; enabling us to create theatre with the Huntingdon's community, that is world class, using this to communicate their stories in a beautiful and humorous way.

 

Please help us to spread the word of A Ship of Fools. Tell your friends, family, employers, your neighbours dog! The more people who know about our cause the faster and more productive we can be. If you can't help financially, there are other ways to get involved: Spread the word or get in touch with us at: 1.a.ship.of.fools.1@gmail.com

story:
There are some stories that define a generation. Of course, one of them is the flight of Balloon Boy. Or at least, that’s what it seemed like at the time. For over an hour, America sat by their TV’s and watched the 50 mile flight of a notable silver weather balloon across the mountaintops of Colorado. Why? Because a Fort Collins father had told the press that his six-year-old son was trapped in the home-made, mylar contraption, leading the press into a frenzy that took over the airwaves. Once the Balloon landed and it was discovered that the young boy was in fact not in it, but hiding in a cardboard box in the family’s attic, the Balloon Boy and his family became instant celebrities, until young Falcon admitted on Larry King Live that it was all a hoax, or more famously, “You guys said we did this for the show”.

When this story occurred almost six years ago, I was only in seventh grade. Still, I was moved by it’s over the top twists and turns and began writing the first draft of “Balloon Boy: The Musical”. Looking back, that first draft was rough. It overflowed with a seventh grade mentality and sense of humor, but I discovered that this show which I felt incredibly passionate about then, and even more passionate about now, had the potential to take me and this story on an incredible journey. 

The past six years have been very exciting for Balloon Boy: In 2011, a workshop was held at the Kraine Theatre, and in 2014 it won the Thespian Musicalworks Award and was presented at the International Thespian Festival in Lincoln, Nebraska. Following this, it received a much publicized world premiere at Monarch High School in Louisville, Colorado, only a few miles away from where the actual event took place. Of course, the show itself has also changed dramatically in the past few years. What started as a light hearted romp with a middle school feel to it, has become a quirky, over the top, irreverent, satirical, and at times poignant look at the American media system and the idea of the modern American family. It has been alot of hard work turning the show into what it is today, but it has been overwhelmingly worth it.

This brings me to the next step for Balloon Boy. The show has been chosen as an official selection of the 2015 New York Musical Theatre Festival, and will be presented as a staged reading this July 7th and 11th. Also exciting is that at 17, I am officially the youngest writer to ever be accepted into this prestigious festival. I am humbled, overjoyed and extremely grateful for this opportunity. However, a balloon needs helium to fly, so I need YOUR help to make Balloon Boy: The Musical New York’s next great musical comedy.

ABOUT NYMF

The New York Musical Theatre Festival nurtures the creation, production, and public presentation of stylistically, thematically, and culturally diverse new musicals to ensure the future vitality of musical theatre.

NYMF is the biggest festival in the world for musicals. Since it’s inception in 2004, it has been the birthplace of three Broadway shows, Next To Normal, title of show, and Chaplin, and 25 off-broadway shows, including this year’s Clinton: The Musical and Altar Boyz. To be in the company of these amazing musicals in absolute honor, and to know that Balloon Boy could fly farther is a dream come true. Balloon Boy’s reading will be staged in an off-broadway theatre, along with many other shows spread out across July, with a professional cast and crew, all thanks to help from NYMF.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT BALLOON BOY: THE MUSICAL

Balloon Boy is irreverent, over the top, quirky and above all else, hilarious. I knew that once it was discovered that this event was all a hoax, a musical comedy needed to be written for two reasons. The first, it was clear that this story was presented in such a dramatic context, it sang. Secondly, I saw the overwhelming anger that the story’s climax brought to the country, and I knew the only way that we could get past that, was to laugh. I think that laughter is the best prescription for frustration it today’s day and age, and if we could laugh at how a family tried to fly to the spotlight and how we all helped them do it, then perhaps it wouldn’t be as frustrating.

That being said, Balloon Boy also imagines what went on behind this story and how it affected the family at it’s center. While the musical is certainly not for what the Heene family did, it explores why what happened happened, and how the spotlight can affect a scheming father, a devoted wife and a confused child.

Balloon Boy: The Musical has also been reset to take place in the present, as due to it’s themes of instant fame and viral celebrity, it seemed only fitting that the story could have happened now. In doing this, the characters, songs and scenes are constantly updated with the most recent pop culture characters so that the musical, in an SNL-esque fashion can stay up to date and therefore feel more satirically poignant.

So, what celebrities can you expect to see in the latest production? You’ll just have to come to find out.

WHY I NEED YOUR HELP

As I’ve said before, I am insanely passionate about my musical, and I only want the best for it. So, I need the best help I can get. This includes my getting a director, musical director, stage manager and a cast of ten professional performers. In donating, not only will you receive some awesome items to prove that you were a part of the production of this ground-breaking new musical, but you will allow me to showcase Balloon Boy in the way I always dreamed it should be, and in the way that you as an audience deserve.

Now is the time to fly. And I hope that you will be able to join me and Balloon Boy: The Musical in flight.


https://soundcloud.com/billy-recce/sets/balloon...

story:
The (New) Trial, adapted from Peter Weiss’s The New Trial, presents a surreal look at the life of Joseph K, an attorney in an international corporation that explores K’s obsessive idealism and his self-destructive methodology in helping others. Confined in his own docile body, K is manipulated as the public mask for the corporation to win the “war” current global market expansion competition, and eventually is abandoned by the corporation once the victory is obtained.

The (New) Trial attempts to deconstruct the docile nature of the self and the hierarchical power relations among the characters of the play, hoping to stimulate changes to society. To manifest this essential concept, actors will explore power dynamics among different characters, and will break the fourth wall to share their real life experience of being an actor with monologues. A giant mirror will also cover up the stage floor for actors to be fully aware of the power relations to the self.

Performance Detail

The (New) Trial is presented by Theater for the New City as part of Dream Up Festival, and is made possible by The Living Theatre, and Label Gray.

Location: Theater for the New City

Time & Date:
September 1 at 6:30pm
September 2 at 6:30pm
September 3 at 6:30pm
September 4 at 9pm
September 5 at 8pm
September 6 at 5pm

Producer: Maria Hoffmann, Dennis Yueh-Yeh Li
Advisory Producer: Miriam Ibrahim
Production Manager: Leonie Ettinger
Director: Dennis Yueh-Yeh Li
Author: Peter Weiss
Stage Manager: Laura Virginia Sandez
Stage Manager: You-Shin Chen
Lighting Designer: Yi-Chung Chen
Sound Designer: Yung-Chin Chang
Graphic Designer: Lisa Lee
Ensemble: Brad Burgess, Leah Bachar, Jody Doo, Serena Gregorio, Samantha Hoefer, Maria Hoffmann, Omri Kadim, & Maite Uzal


The Impact

After the huge success of Marat/Sade, the experimental play in 1965on Broadway by the celebrated German playwright Peter Weiss with the Tony Award and New York Drama Critics’ Circle Award, our international team, coming from Germany, Taiwan, Singapore, Israel, Spain, Argentina, and United States ,will bring Peter Weiss’s last play The New Trial into life with a newly adaptation The (New) Trial to celebrate Peter Weiss’s 100th birthday of next year, and his theatrical legacy, to accomplish the following goals:

    • Fostering intercultural dialogues on social mechanisms with the introduction of German post-war theatre.

    • Facilitating artistic/cultural exchange among Taiwanese and German artists, with a hope of creating more collaboration opportunities between Taiwan and Germany.

    • Reintroduce Peter Weiss’s work through the presentation of The (New) Trial to the American stage.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come to see the show! Get your ticket! Get ticket here!
  • Spread the words about the show!
If you choose one of the perks to help us, don't forget to leave your contact information!
story_txt:
The (New) Trial, adapted from Peter Weiss’s The New Trial, presents a surreal look
at the life of Joseph K, an attorney in an international corporation that
explores K’s obsessive idealism and his self-destructive methodology in helping
others. Confined in his own docile body, K is manipulated as the public mask
for the corporation to win the “war” current global market expansion
competition, and eventually is abandoned by the corporation once the victory is
obtained.
The (New) Trial attempts to
deconstruct the docile nature of the self and the hierarchical power relations
among the characters of the play, hoping to stimulate changes to society.
To manifest this essential concept, actors will explore power dynamics among
different characters, and will break the fourth wall to share their real life
experience of being an actor with monologues. A giant mirror will also cover up
the stage floor for actors to be fully aware of the power relations to the
self.

Performance Detail

The (New) Trial is presented by Theater for the New City as part of Dream Up Festival, and is made possible by The Living Theatre, and Label Gray.
Location: Theater for the New City
Time & Date:September 1 at 6:30pmSeptember 2 at 6:30pmSeptember 3 at 6:30pmSeptember 4 at 9pmSeptember 5 at 8pmSeptember 6 at 5pmProducer: Maria Hoffmann, Dennis Yueh-Yeh LiAdvisory Producer: Miriam IbrahimProduction Manager: Leonie EttingerDirector: Dennis Yueh-Yeh LiAuthor: Peter WeissStage Manager: Laura Virginia SandezStage Manager: You-Shin ChenLighting Designer: Yi-Chung ChenSound Designer: Yung-Chin ChangGraphic Designer: Lisa LeeEnsemble: Brad Burgess, Leah Bachar, Jody Doo, Serena Gregorio, Samantha Hoefer, Maria Hoffmann, Omri Kadim, & Maite Uzal

After
the huge success of Marat/Sade, the
experimental play in 1965on Broadway by the celebrated German playwright Peter Weiss with the Tony Award
and New York Drama Critics’ Circle Award, our international team, coming from Germany, Taiwan, Singapore, Israel, Spain, Argentina, and United States ,will bring Peter Weiss’s last play The New Trial into life with a newly adaptation The (New) Trial to celebrate Peter

story:
Folklore Flavor: 3 City Community Tour


Why is this important to me and my community?

Mi nombre es Ricardo Manuel Guevara. Tengo 22 años y 7 años en la cultura de bboying.  Mi nombre artístico es Bboy Charu con el cual todos me conocen.  En todos mis años siendo parte de la cultura trato de incentivar a demás personas a que se unan y sean parte de la misma de la manera de que puedan convivir, compartan, aprendan y tengan en cuenta una forma distinta de vivir.  En toda mi experiencia bailando y conociendo personas e tenido como resultado el sueño de representar mi país y representar a mi pueblo, mi gente y todo lo que hago lo hago por ellos.  Cada nueva experiencia es para compartirla a ellos y poder dejarles una semilla de lo que ellos no han podido tener y poder darles motivación  y mas determinación para que puedan salir adelante.  Me vean como una imagen en el día de mañana y en el futuro pueda dejar una huella de todo lo que e hecho por mi pueblo.  Mi principal sueño es tener esto plasmado en la mente de todos los que pueden lograr algo en algún momento de su vida y lo tengan presente siempre.

My name is Richard Manuel Gevara.  I'm 22 years old and I've been participating in bboy culture for 7 years.  Everyone who knows me calls me by my artist name, Bboy Charu.  In all my years being part of this culture, I've tried to encourage others to join and be part of this culture in a way that encourages people to connect, share, learn, and to take into account a distinct way of living and seeing the world.  My experience dancing and getting to know people through this culture has resulted in in a dream to represent my country and represent my people and to share all I do to represent them in a good way.  Each new experience I've been blessed with gives me motivation to share with my community and to leave a seed of inspiration and motivation for others to go forward and grow.  This campaign represents a start in building for tomorrow so that in the future I will be able to say I did my best to build up my community both locally and globally.  The larger goal, the big dream if you will, is to have my passions for this culture and the positive impact it has on my community reflected in the minds of those who are beginning their own journeys to accomplishing their own dreams.

Impact

Mi objetivo para esta campaña para recaudar fondos suficientes para permitir que viaje a 3 ciudades para compartir mis conocimientos, la experiencia y construir con otros que están trabajando para crear una Centroamérica más unida y conectada a través de la cultura Hip Hop. Estaré enseñando talleres en los tres lugares. Mi esperanza es que estos talleres ayudarán a apoyar el crecimiento personal y la comunidad a través de la cultura y las tradiciones del Hip Hop. Creo firmemente en la capacidad del Hip Hop para ampliar la visión del mundo y de ofrecer nuevas oportunidades de vida para los jóvenes que aprenden sus cimientos. Hip Hop ha cambiado mi vida y siempre un camino de vida. Quiero compartir esto con los jóvenes en las 3 ciudades de la gira. Para ayudarme a financiar este tour, usted estará apoyando mi visión para levantar mi comunidad.

My goal for this campaign to to raise enough funds to allow me to travel to 3 cities to share my knowledge, experience and to build with others who are working to create a more unified and connected Central America through Hip Hop Culture.  I will be teaching workshops at all three locations. My hope is that these workshops will help to support both personal and community growth through the culture and traditions of Hip Hop.  I believe strongly in Hip Hop's ability to expand the worldview and to offer new life opportunities for youth who learn its foundations.  Hip Hop has changed my life and provided a life path.  I want to share this with youth in all 3 cities of the tour.  By helping me fund this tour, you will be supporting my vision to lift up my community. 


Tour Details

Planeo viajar a 3 paises para ayudar a hacer mi parte para cultivar nuestra cultura y compartir mis conocimientos.  Abajo es le horaria del viaje.

I plan to travel to 3 countries to teach, learn and help do my part to grow our culture and share my knowledge. Below is the tour schedule.

Hall of Femme
30 April, 2015
Nicaragua
I will be traveling to Hall of Femme, an all female Hip Hop festival, to support women’s voices and participation in building our Hip Hop community. While there, I will be taking workshops provided during Hall of Femme. I will also provide a workshop while in Nicaragua for the community.

R16 Centroamerica
30 May, 2015
San Salvador
I will travel to R16 Centroamerica finals en San Salvador to build recognition of Panamanian Bboys and Bgirls


7 Fronteras
6 June, 2015
Honduras
I will travel to Honduras to participate in 7 Fronteras event, organized by 4 Cities Crew & Made in Honduras Crew. While there, I will be providing workshops at local secondary schools for low-income youth in the community. The workshops will be held at José Trinidad Cabañas and E. República de Costa Rica.


Who is Bboy Charu?

Bboy Charu es un bailador de Breaking de Panama de la Provincia de Herrera.  El dedica a promover la cultura hip hop en su pequeña región en Panama. El cual a representado durante 7 años en diferentes países y regiones de Centroamérica y America del norte.  El trata de llevar mas alla su arte a trabes de la danza. Forma parte de una agrupación nacional llamada Die Naam Pro compuesta por jóvenes de diferentes partes de Panamá al igual que una internacional llamada 4 Cities el cual pertenecen bailadores de diferentes países de Centroamérica.


Bboy Charu practices the form and culture of Breaking.  He is from Herrera Province in Panama.  He dedicates himself to promoting Hip Hop Culture en his small region of Panama. He has been representing himself and his country for 7 years in different countries and and regions in Central America y North America.  He works to raise awareness about and elevate this art form and dance culture.  He his part of a national group (Breaking Crew) called Die Naam Pro that trains and builds up youth from different parts of Panama through Hip Hop Culture and dance.  He is also part of an international crew called 4 Cities made up of dancers from Panama, Honduras, Costa Rica & Mexico that works to build the culture and dance form across Central America through teaching and competing in events.

What I Need & What You Get

Voy a viajar tan económicamente como sea posible para mantener los costos bajos. Tengo la intención de tomar el autobús a cada lugar. En cada lugar, me voy a quedar con los organizadores locales. Los fondos se destinarán a pagar por mi viaje y de los alimentos locales + impuestos de viaje para los distintos países.

I will be traveling as inexpensively as possible to keep costs low. I plan to take the bus to each location. At each location, I will be staying with local organizers.

Funds will go to pay for my travel and food + local travel taxes to the various countries.

My estimated budget is ==>

$300USD - Bus Travel (Autobus)
$250USD - Food (Comida)
$50USD -Frontier Tax (travel tax to the various countries)
$500USD =Total Estimated Costs (Costos totales)

I have some perks available at different funding levels. 
Make sure to check them out.


Risks & Challenges

Puede ser difícil para financiar nuestros sueños. Estoy buscando el apoyo de mi comunidad local y global para ayudar a alcanzar este objetivo. Si no soy capaz de recaudar todos los fondos que estoy buscando, yo todavía lo hago todo en mi poder para hacer que la gira suceda. Soy una persona creativa que siempre trata de buscar una vía 

It can be difficult to fund our dreams.  I am seeking support from my local and global community to help me reach this goal.  If I am unable to raise all the funds I'm seeking, I will still do everything in my power to make the tour happen.  I'm a creative person who always tries to fine a way.

Other Ways You Can Help

No todo el mundo puede dar monetariamente. Eso está bien - todavía puede apoyar!

  • Ayudar a difundir la palabra al compartir mi solicitud de apoyo con tus amigos.
  • Deje a sus amigos de la red, la familia y saben acerca de esta página indiegogo.

Not everyone can give monetarily.  That's ok - you can still support!

  • Help spread the word by sharing my call for support with your friends.
  • Let your network, family and friends know about this indiegogo page.

story:
Ghost's after Ibsen by Thomas Kilroy, directed by Austin Pendleton

In this newly revised, freely adapted version of Henrik Ibsen's Ghosts, Kilroy bravely examines ways in which the sins of a father are visited on children in a family frightened by ghosts. Forces of the past and present collide in this biopsy of the interactions between private and public lives, between Church and secular values, and of the characters' prospects as they try to make up for lost time where there's no space left for the truth.
This play was workshopped to rave reviews last August in residency at HB Studio.  And now we want to take it to a larger audience!  In fact so many people told us afterward that we should do it again, that we decided to do just that.  So now the plan is to mount it at "the cell" (yep, that's how it's spelled) in New York City!  http://www.thecelltheatre.org/  Our first show is planned for March 2, so we need to hurry!

Here's What They're Saying about "Ghosts after Ibsen"

"I was greatly taken by the acting and directing of GHOSTS in the workshop.  Nothing would give me grater pleasure than to see it presented to a larger American audience."  Thomas Kilroy, playwright

"I was completely surprised by Ghosts After Ibsen.  I had never seen this play and it was very provocative, the cast was fantastic, and Austin Pendleton had directed it beautifully."  Delia Ephron 

"Directing Thomas Kilroy's adaptation of Ibsen's Ghosts is one of the most exciting experiences I've had in years.  His play amounts to more than a rethinking of the Ibsen play.   It's a whole new play.  A play about Ireland, a play about the discovery by women in Ireland of their own strength in the 1980s, about AIDS, about Catholicism, about the pain and the chaos and, yes, sometimes even the crazy dark humor that arises from the collision of all those things.  It's beautifully written.  And the cast of this production is astonishing and moving.  I would be thrilled to have it up again so that more people can see it."  Austin Pendleton

About Our Company

Thomas Kilroy (Playwright) Plays include:  THE DEATH AND RESURRECTION OF MR. ROCHE (Dublin Theatre Festival, 1968 and Hampstead Theatre, London); THE O’NEILL (Peacock Theatre, 1969); TEA AND SEX AND SHAKESPEARE (Abbey Theatre, Dublin Theatre Festival, 1976); TALBOT’S BOX (Abbey Theatre, Dublin Theatre Festival, 1977 and Royal Court Theatre, London); DOUBLE CROSS (Field Day Theatre, 1986 and Royal Court Theatre); THE MADAME MacADAM TRAVELLING THEATRE (Field Day Theatre, 1991 and Irish Repertory Theatre, New York); THE SECRET FALL OF CONSTANCE WILDE (Guthrie Theatre, Minneapolis 2008/Bite 2000 International Festival, Barbican Theatre, London/Melbourne International Festival, 1998 and Abbey Theatre, 1997); THE SHAPE OF METAL (Abbey Theatre, Dublin 2003 and Origin Theatre Co, New York 2007).  He has also done versions of Chekhov's SEAGULL (Royal Court Theatre 1981) Ibsen's GHOSTS (Peacock Theatre, Dublin Theatre Festival 1989) and Pirandello's SIX CHARACTERS IN SEARCH OF AN AUTHOR (Abbey Theatre 1996) and HENRY IV (Pittsburgh Irish and Classical Theatre 2005) and CHRIST DELIVER US! (Abbey Theatre, Dublin 2010).

Austin Pendleton (Director) has directed Between Riverside and Crazy, by Stephen Adly Giurgis, now at 2nd Stage and previously at the Atlantic Theatre.  He is in rehearsal at CSC directing Hamlet, starring Peter Sarsgaard.  He recently acted at the Public Theatre in Straight White Men, written and directed by Young Jean Lee.

Lauren Hobbs (Regina) was born and raised in Indianapolis, Indiana.  She would like to thank her parents and 3 siblings for giving her a deep love and appreciation for film and theatre.  She would also like to thank her family for all of their love and for their great sense of humor.  She would like to endlessly thank her teachers: Gary Meyers, Bob Berry, Robert Verlaque, Jackie Bartone, Paige Clements, Jim Demonic, Austin Pendleton, and Mark Blum.  Lauren is dedicating her feelings of highest love, joy and gratitude during this show to her heros, Anne Bancroft and Philip Seymour Hoffmann.

Joseph Stillman (Father Manning) has been in off-off Broadway plays including Ghosts After Ibsen by Thomas Kilroy and directed by Austin Pendleton, Eulogy by Jason Jung, Look Homeward, Angel by Ketti Frings and directed by Austin Pendleton, Fugue for Four Voices by Fred Timm, Blue Chip by Chuck Orsland, Red Peppers by Noel Coward, The Noble Spaniard by Somerset Maugham, The Bear by Anton Chekhov, The Importance of Being Earnest by Oscar Wilde, The Knacker’s ABC by Boris Vian, Legend of Lovers by Jean Anouilh, Tiger at the Gates by Jean Giraudoux, The Race Across the Desert by Bertolt Brecht, Baal by Bertolt Brecht, Shakepeare’s Macbeth and Borstal Boy by Brendan Behan. Film credits include Hi Mom! directed by Brian De Palma. He studies at HB Studio with Austin Pendleton.

Debra Lass (Helen Aylward) Theatre:  Look Homeward Angel directed by Austin Pendleton at the Abingdon; Emerging Artists Eatfest; FringeNYC; Ensemble Studio Theater; American Theater of Actors; La Cucaracha; Whitney Museum’s Music Art and Theater Performance Series; Vineyard Playhouse; Virginia Museum Theater.  TV and Film:  Damages with William Hurt; recurring on the Guiding Light; Onion News Network.  This production of Ghosts after Ibsen was developed in residency at HB Studio.  AEA; SAG/AFTRA  Thanks to HB Studio, the cell and especially to Austin.

Keegan McDonald (Oliver) is very happy to be reprising the role of Oliver in "Ghosts after Ibsen" after the success of the Summer run of the show at HB Studios. He has also played Eugene Gant in Look Homeward, Angel at the Abingdon Theatre and Jelly Beamis in A Loss of Roses at the Arkansas Rep in Little Rock, both of which were directed by Austin Pendleton. Many thanks to Austin, Debra, the cell and the entire cast and crew for making this show possible.

Jim Broaddus (Jack English) has appeared on Broadway, Off-Broadway, regionally and in film, and has performed in numerous commercials, both on-camera and voice-over. Broadway: ROMEO & JULIET, SAINT JOAN, TARTUFFE, 13 RUE DE L’AMOUR. Off-Broadway: TWELFTH NIGHT, RICHARD II. Regional: SHE STOOPS TO CONQUER, THE CONTRAST. Jim holds an MFA in Acting from Temple University.

Greg Petroff (Stage Manager/Assistant Director) received his BA in Theatre from CWRU and his MFA in Acting from Rutgers.  He has stage managed “House of Blue Leaves,” “Relatively Speaking” at Centenary Stage and “Time of Your Life at The Mint.  As an actor, he has been seen in such productions as MacBeth, Julius Caesar and A Midsummer Night's Dream with Gorilla Rep. He is happy to be a part of this production.

What Stuff Costs and Why We Need You

  • Nobody should have to work for free:  $2,500  (director, actors, stage manager, assistant director, crew -- oh, yeah, and producers)
  • Rights to the play -- yes, playwrights deserve to be paid:  $1,050
  • Theater Rental: $7,500 for the cell's lovely ground floor stage on West 23rd St.
  • Rehearsal Space for 24 hours:  $534
  • Printing, copying and all that kind of stuff:  $350
  • Publicity because people need to know about us!  $2,000
  • Insurance $200, gotta have it!
  • Ancillary -- $1,866 -- there's always something.
All tickets will not be more than $18.00!

How to Contribute

Contributors can fund "Ghosts after Ibsen" with any amount  by clicking on the "Contribute Now" button and selecting the amount they would like to contribute.  We gratefully accept any amount.

And guess what?  Your contributions are tax deductible within the extent of the law because we have fiscal sponsorship through Fractured Atlas.  


Risks and Challenges

It's really hard getting plays produced and you rarely make your money back.  That's not why we do it anyway.  But sometimes you just know that the story is one that needs and deserves to be told, so you do it against the odds.  We're just hoping  to break even and if we make a little extra we'll put it toward another production!

Photo Credit:  Vladimir Weinstein  http://www.vladimirweinstein.com

"I was greatly taken by the acting and directing of GHOSTS in the workshop.  Nothing would give me grater pleasure than to see it presented to a larger American audience."  Thomas Kilroy, playwright


"I was completely surprised by Ghosts After Ibsen.  I had never seen this play and it was very provocative, the cast was fantastic, and Austin Pendleton had directed it beautifully."  Delia Ephron 


"Directing Thomas Kilroy's adaptation of Ibsen's Ghosts is one of the most exciting experiences I've had in years.  His play amounts to more than a rethinking of the Ibsen play.   It's a whole new play.  A play about Ireland, a play about the discovery by women in Ireland of their own strength in the 1980s, about AIDS, about Catholicism, about the pain and the chaos and, yes, sometimes even the crazy dark humor that arises from the collision of all those things.  It's beautifully written.  And the cast of this production is astonishing and moving.  I would be thrilled to have it up again so that more people can see it."  Austin Pendleton


    
About Our Company
Thomas Kilroy (Playwright) Plays include:  THE DEATH AND RESURRECTION OF MR. ROCHE (Dublin Theatre Festival, 1968 and Hampstead Theatre, London); THE O’NEILL (Peacock Theatre, 1969); TEA AND SEX AND SHAKESPEARE (Abbey Theatre, Dublin Theatre Festival, 1976); TALBOT’S BOX (Abbey Theatre, Dublin Theatre Festival, 1977 and Royal Court Theatre, London); DOUBLE CROSS (Field Day Theatre, 1986 and Royal Court Theatre); THE MADAME MacADAM TRAVELLING THEATRE (Field Day Theatre, 1991 and Irish Repertory Theatre, New York); THE SECRET FALL OF CONSTANCE WILDE (Guthrie Theatre, Minneapolis 2008/Bite 2000 International Festival, Barbican Theatre, London/Melbourne International Festival, 1998 and Abbey Theatre, 1997); THE SHAPE OF METAL (Abbey Theatre, Dublin 2003 and Origin Theatre Co, New York 2007).  He has also done versions of Chekhov's SEAGULL (Royal Court Theatre 1981) Ibsen's GHOSTS (Peacock Theatre, Dublin Theatre Festival 1989) and Pirandello's SIX CHARACTERS IN SEARCH OF AN AUTHOR (Abbey Theatre 1996) and HENRY IV (Pittsburgh Irish and Classical Theatre 2005) and CHRIST DELIVER US! (Abbey Theatre, Dublin 2010).
Austin Pendleton (Director) has directed Between Riverside and Crazy, by Stephen Adly Giurgis, now at 2nd Stage and previously at the Atlantic Theatre.  He is in rehearsal at CSC directing Hamlet, starring Peter Sarsgaard.  He recently acted at the Public Theatre in Straight White Men, written and directed by Young Jean Lee.
Lauren Hobbs (Regina) was born and raised in Indianapolis, Indiana.  She would like to thank her parents and 3 siblings for giving her a deep love and appreciation for film and theatre.  She would also like to thank her family for all of their love and for their great sense of humor.  She would like to endlessly thank her teachers: Gary Meyers, Bob Berry, Robert Verlaque, Jackie Bartone, Paige Clements, Jim Demonic, Austin Pendleton, and Mark Blum.  Lauren is dedicating her feelings of highest love, joy and gratitude during this show to her heros, Anne Bancroft and Philip Seymour Hoffmann.
Joseph Stillman (Father Manning) has been in off-off Broadway plays including Ghosts After Ibsen by Thomas Kilroy and directed by Austin Pendleton, Eulogy by Jason Jung, Look Homeward, Angel by Ketti Frings and directed by Austin Pendleton, Fugue for Four Voices by Fred Timm, Blue Chip by Chuck Orsland, Red Peppers by Noel Coward, The Noble Spaniard by Somerset Maugham, The Bear by Anton Chekhov, The Importance of Being Earnest by Oscar Wilde, The Knacker’s ABC by Boris Vian, Legend of Lovers by Jean Anouilh, Tiger at the Gates by Jean Giraudoux, The Race Across the Desert by Bertolt Brecht, Baal by Bertolt Brecht, Shakepeare’s Macbeth and Borstal Boy by Brendan Behan. Film credits include Hi Mom! directed by Brian De Palma. He studies at HB Studio with Austin Pendleton.
Debra Lass (Helen Aylward) Theatre:  Look Homeward Angel directed by Austin Pendleton at the Abingdon; Emerging Artists Eatfest; FringeNYC; Ensemble Studio Theater; American Theater of Actors; La Cucaracha; Whitney Museum’s Music Art and Theater Performance Series; Vineyard Playhouse; Virginia Museum Theater.  TV and Film:  Damages with William Hurt; recurring on the Guiding Light; Onion News Network.  This production of Ghosts after Ibsen was developed in residency at HB Studio.  AEA; SAG/AFTRA  Thanks to HB Studio, the cell and especially to Austin.
Keegan McDonald (Oliver) is very happy to be reprising the role of Oliver in "Ghosts after Ibsen" after the success of the Summer run of the show at HB Studios. He has also played Eugene Gant in Look Homeward, Angel at the Abingdon Theatre and Jelly Beamis in A Loss of Roses at the Arkansas Rep in Little Rock, both of which were directed by Austin Pendleton. Many thanks to Austin, Debra, the cell and the entire cast and crew for making this show possible.
Jim Broaddus (Jack English) has appeared on Broadway, Off-Broadway, regionally and in film, and has performed in numerous commercials, both on-camera and voice-over. Broadway: ROMEO & JULIET, SAINT JOAN, TARTUFFE, 13 RUE DE L’AMOUR. Off-Broadway: TWELFTH NIGHT, RICHARD II. Regional: SHE STOOPS TO CONQUER, THE CONTRAST. Jim holds an MFA in Acting from Temple University.
Greg Petroff (Stage Manager/Assistant Director) received his BA 
in Theatre from CWRU and his MFA in Acting from Rutgers.  He has stage 
managed “House of Blue Leaves,” “Relatively Speaking” at Centenary Stage
 and “Time of Your Life at The Mint.  As an actor, he has been seen in 
such productions as MacBeth, Julius Caesar and A Midsummer Night's Dream
 with Gorilla Rep. He is happy to be a part of this production.
What Stuff Costs and Why We Need You

Nobody should have to work for free:  $2,500  (director, actors, stage manager, assistant director, crew -- oh, yeah, and producers)
Rights to the play -- yes, playwrights deserve to be paid:  $1,050
Theater Rental: $7,500 for the cell's lovely ground floor stage on West 23rd St.
Rehearsal Space for 24 hours:  $534
Printing, copying and all that kind of stuff:  $350
Publicity because people need to know about us!  $2,000
Insurance $200, gotta have it!
Ancillary -- $1,866 -- there's always something.

All tickets will not be more than $18.00!

How to Contribute
Contributors can fund "Ghosts after Ibsen" with any amount 
 by clicking on the "Contribute Now" button and selecting the amount 
they would like to contribute.  We gratefully accept any amount.And guess what?  Your contributions are tax deductible within the extent of the law because we have fiscal sponsorship through Fractured Atlas.  


Risks and Challenges It's really hard getting plays produced and you rarely make your money back.  That's not why we do it anyway.  But sometimes you just know that the story is one that needs and deserves to be told, so you do it against the odds.  We're just hoping  to break even and if we make a little extra we'll put it toward another production!
Photo Credit:  Vladimir Weinstein  http://www.vladimirweinstein.com

story:
Hi! I'm Nicolette Romero, a Burlesque performer as well as an artist and designer. I recently won the regionals at the Pittsburgh Burlypicks for the improv. category.   Now i get to go to LA to compete for the world title. Eek! So exciting. Unfortunately, between gas, hotels & travel costs, it's looking to add up to quite a bit. I don't want money to stop me from such an awesome opportunity, so I came up with some pretty rad rewards for contributions as well as a travel log that I will be keeping and updating on my trek.  In addition to the Burlypicks finals in LA i get to stop in two other cities to explore and preform on my way back. I will be uploading pics and stories of all the exciting details of the trip!

If you'd like to support my burlesque championship journey, please donate to my indiegogo campaign. If you have alternate ways you'd like to contribute (hotel rewards points, gas cards, etc) just contact me. 

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/nicoletteromeroart

 Email: Nicoletteromero@hotmail.com 

Link to the performance that won me the title:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uOj5msYx9D8

This performance was all on-the-spot improv. I had to pick a prop (I chose monkey puppet) & once I got on stage I had to pick a theme out of a hat - I got zombie! I didn't know the music until it started & had to make up a performance on the spot!!

Thank you for all your support!

xoxo

Nicolette



*photo credits: Bucket Photography, Miser Photo 
**video credit: Smokin McQueen

story:
About This Project

Live Arts Collaboration, Inc. (a non-profit organization) is producing Ren Gyo Soh's “Butoh Medea” at The Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer. "Butoh Medea" is a project that melds classical Greek tragedy with a contemporary Japanese dance form to create a new genre of performance. It is directed by Brian Rhinehart and received 4 awards at The United Solo Theatre Festival in 2014, including “Best One-Woman Show.” The awards were announced at the festival's closing gala on Sunday, November 23rd, celebrating the 5th Anniversary of the 10-week festival, which presented 130 productions from 6 different continents. 

© Vanessa Teran

Best One-Woman Show

Best Lighting Design

Best Costume Design

Best Choreography

© United solo

Yokko started creating “Butoh Medea” last March, adapting the mythological Medea, and Euripides' tragic dramatization of her story, using the Japanese dance form of Butoh. She started working with co-choreographer Jordan Rosin, costume designer Deepsikha Chaterjee, and lighting designer Derek Van Heel for a workshop of the show in May, 2014. After the first dance workshop, she started working with playwright Sean Michael Welch, who finalized the adaptation. Shortly after that Ren Gyo Soh began editing the play's soundscape and working with director Brian Rhinehart to blend dance and text. 

 

We as a team believe this piece is important as a new form of dramatic art, and needs to be seen by a wider audience, so we decided to bring the show to The Edinburgh Festival this summer. This inter-cultural, collaborative creation that was born in a basement in New York City will now take the world stage!! 

But, to realize this dream, we need your help! Your TAX-FREE donation can make this production possible!

What We Need & Where it goes 

Here is our touring budget! 

Theatre Rental: $3,757.44-

Fringe Registration Fee: $450.49-

Accomodation Fee: $3,500.00-

PR Fee: $3,000-

Transportation: $3,500.00-

---------------------------------------

TOTAL: $15,000 (rounded up)-

The Impact

The awards we received last fall were a huge encouragement for us to keep doing what we are doing. People may know the story of Medea, and may have seen other Medeas onstage, but no one has ever seen a Butoh Medea. Sharing the form of Butoh and Ren Gyo Soh's mission is the key to this project. Your donation will support not only our dream, but will also encourage anyone who is interested in Butoh and dance/theatre in general.

Yokko's Pledge

It is a huge financial and professional risk to take a show to another country, and this festival will be very challenging to me as a performer.  The festival will include 21 shows in 3 weeks—nearly one show everyday. So, every time I perform, I will be drenched in sweat; I will be mentally, physically, emotionally and spiritually exhausted, but I vow to give every ounce of my being to my audience every day. That is my pledge.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word as much as possible, and help us make this show happen!! 

Ren Gyo Soh Official Website

Facebook Page

Twitter

story:
Who are Colla Voce?

  • As a new, emerging theatre group, Colla Voce Theatre has enjoyed great success in the company’s hometown of Sheffield. Having received rave reviews for their production of “The Last Five Years” (“truly remarkable”, 5* - Blunt Cinema) and the Colla Voce Cabaret (“where self derision and sheer fun meet talent and sensitivity”, 5* - Forge Press), they now premiere their first piece of original writing: “Buried: A New Musical” written by Tom Williams and Cordelia O’Driscoll.
  • The company performs musical theatre with a fresh take - they showcase the unusual, the forgotten and the undiscovered. Whether they are producing stories that rarely get told, or stories that have never been told before, Colla Voce Theatre attempts to challenge the conceptions of what musical theatre can be.

What is 'Buried' about?

  • He’s a shy, seemingly-average young professional. She’s a sarcastic thrill-seeker. After matching on an online dating service, this young and fun-loving couple form a unique relationship when they discover something special that they have in common: they’re both serial killers.
  • “Buried: A New Musical” tells the story of these exceptional characters as they join forces, setting out on a trail of deception and murder whilst simultaneously attempting to navigate their way through the world of normal, adult relationships. Combining a beautiful, folk-inspired score and a bitingly funny script, this new musical puts a bloody spin on the traditional rom-com, examining the world of relationships when pushed to its extremes.

Your donations help to fund the show!

  • Putting on a show at the Edinburgh Fringe will be invaluable to our company in terms of exposure, especially with our first ever original musical, however the costs are high.
  • With all of the incredible talent involved, it would be a shame if we weren't performing the best possible version of the show, and your donation can help us reach this goal! We need to raise enough money to cover technical costs (such as microphones, costuming and set) and also venue hire.
  • By donating towards 'Buried', you're investing in an emerging theatre company with a lot of potential. You're also eligible for some of our fantastic perks, such as an original song written for you by the show's writers, or having a character in 'Buried' named after you!

Having received rave reviews for their production of “The Last Five Years” (“truly remarkable”, 5* - Blunt Cinema) and the Colla Voce Cabaret (“where self derision and sheer fun meet talent and sensitivity”, 5* - Forge Press), they now premiere their first piece of original writing: “Buried: A New Musical” written by Tom Williams and Cordelia O’Driscoll.
