story:
Javotte est la nouvelle création de notre collectif Les Casseroles. Du 25 mars au 11 avril 2015, nous présenterons en codiffusion avec le Théâtre Denise-Pelletier, l'adaptation théâtrale du roman Javotte de l'écrivain Simon Boulerice. Cette création est orchestrée par le metteur en scène Jean-Guy Legault qui signe aussi l'étonnante adaptation scénique. Voici l'antépisode moderne du conte de Cendrillon du point vue de la méchante demi-soeur, Javotte. Située dans une petite ville au sud de Montréal, cette fable révèle les états d'âme de la moche et abjecte Javotte, aux désirs de vengeance inassouvis.

Nous nous sommes entourés d'une équipe de concepteurs chevronnés pour donner lieu à une vision précise de l'oeuvre scénique : Julie-Ange Breton à la scénographie et aux costumes, Mathieu Marcil aux éclairages, Navet Confit à la conception musicale et Mariflore Véronneau à l'assistance à la mise en scène. Nous, les cinq membres de la compagnies (Valérie Dumas, Caroline Gendron, Marc-Antoine Larche, Lyne Lefort et Émilie-Lune Sauvé) faisons partie de la distribution de la pièce ainsi que Gabrielle Côté dans le rôle de Javotte.

Créé bien avant le soulèvement populaire du Printemps érable et formé en majeure partie de finissants en interprétation de l'École Nationale de Théâtre, le Collectif les   Casseroles fait du bruit depuis 2008. En adaptant nos divers matériaux artistiques à la scène de théâtre et faisant de cette scène le lieu des rencontres inattendues, nous favorisons l'émergence d'une prise de parole actuelle et audacieuse. Nous jonglons entre l'absurde, le comique et le dramatique, provoquant des ruptures et des variations de rythme, à la recherche de ludisme, de fraîcheur et d'une parole spontanée, parfois crue et criante comme celle de Javotte.

Nous sollicitions votre générosité pour donner à cette ambitieuse production les moyens de prendre son envol. Pour permettre à nos concepteurs de créer librement, nous avons besoin de votre aide financière. Elle sera utile pour payer les matériaux en lien avec la fabrication du décor et des costumes et pour défrayer les frais des équipements techniques nécessaires à la production. Tout montant supplémentaire sera investi dans la promotion du spectacle.

Le projet du Collectif les Casseroles en est un des plus emballants et toute l'équipe espère avoir la chance de le réaliser dans les meilleures conditions de création possible. Merci pour votre aide!

Le Collectif les Casseroles 

Valérie Dumas, Caroline Gendron, Marc-Antoine Larche, Lyne Lefort et Émilie-Lune Sauvé

story:
We don't need a theater to put on a play, but we do need your help!

We are bringing David Auburn's Pulitzer Prize-winning play Proof to Pottstown, PA -- yep, that's a lot of p's.  Here's one more:  we're staging it on an actual porch of a beautiful country home called Sycamore Hill. We're lucky to have access to the venue, which has the perfect porch to serve as our "stage." This site-specific approach will save costs while helping us mount this touching play in an accessible way and get up-close-and-personal with a whole new audience.   

And why not?  Site-specific theater helps actors and other theater artists crack open fresh opportunities to perform and create for the benefit of themselves, their communities, AND their audiences. That's our goal.  

We're calling ourselves Theater with a View and hoping this will be the start of something new, something exciting and inspiring and invigorating, something that will let us bring more theater to audiences. . .outside of the theater!

But for right now. . .

We need your help!  And we've got some fun perks lined up to show our gratitude.

We are keeping our production slim and trim, but we aim to raise $5,000 to help cover unavoidable costs, including:
  • Production of promotional materials: Help us build our audience by letting them know we're here!  Posters, postcards, postage (more p's). . . these are the building blocks of our outreach to the local community . 
  • Equipment rentals: lights, lighting gear, and other technical equipment
  • Paying our actors. . . and our crew: We have a cast of professional actors who are already doing this more for their hearts and for their audiences than for a paycheck. They are sacrificing other opportunities in NY to work together and create something fresh together.
  • Travel: Getting our cast and crew from New York to Pennsylvania and home again.
  • Feeding the cast and crew 
  • Fees: for the rights to perform the play
  • Chairs, a port-a-potty, other "site-specific" amenity rentals: For all the benefits of using a site-specific space instead of a theater, it also presents some equally specific challenges and needs!

Our Cast (& director, too) 

Our cast of actors are Nina Covalesky as Catherine, Matthew Dunivan as Hal, Michael Hajek as Robert and Jessica Myhr as Claire. Seth Reich is our fearless leader, our director.  All of our actors are members of Actors' Equity Association.  Each of us has worked with at least one of the others before and we are proud and excited to be working together one and all now.

The Play

Proof  won a Pulitzer, did we mention?  And a Tony.  And buckets of other awards.  But awards aren't the point. And neither is math, frankly, though we love the mathematical specifics peppered throughout Proof that give us a crystal clear sense of the characters and their stakes. David Auburn's gem of a play is populated with mathematicians and the people that love them -- but at it's core it's a well-told story about family, the interplay between genius and mental instability, self-worth, and the relationships that define us.  

    No Money?  No Problem! Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't help Theater with a View and our production of Proof financially right now?  Not a problem!  

    You can still lend an invaluable hand by sharing this campaign, spreading the word, and helping us build our audience.  Facebook, Twitter, emails, word of mouth, smoke signals--- all are pieces of the big ole helpful pie.  We will be grateful for any and all of it. 

    And, of course. . . you can always just come see Proof and share the experience with us.  

    Thank you!

Thank you!

story:
BONES IN THE BASKET is going OFF BROADWAY! And you can be a part of it, because we can’t do it without you!

BONES IN THE BASKET, first developed at the Yale Cabaret, has been offered a production at the American Theatre for Actors as part of the Araca Project!  This is our chance to share this remarkable show with a much wider audience, and we are asking for your support!



OUR SHOW:

BONES IN THE BASKET is an evening of Russian fairy tales.  In this vodka-fueled theatrical event, a penniless troupe of Russian storytellers invade your theatre to try and earn their supper.  They flirt and tease; they revel in the gypsy punk stylings of their mysterious one-man band; and all the while wooing the audience with their renditions of riotously morbid Russian fairy tales that are not interested in “happily ever after.”

WARNING:  these peformers will flirt with you.  They may offer you a drink.  They may invite you onstage (or backstage).  They may try and kiss you.  No matter what, the management takes NO responsibility for loss of wallets, kidneys (put some ice on it), or hearts.

Learn more at:  www.bonesinthebasket.com



OUR HISTORY:

BONES IN THE BASKET was first developed at the Yale Cabaret in 2009.  It was the first production for a group of young collaborators who would go on to create a number performances together over the years, both at Yale School of Drama and as professional theatre artists.

Now, we are all working theatre professionals, mostly living in New York City, and we return to this piece because it remains the touchstone production for our ensemble.  It encapsulates our collective voice, our love of storytelling and theatre, and what art can offer human beings.

The stories we are pulling from are dark. These fairy tales were being told at a time of social and political upheaval in rural Russia, just after the revolution and the world wars. These stories are not the simple morality tales that one expects from Hans Christian Andersen or the Grimm Brothers.  Instead, they are bloody, morbid, paradoxical stories where darkness and evil often triumph, and although innocence and kindness are often praised, cleverness and guile are ultimately rewarded.  These are stories about the step from childhood to maturity—the moment when innocence is lost, and in that loss, how we learn to survive.

But in that recognition of loss, BONES IN THE BASKET captures something vital, for although these fairy tales are dark and morbid, they are not depressing. The very act of telling these stories becomes a triumph.

Through storytelling, the troupe learns to survive. It is the choice to greet the inevitability of loss and death not with defeat, but with a smile.

OUR ENSEMBLE…



What makes Bones in the Basket truly unique is the ensemble of artists from whence it was born.  Both onstage and off, this is a remarkable band of misfits.  We all met during our first year at the Yale School of Drama, and Bones was the production that let us escape grad school and find in each other an artistic community.  It has been the touchstone for us all for years now, the reason that even as our careers develop, we keep returning to this ensemble and in particular to this very special show.

PRODUCTION STAFF:

Devin Brain, Director / Producer

Lindsey Turteltaub, Producer

Tara Kayton, Producer

Alexandra Henrikson, Creator / Producer

Tanya Dean, Dramaturg

Michael McQuilken, Composer / Performer

Meredith Ries, Scenic Designer

Valérie T. Bart, Costume Designer

Alan Edwards, Lighting Designer

Ken Goodwin, Sound Designer

Brandon Curtis, Production Manager

Kirsten Parker, Stage Manager


ENSEMBLE:

Daniel Binstock, Performer

Stephanie Hayes, Performer

Alexandra Henrikson, Performer

Blake Segal, Performer

Jillian Taylor, Performer


DEVISING ENSEMBLE

Daniel Binstock, Tanya Dean, Dipika Guha, Stephanie Hayes, Alexandra Henrikson, Ben Horner, Irene Sofia Lucio, Blake Segal

To learn more about our ensemble, or perhaps just to take a look at their beautiful pictures, take a look at:  http://www.bonesinthebasket.com/castandcreative.html



AND THEN THERE IS YOU:

Where does this leave you? Well, we are asking for your support for Bones in the Basket because although the Araca Group has supported this project, we still need to raise a great deal of money to put this show up again.

PRODUCING IN NYC:

New York City is one of the most vibrant theatrical cities in the world; it is also one of the most expensive cities in the world, and producing theatre here is both difficult and costly.  Your donations go directly to support the artists making this production.  Our hope is that this presentation of Bones will be a stepping-stone; a chance to finish the show’s development and then share it with an audience who are capable of helping it find further life.  And you can be a vital part of that.

Over the next two months we will be striving to raise $20,000 for this production.  That is a lot, but all of it is carefully considered to make this the best possible production.

WHAT YOUR DONATION PAYS FOR:

Paying the Artists Involved:  our first priority is to pay the artists. We are primarily investing the funds of the production not in objects but in people, because the theatre is an art that can celebrate humanity. And the first step of that is celebrating the talent and skill of the theatremakers.
    • $50 pays for an electrician to hang our lights
    • $250 pays for an actor to work for a week
    • $1,000 pays for our composer
Materials for the Design:  after the people comes the stuff.  Theatre is a tangible art form, and although our show is designed to be carried through Russia in a trunk, there are still a lot of costumes, lights, and birch trees to buy.
    • $50 pays for one base costume
    • $100 pays for an array of fantastic masks
    • $500 pays for the rental of the sound equipment we need
Rehearsal Space:  anyone that has tried to find an apartment in New York City knows that space is at a premium here, and space to rehearse a play is no different.  This is a significant expense, and depending on location and size of the room rehearsal space can easily be $25 / hr.
    • $50 pays for 2 hours of rehearsal space
    • $100 pays for half a day of rehearsal space
    • $500 pays for about a week of rehearsal space
Misc. (insurance, photocopies, trucks, etc):  getting those actors onto a stage is a strangely complicated process with hours of labour and admin happening offstage. Producing a show is filled with additional expenses like insurance, truck rental to move sets and lights, and paper(which must be like white gold because man, is photocopying a script expensive!).
    • $50 covers printing scripts for the cast and crew
    • $100 pays for transporting set and lights to the space
    • $500 pays for insurance for the rehearsal period


WHAT WE CAN OFFER YOU:

Our heartfelt thanks, and the chance to see a unique piece of theatre.  Yes, but what else?  Each level of perk to the right offers its own unique package of rewards, but in general:
    • All Donations are Tax-Deductible!
    • All donations receive recognition in our program, on our website, and on social media
At various levels of donation you can also get:
    • Invitations to Rehearsals and Private Events
    • Signed Pictures of the Cast
    • Recordings of the songs in the show
    • Tickets and Reserved seating at the performances
    • Pesonalized updates from the Director and Cast
    • Dinner with the Creative Team

And of course, with all of these perks we are trying, in some small way at least, to express our gratitude in your support of this piece, and our work, because we appreciate it more than we can probably ever say.



RISKS AND CHALLENGES:

Producing theatre in NYC is a risk, there’s no denying that.  People have broken their bank accounts, their hearts, and their bodies making theatre in this city, and they will continue to do so.

That risk is part of the drive to do it. Risk is the price of beauty.

But, our team is working hard to minimize our risks.  We have gathered together a remarkable group of artists, each of whom is a seasoned theatrical professional with years of experience.  We have artists who have worked in every level of the theatre both nationally and internationally, and we have a show that is born of their voices and their hearts.  That combination of skill, talent, and passion is our shield against the risk, and we are confident that in October Bones in the Basket is going to be a remarkable show.



OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

First and foremost:  come and see the show!  All of this is moot if you don’t get a chance to see this piece, because this is live theatre and it is all about the evanescent connection in the moment.  So, come and join us October 8 – 12 at the American Theatre for Actors (tickets on sale soon).

Tell your friends about the show and this campaign:
    • Like posts associated with BONES IN THE BASKET
    • Share this funding link on social media:  https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bones-in-the-basket
    • Send people to our website:  www.bonesinthebasketcom

And the last way you can help:  share your thoughts with us.  You can email us, Facebook message us, comment on us, find us after a show…we would love to hear what you think about the campaign, the site, and Bones in the Basket.

We can’t wait for October, and we hope to see you all at the show!
story_txt:
BONES IN THE BASKET
is going OFF BROADWAY!
And you can be a part
of it, because we can’t do it without you!

BONES IN THE BASKET, first developed at the Yale Cabaret,
has been offered a production at the American Theatre for Actors as part of the
Araca Project!  This is our chance to share this remarkable show with a much
wider audience, and we are asking for your support!
OUR SHOW:

BONES IN THE BASKET is an evening of Russian fairy tales.  In this vodka-fueled theatrical event, a penniless
troupe of Russian storytellers invade your theatre to try and earn their
supper.  They flirt and tease; they revel
in the gypsy punk stylings of their mysterious one-man band; and all the while
wooing the audience with their renditions of riotously morbid Russian fairy tales
that are not interested in “happily ever after.”
WARNING:  these
peformers will flirt with you.  They may
offer you a drink.  They may invite you
onstage (or backstage).  They may try and
kiss you.  No matter what, the management
takes NO responsibility for loss of wallets, kidneys (put some ice on it), or
hearts.
Learn more at: 
www.bonesinthebasket.com



OUR HISTORY:


BONES IN THE
BASKET was first developed at the Yale Cabaret in 2009.  It was the first production for a group of
young collaborators who would go on to create a number performances together
over the years, both at Yale School of Drama and as professional theatre
artists.
Now, we are
all working theatre professionals, mostly living in New York City, and we
return to this piece because it remains the touchstone production for our
ensemble.  It encapsulates our collective
voice, our love of storytelling and theatre, and what art can offer human
beings. 
The stories
we are pulling from are dark. These fairy tales were being told at a time of
social and political upheaval in rural Russia, just after the revolution and
the world wars. These stories are not the simple morality tales that one
expects from Hans Christian Andersen or the Grimm Brothers.  Instead, they are bloody, morbid, paradoxical
stories where darkness and evil often triumph, and although innocence and
kindness are often praised, cleverness and guile are ultimately rewarded.  These are stories about the step from
childhood to maturity—the moment when innocence is lost, and in that loss, how we
learn to survive. 
But in that
recognition of loss, BONES IN THE BASKET captures something vital, for although
these fairy tales are dark and morbid, they are not depressing. The very act of
telling these stories becomes a triumph. 
Through
storytelling, the troupe learns to survive. It is the choice to greet the
inevitability of loss and death not with defeat, but with a smile.




OUR ENSEMBLE…
What
makes Bones in the Basket truly
unique is the ensemble of artists from whence it was born.  Both onstage and off, this is a remarkable
band of misfits.  We all met during our
first year at the Yale School of Drama, and Bones
was the production that let us escape grad school and find in each other an
artistic community.  It has been the
touchstone for us all for years now, the reason that even as our careers
develop, we keep returning to this ensemble and in particular to this very
special show.
PRODUCTION STAFF:
Devin Brain, Director / Producer
Lindsey Turteltaub, Producer
Tara Kayton, Producer
Alexandra Henrikson, Creator / Producer
Tanya Dean, Dramaturg
Michael McQuilken, Composer / Performer
Meredith Ries, Scenic Designer

Valérie T. Bart, Costume Designer
Alan Edwards, Lighting Designer
Ken Goodwin, Sound Designer
Brandon Curtis, Production Manager
Kirsten Parker, Stage Manager
ENSEMBLE:
Daniel Binstock, Performer
Stephanie Hayes, Performer
Alexandra Henrikson, Performer
Blake Segal, Performer
Jillian Taylor, Performer

DEVISING ENSEMBLE
Daniel Binstock, Tanya Dean, Dipika Guha, Stephanie Hayes, Alexandra Henrikson, Ben Horner, Irene Sofia Lucio, Blake Segal
To learn more about our ensemble, or perhaps just to take a
look at their beautiful pictures, take a look at:  http://www.bonesinthebasket.com/castandcreative.html






AND THEN THERE IS YOU:





Where does this leave you? Well, we are asking for your support for Bones in the Basket because although the Araca Group has
supported this project, we still need to raise a great deal of money to put
this show up again.
PRODUCING IN NYC:
New York City is one of the most vibrant theatrical cities
in the world; it is also one of the most expensive cities in the world, and
producing theatre here is both difficult and costly.  Your donations go directly to support the
artists making this production.  Our hope
is that this presentation of Bones will
be a stepping-stone; a chance to finish the show’s development and then share it
with an audience who are capable of helping it find further life.  And you can be a vital part of that.
Over the next two months we will be striving to raise
$20,000 for this production.  That is a
lot, but all of it is carefully considered to make this the best possible
production.
WHAT YOUR DONATION PAYS FOR:
Paying
the Artists Involved:  our first
priority is to pay the artists. We are primarily investing the funds of the
production not in objects but in people, because the theatre is an art that can
celebrate humanity. And the first step of that is celebrating the talent and
skill of the theatremakers.

$50 pays for an electrician to hang our lights

$250 pays for an actor to work for a week

$1,000 pays for our composer


Materials for the Design:  after the people comes the stuff.  Theatre is a tangible art form, and although
our show is designed to be carried through Russia in a trunk, there are still a
lot of costumes, lights, and birch trees to buy.

$50 pays for one base costume

$100 pays for an array of fantastic masks

$500 pays for the rental of the sound equipment
we need



Rehearsal
Space:  anyone that has tried to find an
apartment in New York City knows that space is at a premium here, and space to
rehearse a play is no different.  This is
a significant expense, and depending on location and size of the room rehearsal
space can easily be $25 / hr.

$50 pays
for 2 hours of rehearsal space


$100 pays
for half a day of rehearsal space


$500 pays
for about a week of rehearsal space



Misc.
(insurance, photocopies, trucks, etc):  getting those
actors onto a stage is a strangely complicated process with hours of labour and
admin happening offstage. Producing a show is filled with additional expenses
like insurance, truck rental to move sets and lights, and paper(which must be
like white gold because man, is photocopying a script expensive!).

$50 covers printing scripts for the cast and
crew

$100 pays for transporting set and lights to the
space

$500 pays for insurance for the rehearsal period




WHAT WE CAN OFFER YOU:
Our heartfelt thanks, and the chance to see a unique piece
of theatre.  Yes, but what else?  Each level of perk to the right offers its own unique
package of rewards, but in general:

All Donations are Tax-Deductible!

All donations receive recognition in our
program, on our website, and on social media

At various levels of donation you can also get:

Invitations to Rehearsals and Private Events

Signed Pictures of the Cast

Recordings of the songs in the show

Tickets and Reserved seating at the performances

Pesonalized updates from the Director and Cast


Dinner with the Creative Team



And of course, with all of these perks we are trying, in
some small way at least, to express our gratitude in your support of this
piece, and our work, because we appreciate it more than we can probably ever say.

Producing theatre in NYC is a risk, there’s no denying
that.  People have broken their bank
accounts, their hearts, and their bodies making theatre in this city, and they
will continue to do so.
That risk is part of the drive to do it. Risk is the price
of beauty.
But, our team is working hard to minimize our risks.  We have gathered together a remarkable group
of artists, each of whom is a seasoned theatrical professional with years of
experience.  We have artists who have
worked in every level of the theatre both nationally and internationally, and
we have a show that is born of their voices and their hearts.  That combination of skill, talent, and
passion is our shield against the risk, and we are confident that in October Bones in the Basket is going to be a
remarkable show.





OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

First and foremost: 
come and see the show!  All of
this is moot if you don’t get a chance to see this piece, because this is live
theatre and it is all about the evanescent connection in the moment.  So, come and join us October 8 – 12 at the
American Theatre for Actors (tickets on sale soon).
Tell your friends about the show and this campaign:


Like posts associated with BONES IN THE BASKET
Share this funding link on social media:  https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bones-in-the-basket
Send people to our website:  www.bonesinthebasketcom

And the last way you can help:  share your thoughts with us.  You can email us, Facebook message us,
comment on us, find us after a show…we would love to hear what you think about
the campaign, the site, and Bones in the
Basket.
We can’t wait for October, and we hope to see you all at the show!

story:
Short Summary

Kate Kaminski was a high school drama nerd who took a long detour to the road to PortFringe 2019. Kate has been making films in Maine since 1990 but for the past few years she’s been dreaming about bringing her particular style of narrative and cinematic sensibility to live performance. When her long time project Bluestocking Film Series closed in 2018, Kate began teaching on-camera acting workshops and reconnected with her secret desire to write and direct for live audiences.

Thus was the idea for "Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon" born in late fall 2018. Borrowing (with gratitude) from the title of one of her favorite films — "Séance on a Wet Afternoon" — it became clear that it was time to commit to making something happen. With some great actors on board, and with acceptance to PortFringe, the long-desired live performance project has come together. (More about the actors below.)

This crowdfunding campaign aims to raise funds that will allow us to elevate the visual style of “Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon through production design (set, props, wardrobe, hair & makeup) as well as through audience-interactive elements (shhh….more details about those elements coming soon). We also intend to pay our actors and small crew (artists deserve to be paid for their talents!).

By backing our campaign, you not only join us on our journey, you’ll help us create A Total Experience. We want our audiences to feel like they’re attending a real séance, although one that’s slowly going hilariously off the rails.

Will you join us?

 

What is "Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon" about?

"Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon" satirizes cultural appropriation, the self-promotional obsession of online life, online hookups, and the need we all have to believe in something...beyond. Embedded within the audience, the séance gets awkward right away as subterranean jealousies surface and a couple on a first date get disruptive. But when contact with THE FUTURE appears to be happening, and the messages aren’t what anybody is expecting, everything falls into chaos.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re budgeting $3,000 to create the most exciting and artful production and graphic/motion design possible and to pay our onstage performers. This will pay for:

  • Furniture and props (rental / purchase)
  • Production design + hair/makeup services
  • Wardrobe (rental / purchase)
  • Graphic, motion + promotional writing and design services
  • Interactive elements printing/fabrication costs
  • Performers in front of the audience (and crew behind the scenes)

When you back our campaign, you can choose from a variety of levels of support. And here are some of the exciting perks* we have in store for you.

  • Social media shout with a special "psychic prediction" just for you
  • Video thank you from cast members
  • Handmade friendship bracelet imbued with psychic protection
  • A beautiful full-color Protection Disk
  • Meet The Psychics Happy Hour on Us
  • Printed thank you in our PortFringe 2019 program

If we don’t fully meet our funding goal, we will make compromises where we have to, but will strive to make “Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon” look just as great as if we were fully funded.

The Impact

One of the most promising aspects of this venture into live performance is the opportunity to combine theatrical and cinematic conventions in an immersive and interactive experience for the performers and audience alike. As a hybrid, our project is part of a spectrum of immersive experiences that are on the cutting edge of next wave entertainment.

As women makers, we have faced a lot of barriers and we’ve dealt with those barriers by going around them, taking the long way, and most often doing it ourselves. We are boldly going where we haven’t been before because that is the way artists grow. We’re still growing. We hope you’ll journey with us as we continue to evolve and create new forms of audience-based work.

Risks & Challenges

Time is one of the biggest challenges we’ll face. PortFringe takes place from June 13–22 and our show opens on June 15, so we don’t have a huge amount of time to design this production and gather the materials necessary to make it shine. But we have proven many times before that we have the resources, ties within the community, and sheer determination to make impossible things happen. We’re confident that we’ll get it all done in time and on budget as we always have.

Though we call ourselves risk takers, there is very little risk that we won’t succeed in putting on a memorable show. That’s how we roll.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute funding, that doesn't mean you can't be part of “Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon.”

If you can give us a shout on your social media and share our campaign, you’re on the team! Don’t forget to use Indiegogo’s sharing tools — it’s easy, fast, and delicious. Yes, delicious sharing tools! Indiegogo’s got them!

Creative Team

Gitgo Production — Who We Are

Kate Kaminski and Betsy Carson formed Gitgo Productions in the early aughts and have been collaborating on film projects since 1994. Having produced four DIY feature films and dozens of short documentary and narrative films, the duo has worked with many of the most talented crew people and actors in Maine and have screened their work across the globe. Their improv comedy web series “Willard Beach” was the first made in Maine and ran for 53 episodes from 2009-2010.

Kate Kaminski (Writer-Director)

Any performance depends upon the dynamic collaboration between actors. Meet the actors of "Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon" (in alphabetical order)

Paul Drinan (Jake Logan/Jāquan LaKwanda)

Survivor of both coasts and now loving Maine.

Your cosmic connection to the Rich and Famous.

Sophie Hill (Rose Slade)

Humbled and excited to be a part of this project, this is Sophie’s first appearance in the PortFringe Festival! An interdisciplinary performance artist with a background in dance, theater and costume design, she is drawn to pieces that carry elements of comedy and satire, while exposing truths that push limits and boundaries. “Unmasking cultural appropriation AND delving into the afterlife?!? Yes Please.”

Call me "The Cat."

Reggie Burrows Hodges (Michael)

Multi-hyphenate man of mystery

"What's a smart attractive guy like myself doing without your phone number?"

Sheila Jackson (Tonya)

Fringe Fest Freashman

Animal lover and mom to rescues including 3 dogs (2 with specials needs), a deaf cat, and a goldfish. Actively seeking love and swiping right.

Christine Louise Marshall (Honor Gale, Ghosthunter)

Christine Louise Marshall would like to thank all the women who were unable to make this role fit their schedules, thus allowing her to work with such a kickass team of stone freaks.

Ripping the mask off frauds and fakes everywhere using my cutting-edge, high-tech paranormal research equipment and finely-tuned nose for b.s.!

Scott Mullenberg (Leslie Seeman)

How many bookbinders do you know who also act?

Receiving messages from The Other Side with the help of his faithful spirit guide, Origami.

Kerry Rasor (Jayne Nixon)

Kerry is so exited to be back at Fringe!  She lives in Kinney Shores with her two teens and enjoys square dancing, scrap booking and contract bridge.

Five eighteen eighty!

Meet the Crew

Thomas Puckett (Graphic and Motion Design)

The spirits compelled me to contribute my dark (graphic) arts to this phenomenal group of misfits. I have spent many years reading my clients’ minds so I felt especially suited to participate in this otherworldly event.

Connie-Marie Puckett (Second Unit Writing)

I’m a writer for Motion House Road, a small creative studio located in Cape Elizabeth, Maine. I was born under the sign of Taurus with a Taurus moon in the year of the Ox. Do not look into my eyes. My powers are legion!

----------------------------------------------

*Disclaimer: "Séance on a Tuesday Afternoon" is a work of fiction and any "psychic predictions" associated with our perks for this crowdfunding campaign (or otherwise) are intended for entertainment purposes only.

story:
Un peu plus sur le projet…

Boris Vian chante Juste le temps de vivre, alors que je me  pourvoie de cette urgence de le raconter. Valsant aux abords du gouffre de ma vulnérabilité, je me lance dans l’écriture d’une pièce de théâtre afin de démystifier les méandres du deuil. Célébrant la vie avec douce folie, ce récit se veut être une ode aux bêtes que nous sommes et à notre volonté de survivre à ce qui tue.

***

Qu'il est bon de goûter aux joies de la création, mais cela a un prix ! Voilà pourquoi je fais appel à vous et à votre générosité pour donner vie à ce tendre balbutiement. 

Tous les fonds amassés serviront à assurer les coûts pour l'exécution de cette résidence (per diem, frais de transport,  production (soutien technique, visuels, publicité...etc).

Je vous remercie d'avoir pris le temps de me lire et de contribuer à ce projet qui me tient tant à coeur. Si l'envie vous prend de partager cette page, je vous en serai très reconnaissante ! 

Mille mercis

Valsant aux abords du gouffre de ma vulnérabilité, je me lance dans l’écriture d’une pièce de théâtre afin de démystifier les méandres du deuil. Célébrant la vie avec douce folie, ce récit se veut être une ode aux bêtes que nous sommes et à notre volonté de survivre à ce qui tue.***Qu'il est bon de goûter aux joies de la création, mais cela a un prix ! Voilà pourquoi je fais appel à vous et à votre générosité pour donner vie à ce tendre balbutiement. Tous les fonds amassés serviront à assurer les coûts pour l'exécution de cette résidence (per diem, frais de transport,  production (soutien technique, visuels, publicité...etc).Je vous remercie d'avoir pris le temps de me lire et de contribuer à ce projet qui me tient tant à coeur. Si l'envie vous prend de partager cette page, je vous en serai très reconnaissante ! Mille mercis

story:
Hampstead's History

Founded in 1983,  the non-profit touring children's theatre, The Hampstead Stage Company, began its mission of bringing classic literature to life! Every year Hampstead performs over 2,000 shows for children all across the nation. We've performed for well-over 21,000,000 audience members, and now we need your help expanding in order to reach an audience base that often gets forgotten about, young adults. 


Our Mission

The Young Adult Series is will be the new branch of tour we are launching this October. We are sending out a team of two actors (like all of our shows!) to perform an adaptation of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein at various middle schools, high schools, and theatres across the New England area. With your help this new branch of tour will be a hit, and eventually will expand to multiple teams performing nationwide.


How You Can Help

We are hoping that with your donation we can work with places like Portable Scenery to design and craft some of the stage elements that are both visually stunning and durable so we can use them for future tours. Check out the breakdown: 

The Perks!

  • Your voice in the show 
  • VIP ticket to one of our performances
  • Your support donates one of our shows to a place of your choosing! 
  • An annotated edition of Bernie Wrightson's illustrated copy of Frankenstein from our director Austen. Click HERE to see how cool it is!
There's a bunch of other fantastic perks, too. Check them out!

The Impact

Here at Hampstead, we know that the future is dependent upon the next generation. Funding for the arts in schools have been drastically cut over the past decade, and now, more than ever, young adults are entering "the real world" without ever seeing a performance. Our aim isn't to inspire young adults to become artists (if so, great!)- We are hoping that exposure to theatre at this time in their life will help create an even more open-minded culture and nation. With your help we are creating a production that will spark conversation about the classics and current topics in relation to this show and art in general. 


Will It Work?

This isn't our first time creating a new branch of tours. Back in 2009, we found a way to reach even more children by creating a Summer season that focused on performing at Libraries. This tour is now our largest and most successful season. 

However, the Young Adult Series is an even bigger and bolder venture than creating our summer season. Instead of sticking with our same formula like we did in the Summer, we're breaking the mold by building a brand new style of set, adding sound for the first time, and venturing into a new venue: High Schools.

High Schools devote less money and time to the arts these days, which make performing at these venues difficult. This is why we need your help with donations, so we cut costs down for our shows and donate our shows to communities in need.   


Other Ways You Can Help

No donation, no problem! Here's some other ways you can help out our cause:

  • Spread the word! Use one of the tools at the top to share on social media and via email! 
  • Let us know if there are any schools or theatres that would be interested in having a performance. We're looking at expanding beyond New England like our other tours, and we'd love to give back to your community. 
  • See a show! Keep your eyes out for our Summer shows in your area, and bring your family to watch the performance. We'd love to share what we are passionate about with you.

Thank you for your time, and we look forward to this creation of Frankenstein!

story:
We are a group of female-identifying artists seeking to creating feminist art. 

 

ABOUT THIS PLAY

After freshman Joni joins sorority Theta Beta, she learns that sisterhood means more than the colors you wear. Accompanied by her troubled best friend Kate, Joni spirals down a rabbit hole of bulimia dream ballets, Bachelor restoration comedies, and Dirty Disney ragers. Confronted with a world that confounds her expectations, Joni forces all the members of Theta Beta to ask: what do women owe other women? Period Sisters, a 2018 O’Neill finalist, creates a searing portrait of life as a young, 21st century woman. A fierce new voice in the American theater, playwright Ali Viterbi mixes fun with fury, creating the feminist theater you didn’t know you needed.

 

SUPPORT THIS PLAY

Creating feminist art means paying female-identifying artists a living wage.

Too often we've all been told that we should work for the exposure, for the credit, or for the art. But this attitude undercuts the value of artists' time, talent, and unique skillset.

With your help, we can compensate our artists at the level that they deserve.

  • A $25 pledge will enable us to pay for one artist's travel.
  • A $50 pledge will enable us to hire a production assistant.
  • A $100 pledge will enable us to hire additional labor to build our set.
  • A $250 pledge will enable us to support an early career stage manager.
  • A $500 pledge will enable us to fully realize the costume design.
  • A $1000 pledge will enable us to compensate the lead artists for their time and labor.

Any pledge you make goes directly to supporting feminist art, and the female-identifying artists who create it.

story:
This year marks Best Kind Productions’ seventh season and a truly exciting moment for our company: our first original musical in full production.  Kyle McDavid, founder and Co-Artistic Director of Best Kind Productions, started work several years ago on writing a musical about John Murray Anderson, a St. John’s native who went on to incredible success in theatre, including producing on Broadway.  After a reading at the LSPU Hall in December of 2015, a workshop at the Barbara Barrett Theatre in September of 2016, and months of development through Kyle fine-tuning the script and investigating and exploring in rehearsals with some of the area’s best musical theatre actors, we are bringing the world premiere production of Impresario to the stage at the LSPU Hall this May as a part of the RCA Presentation Series.

 

We couldn’t be more excited about sharing this production with an audience.  And as our first original musical, and being about such a brilliant individual, we want it to be as vibrant and bigger-than-life as it possibly can be, just like John Murray Anderson himself.

 

In order to do that, we are seeking additional funding from generous supporters like you.  Your donation to our production will help us create a beautiful and exciting set; to rent high quality equipment to make this never-before-heard score sound fun and fantastic; and to engage for our production some of the area’s best and brightest actors, musicians, designers, and technicians.  Your generous donation will go directly towards making this show that exciting, energized, heartfelt, and hilarious story that we know it can be.

 

And your donation could come with some great perks, including autographed programs, posters, scripts, and even meet and greets with the cast and a behind-the-scenes look at rehearsals.

We hope you’ll consider helping us to make this show the brilliant, fully original theatrical experience we know it can be.

 

The show takes place May 18th -20th at the LSPU Hall, as part of the Resource Centre for the Arts season.  Tickets are available at http://rca.nf.ca/event/impresario-2/ or by calling the box office at 753-4531.

 

Music, Lyrics and Book by Kyle McDavid
Directed by Timothy Matson
Produced by Best Kind Productions
Presented by Resource Centre for the Arts

eyeGO tickets for high school students are available by phone or at the Hall Box Office.

story:
This is the first production of Milky Way Coffee Roasters, a new collaboration of young theatre makers in the Boston area. We hope to expand the limits of theatre being produced in the region, especially in regards to stories about diverse people and in the genres we explore on stage. Milky Way Coffee Roasters wants to see queer and femme bodies telling not just their own stories, but the stories that belong to all of us- stories of fantasy and horror that show us the things that could be real, whether in our dreams or nightmares. We have been given a wonderful opportunity by the Mosesian Center for the Arts to use the Black Box theater at a discounted rate in order to make this possible, but we still need your support to bring us over the finish line!

Find out more about all of our team on Facebook!

Sloth Levine and Katie Grindeland both graduated from Emerson College in 2016 and have been working steadily in the Boston theatre scene. Levine is a director, writer, and designer who has worked with Stage Source on the Gender Explosion Initiative as an advocate for transgender and non-binary theatre makers and has been published on HowlRound and American Theatre. Grindeland is an actor, writer, designer, administrator, and teaching artist. You may have seen one or both of their work at Emerson Stage, SpeakEasy Stage Company, New York Theatre Workshop, Company One, American Repertory Theatre, Fresh Ink Theatre, New Repertory Theatre, Wheelock Family Theatre, or Brown Box Theatre Project. At Emerson College, the two collaborated on  a dark vaudevillian James and the Giant Peach, winning the 2016 EVVY Award for Best Theatrical Production, Best Director, Best Supporting Actress, and Best Lighting Design. 

Theatre is often done entirely out of passion, because it's hard (which we love) and doesn't pay well (which is an institutional problem we don't love). Everyone helping us put this together are friends who want to do this project because they either want to see themselves represented, or they want to create something where they get to help redefine the rules. And they're agreeing to do so for the tiniest of stipends. We (Sloth and Katie) are acting as volunteers on this project, and not paying ourselves, so more can go to them. We are so grateful to our team, and want to help propagate the idea that young artists should not have their time and talent unfairly compensated. I can't tell you how many times we've taken work that pays in nothing or close to nothing, because it's what we've been told we have to do in order to get the paid work. But now we're in a position where we get to decide, and regardless of who you are you deserve to be paid, gosh darnit! Every donation you make not only helps pay our incredible team, but also signs you up to be a part of a movement where we work together to define what every artist deserves for their time and skills. 

We've been lucky enough to receive a generous donation from the Bob Jolly Charitable Trust Fund, as well as an agreement with the space we're working in that will help us, no matter what, increase our artists' pay - your donations just help make it as equitable as possible. While ultimately this is a grassroots project, but Milky Way Coffee Roasters wants to be able to acknowledge the labor of all our artists as best we can, and the more support we receive the better we can do that. This production is almost entirely led by women and non-binary people who want to make an impact on theater in Boston. We believe it is important to start off our journey setting a precedent.

If you support Nosferatu, The Vampyr, you are taking the opportunity to support Milky Way Coffee Roasters from our very inception. We will consider you one of our founding patrons!

Check out the nifty perks you can receive!

Whether or not you can support us with a donation, help us spread the curse of the Nosferatu by sharing this on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Grindr, MySpace, FarmersOnly.com, or any other place you spend time online.

story:
Now Harlem... OR GENTRIFY THIS "The Play"

When Rita, a young white poet, moves to a gentrifying uptown block, her black neighbor Joanne, who often goes by the name "Harlem" exclaims, "Your being here is like another Applebee's we don't need." In a slam poetry type of showdown, Harlem is forced to choose between the cause she believes in and an answered prayer. Written for a society masked by centuries of pain, Now Harlem... OR GENTRIFY THIS! 

The Story 

Performer and playwright Latonia Phipps, derived inspiration for this project after moving to Harlem. In relocating, Phipps noticed that the Harlem of today was not the same beloved Harlem she grew up with. This left her to wonder, "What happened to the Harlem I read about in my history books?" Her experiences and questions became Now Harlem... OR GENTRIFY THIS! This production first premiered on July 10th, 2104 at University Settlement after Phipps was offered the opportunity to be apart of an Artist in Residence program. This piece had such a great impact on the L.E.S community Phipps decided to bring this show back to where it originated... HARLEM. 

WHAT WE NEED

To cover production fees as well as stationary costs for press packages presented to interested theaters companies.

  • Director                          $800
  • Light/media                  $600
  • Actors                              $700
  • Press packaging fees  $125

50 for 50 (Harlem Based Organizations)

Set up to bridge the gap between local organizations and the Harlem community. We need 50 Harlem based companies to make a $50 tax-deductible donation to help sponsor this project. In exchange we will feature your logo and company name on all of our social media outlets as well as a mention in the program for our next show.  


The Impact

This production experienced three nights of successful talk backs and a packed audience which included Harlem and L.E.S residence, local artist, housing representatives and community board members. What we learned....

  • Gentrification has happened and is happening.
  • People can empower themselves by being apart of their community boards.
  • Artist have a huge impact on this change and can help by using their gifts to keep this conversation going.

No Money... We still need YOU.

  • Share this link on your social media outlets. Help bring this play to Harlem.
  • Every little bit helps.

story:
SOY//I'M

Hola!Mi nombre es Maque Pereyra, bailarina y coreógrafa boliviana de danza contemporánea y quiero contarte esto:

//Hi!My name is Maque Pereyra bolivian contemporary dancer and choreographer, and I'm here to tell you this:


2 para ALEGRÍA//2 for JOY

Esta es la 2da vez que soy invitada a participar de BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO-IMPULSTANZ VIENA, como una de los 35 bailarines seleccionados de todas partes del mundo. El año pasado no pude asistir por falta de recursos económicos. Ahora pienso que si esta oportunidad viene a mí por segunda vez, es porque debo ser parte de esto!

Porque creo que como la única boliviana seleccionada para este proyecto es no solo un honor sino una gran oportunidad de desarrollarme como profesional, de aprender y compartir esta experiencia con mis colegas y amigos bailarines en Bolivia, porque cada viaje es una oportunidad, cada persona que conoces delinea tu camino. Porque  en Bolivia habemos muy buenos bailarines y lo que necesitamos son oportunidades para desarrollarnos.

Ayúdame a ser parte de BDC esta vez! 

// This is the 2nd time I got invited to BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO-IMPULSTANZ VIENNA, as one of the 35 dancers selected from all over the world. Last year I couldn’t make it because of lack of financial resources. I think now that if this opportunity comes to me twice it’s because I must be part of it!

I believe that, as the only bolivian dancer selected for this program, it’s not only an honor but an opportunity to develop myself as a dance professional, to learn and share this experience with the contemporary dance community in Bolivia, cause every journey is an opportunity, cause every person that you meet defines your path. Because in Bolivia there are really good dancers and what we need are development opportunities.

Help me to be part of BDC this time!


EL DINERO SE UTILIZARÁ EN//MONEY GOES TO

BONO DE PARTICIPACIÓN//PROJECT FEE:

  • 8.050 US DOLLARS

BOLETO DE AVIÓN (APROX.)//AIRFARE (APROX.)

  • 1.500 US DOLLARS

Haciendo una donación obtienes recompensas especiales!

//By donating you get special rewards!


El bono incluye

Todos los talleres especiales BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO // 4 talleres IMPULSTANZ // 1 proyecto de campo IMPULSTANZ // 20 tickets para performances IMPULSTANZ // Proyecto coreográfico por Ismael Ivo // Alojamiento en Viena // Per diem // Presentación del trabajo final en Viena // Presentación del trabajo final en São Paulo(incl.boleto de avión  Viena – São Paulo – Viena, per diem y alojamiento)

El bono NO incluye

Expensas de viaje del país de origen hacia Viena y de vuelta // Costos de visa // Seguro de salud.


Fee includes

• All special BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO workshops • 4 ImPulsTanz workshops

• 1 ImPulsTanz field project • 20 tickets for ImPulsTanz performances

• Choreography project by Ismael Ivo • Accommodation in Vienna• Per diem

• Presentation of the final work in Vienna • Presentation of the final work in São Paulo(incl. airfare Vienna – São Paulo – Vienna,per diem and accommodation)

Fee DOES NOT include

• Travel expenses from the home country to Vienna and back • Visa costs

• Health insurance


COMPÁRTELO!//SHARE IT!

Si no puedes hacer una donación, POR FAVOR comparte la campaña con tu familia, amigos y contactos en redes sociales. Te lo agradecería mucho.

//If you can’t donate PLEASE share the campaign with your family, friends and contacts on social networks. I would greatly appreciate it.


CRÉDITOS DEL VIDEO//VIDEO CREDITS

Director: Miguel Hilari

Música final//Final music: Guaracha sabrosona (Alberto Pedrazas)

Esta es la 2da vez que soy invitada a
participar de BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO-IMPULSTANZ VIENA, como una de los 35
bailarines seleccionados de todas partes del mundo. El año pasado no pude
asistir por falta de recursos económicos. Ahora pienso que si esta oportunidad
viene a mí por segunda vez, es porque debo ser parte de esto! 
Porque creo que como la única boliviana
seleccionada para este proyecto es no solo un honor sino una gran oportunidad
de desarrollarme como profesional, de aprender y compartir esta experiencia con
mis colegas y amigos bailarines en Bolivia, porque cada viaje es una oportunidad,
cada persona que conoces delinea tu camino. Porque  en Bolivia habemos muy buenos bailarines y lo
que necesitamos son oportunidades para desarrollarnos.
Ayúdame a ser parte de BDC esta
vez!  
// This is the
2nd time I got invited to BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO-IMPULSTANZ VIENNA, as one of the
35 dancers selected from all over the world. Last year I couldn’t make it
because of lack of financial resources. I think now that if this opportunity
comes to me twice it’s because I must be part of it! 
I believe that,
as the only bolivian dancer selected for this program, it’s not only an honor
but an opportunity to develop myself as a dance professional, to learn and
share this experience with the contemporary dance community in Bolivia, cause
every journey is an opportunity, cause every person that you meet defines your
path. Because in Bolivia there are really good dancers and what we need are
development opportunities.
Help me to be part
of BDC this time!

EN//MONEY GOES TO

8.050 US DOLLARS
BOLETO DE AVIÓN

1.500 US DOLLARS

Haciendo una donación
obtienes recompensas especiales!

special rewards!
El bono incluyeTodos los talleres especiales BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO // 4 talleres IMPULSTANZ // 1
proyecto de campo IMPULSTANZ // 20
tickets para performances IMPULSTANZ // Proyecto
coreográfico por Ismael Ivo // Alojamiento
en Viena // Per diem // Presentación del trabajo final en
Viena // Presentación del trabajo
final en São Paulo(incl.boleto de avión 
Viena – São Paulo – Viena, per diem y alojamiento)El bono NO incluyeExpensas de viaje del país de origen hacia Viena y de vuelta // Costos de visa // Seguro de salud.Fee includes
• All special BIBLIOTECA DO
CORPO workshops • 4 ImPulsTanz workshops
• 1 ImPulsTanz field project •
20 tickets for ImPulsTanz performances
• Choreography project by
Ismael Ivo • Accommodation in Vienna• Per diem
• Presentation of the final
work in Vienna • Presentation of the final work in São Paulo(incl. airfare
Vienna – São Paulo – Vienna,per diem and accommodation)

Fee DOES NOT include
• Travel expenses from the
home country to Vienna and back • Visa costs
• Health insuranceCOMPÁRTELO!//SHARE IT!
Si no puedes hacer una donación, POR FAVOR comparte la campaña con tu
familia, amigos y contactos en redes sociales. Te lo agradecería mucho.

donate PLEASE share the campaign with your family, friends and contacts on
social networks. I would greatly appreciate it.CRÉDITOS DEL

story:
In 1914, F. Scott Fitzgerald was an emerging artist, too...

The Underclassman is an original musical by Peter Mills (www.pcmills.com) and Cara Reichel (www.CaraReichel.com) which presents a fictionalized account of the college years of F. Scott Fitzgerald at Princeton and his first romance with debutante Ginevra King.  The show takes as inspiration both Fitzgerald’s own biography and his novel, This Side of Paradise.  It's an exciting and large-scale project, and we are undertaking this campaign to support our production expenses, including funds to cover costume design and sound design needs, which are considerable!

  • The show will be produced by the critically-acclaimed Prospect Theater Company at The Duke on 42nd Street (www.Dukeon42.org) from Nov. 9 - 23, 2014 for an initial run of 16 performances, with possible extension! 

  • Prospect is a 15-year-old non-profit organization that supports the development and production of new musicals by emerging artists.  The company’s work recently received a 2013 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Ensemble Performance and a 2013 National Theatre Grant from the American Theatre Wing (creator of the Tony Awards).

  • Music and lyrics are by one of Prospect's founding members, Peter Mills, and the book is by Mills and Cara Reichel, the company's Producing Artistic Director.  The production will be directed by Reichel, choreographed by Christine O'Grady, and music directed and orchestrated by Daniel Feyer.  Costume Design is by Sidney Shannon, and Scenic Design by Ann Bartek.

  • First produced by Prospect in 2005 as a showcase on the Lower East Side under the title The Pursuit of Persephone,  the show received Drama Desk nominations for Outstanding Score and Orchestrations. 
  • The centenary of Fitzgerald's Princeton career and World War I present the perfect moment to re-visit his early life, and investigate the forces that shaped one of America's greatest writers.

The Story

    1915.  Brilliantly talented, young F. Scott Fitzgerald is swept into the hierarchy of Ivy League society and the antics of the Princeton Triangle Club, in pursuit of the beautiful and elusive debutante Ginevra King.  Their romance inspired one of the greatest novels of the 20th century...

    Ginevra was Fitzgerald’s first love – the girl who got away.  Many scholars agree she is the model for the character of Daisy Buchanan in The Great Gatsby.  As Fitzgerald struggles to make a place for himself in Ginevra’s socially elite world, gaining status by writing and performing with the Triangle Club, he grows into his writer’s voice, mentored by his best friends and classmates, Edmund Wilson and John Peale Bishop, who also went on to become major literary figures.

    Combining contemporary musical theater story-telling technique with a traditional palette of early 20th century American song form and a strong dose of period musical comedy, The Underclassman parallels Fitzgerald’s story with a national coming-of-age narrative, as the country leaves a period of naïve isolationism and enters into the global conflict of World War I. 

    What We Need & What You Get

    We've already raised vital seed money for this production, including a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.  However, we still are seeking critical funds to meet our production budget, and help the show realize its design potential. 

    • We need to raise $15,000 through this campaign, to cover capital costs for costumes, sound, scenery, props, and lighting.  If possible we hope to exceed that amount to further enhance our resources and expand on an extremely tight budget!
    • Perks include exclusive behind-the-scenes access opportunities, opening night invites, signed posters by the company, an mp3 recording of a song from the show, and for those who are able to provide leadership funding, Honorary Producer credit and even the opportunity to name a character in the show!
    • Prospect Theater Company is a 501c3 non-profit, and all gifts are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law (less the cash value of any perks).

    The Impact

    After 9 years of development through readings and workshops, it is time to see this story live and breathe again on stage!  

    • Prospect’s goal with this production is to share with audiences an exuberant, heartfelt, and intelligent new work, expanding the American musical theater canon. 
    • Our production will finalize the show’s script and orchestrations, preparing it to move on to future production – on Broadway (!), in regional theaters, or in college productions around the country. 
    • This new and significantly re-vamped production will feature a cast of 19 young performers, an orchestra of 8, and an extensive creative and design team and backstage crew.  In total, the show will employ more than 50 emerging theater professionals.

    • We also will offer educational outreach opportunities to inform and excite both student and adult audiences about the early life of a major American literary figure, illuminating the roots of a classic novel. 

    Risks & Challenges

    As a company of artists, Prospect has a successful history of pushing the envelope and making theater magic with limited resources.  In our 15 years of bringing to life new musicals, we've learned how to stretch every dollar to create great art and important opportunities for emerging artists.  We also know the bottom line of what it will take to make something happen, and we're not quite there yet -- which is why we have launched this campaign and are asking for your donations!

    Musicals take a full complement of voices and bodies to truly come to life -- and with a cast of 19 and a band of 8, this will be the most ambitious show Prospect has embarked on in the company's history.  The period costumes alone for an ensemble of this size are daunting to pull together, not to mention all the other needs for proper sound design, lighting, scenery and props.  It's a big risk for us -- but a worthwhile one:  this production has the potential for huge impact on the careers of every single company member working on the show.  As an organization, we have the proven expertise and are ready to meet the challenge, so we hope you can give us a boost!

    We Need Your Encouragement.

    We hope you will lend your support to Prospect’s online campaign for our upcoming production of The Underclassman.  However, if you are not able to contribute at this time, please help by spreading the word about the campaign and performances to your social network!  Tickets go on sale Sept. 1st.  Visit www.ProspectTheater.org for details.  We hope to see you at the theater this fall...

    Meet the Composer

    "Peter Mills may be the cleverest new songwriter on the New York theatre scene.  His lyrics often leave me shaking my head with envy."
    - Stephen Schwartz

    PETER MILLS (composer/lyricist/co-bookwriter) is one of America’s most celebrated new musical theater writers.  Recently, he received the 2014 Donna Perret Rosen Award from NYC’s Second Stage Theatre and the 2011 Cole Porter Award from the ASCAP Foundation.  He was also honored to receive the 2010 Kleban Prize for lyrics, the 2007 Fred Ebb Award for emerging songwriters, 2006 Drama Desk Award nominations, the 2003 Richard Rodgers New Horizons Award from ASCAP, and a 2002 grant from the Jonathan Larson Performing Arts Foundation.  In addition to the twelve musicals he has penned for Prospect Theater Company, of which he is a founding member, Pete is currently writing lyrics for the Broadway-aimed production of The Honeymooners musical.  Peter holds an M.F.A. in Musical Theater Writing from NYU, and a degree in English/Dramatic Literature from Princeton University.  Visit www.pcmills.com for more information!

    About Prospect Theater Company

    Prospect Theater Company is one of America's leading producers of new musical theater, and was honored to receive a 2013 National Theatre Company Grant from the American Theatre Wing (home of the Tony Awards), in recognition of its contributions to the dynamism of the national theatre community.  Since 2000, the company has fully produced more than 25 premiere musicals in New York City, in addition to mounting new plays and numerous re-inventions of classic works.  Year-round, Prospect supports developmental opportunities for emerging musical theater artists, especially through its annual musical theater writers lab and Summer Intensive Training Program for teens.  Notable productions include: the Drama Desk Award-winning Working (2012), Jasper in Deadland (2014), the Drama Desk nominated Tamar of the River (2013), Unlock'd (2013), Iron Curtain (2006, 2011), Myths and Hymns (2012), With Glee (2010), The Blue Flower (2008), Golden Boy of the Blue Ridge (2009), The Hidden Sky (2010), Illyria (2002, 2008), and the Drama Desk nominated The Pursuit of Persephone (2005).  For more information, please visit www.ProspectTheater.org

story:
FOLLOWING THEIR ENORMOUS OPEN-AIR SUCCESS THIS SUMMER,

THE GRASSROOTS SHAKESPEARE COMPANY, LONDON IS BACK TO ANNOUNCE THE OPENING OF THEIR INDOOR WINTER SEASON.

Grassroots introduction to their winter season will be celebrated by a histrionic party of events that aims to recreate an atmosphere reflective of the Elizabethan era. In its secret show location; complete with some period costume, candles, mulled wine and a homely wood fire; this humble and family friendly event welcomes all to celebrate one of Shakespeare's most farcical comedies in a bespoke mock-Tudor setting. This interactive experience promises to immerse its audience straight into 16th Century London and guarantees a fun-filled evening unlike anything Grassroots have offered before.

Following its interactive performances in the East of London, Grassroots will then support The Complete Works of William Shakespeare at The New Red Lion Theatre in Islington. Presenting two exclusive late-night performances, Grassroots will be providing a wonderfully intimate in-house experience for all involved.

.......................................................................................................................................


'This is the short and long of it...

In a time of near-constant arts cuts, Grassroots Shakespeare is turning to the original practices of Elizabethan touring players to bypass expensive ticket prices and funding bureaucracy to take Shakespeare directly to audiences. This heady mix of professional actors with no director, no crew, gender-blind casting, no ‘fourth wall’, using only cue scripts and a few days rehearsal, peels back centuries of theatre history and analysis to present the text in a fresh and exciting way. The shows are not stuffy, self-important, or difficult to understand. They're fast-paced, interactive events appealing to audiences of all ages and backgrounds – accessible, original, and fun!

'As good luck would have it...'

In true Grassroots style, the script will be suitably abridged to help deliver a well-rounded and coherent version of the play within an hour and a half. As part of the company's ethos it's important to Grassroots that the experience of classical theatre (performed in any setting) can provide an intimate viewing that a broad range of theatregoers can enjoy. As a “pop-up theatre company” Grassroots aims to challenge other companies by continually offering something new to their audiences, albeit an interactive event prior to performance, a musical version of the text (whereby the entire cast learnt to play instruments in less than a few hours), performing in torrential rain or a classical performance told through a qualified sign linguist in aid of The Shakespeare Festival 2012 – no task is too great for Grassroots Shakespeare! Best known for our comedic timing and outlandish characterisation we aim to bring a merriness of all shapes and sizes to London for this winter season.


'Why, then the world's mine oyster...'

Grassroots, re-cast in London prior to the opening of A Midsummer Nights Dream, August 2011, developed into a company now comprised of Brits, Americans, a Canadian and a German. Importantly for them, creating a diversity amongst the ensemble was fundamental if they were to connect to a contemporary society – both nationally and internationally. This somewhat cosmopolitan edge on Shakespeare gave room for so many different interpretations of the text and now with an enormous following in the USA and their first four months in London opening to enormous success, they have every intention of continuing their efforts to get Grassroots Shakespeare on the theatre map and onto stages throughout the UK and Europe.


So, why are we here?

The thing that many people aren't aware of with Grassroots Shakespeare is that we are a non-profit organisation that exists without funding of any kind. Performing solely with unpaid actors to a free audience we strive to bring live classical performance to anybody willing to watch. Although, communities have welcomed our work with open arms we still feel there is an enormous market for our interactive and cultural events to be performed on a larger scale. We want to stimulate and encourage people of all generations, backgrounds and ages to enjoy our work and feel inspired by the wholesome sense of community it brings.

How can your donations help us?

Currently Grassroots Shakespeare has a kitty of £0. Following the success of our open-air summer production "A Midsummer Nights Dream" we were offered over £1000 by our public audience to which we have paid towards our residency this winter season. However, we are desperate to immerse ourselves into the production in time for the Christmas period and embark on a full scale event.

What we receive will pay towards our venue and costume hire, advertisement costs (e.g. programmes, flyers, posters), audience refreshments and hopefully if there's anything left a round of drinks for our actors! Importantly for us we want to not only develop this performance, but create a fund that can continue to develop the company and our plan to maximise the interest for Shakespeare.

Who do we intend to help?

One of our big plans for 2012 includes a THEATRE IN EDUCATION TOUR. It would be wonderful if part of the fund could support our campaign to get into schools and educate children about the heritage of classical text and further about how theatre and creativity can stimulate learning.

Alongside this, Grassroots Shakespeare believe whole-heartedly in supporting  others. One way we do this is by fundraising in support of our two chosen charities.


Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research (c) and Myeloma UK (c). 


In this particular case the following breakdown applies:


FOR THE FIRST SET OF DONATIONS UP TO £500 10% WILL BE DONATED.


FOR THE SECOND SET OF DONATIONS UP TO £1000 20% WILL BE DONATED.


FOR EVERY DONATION RECEIVED AFTER THAT 30% WILL BE DONATED.


Each percentage will be equally split between THE TWO CHARITIES - so the more you give to us, the more we give to them!


To see more information on our chosen charities and the work we aim to do on their behalf please visit our Twitter account on: @grassrootsLON 


Please do not be put off by the donation total being recorded in American dollars, Grassroots Shakespeare London will receive all of your donations in BRITISH STERLING.


How much should you donate?

Absolutely anything you can afford. We are grateful to receive any financial support we can and accept it with enormous gratitude.


NOTE: Each charitable donation will be listed with thanks, in our programme and further on our website.

Please do not be put off by the donation total being recorded in American dollars, Grassroots Shakespeare London will receive all of your donations in BRITISH STERLING.

.......................................................................................................................................


GRASSROOTS SHAKESPEARE CO. was founded in 2009 in Utah, USA. Originally developed through an ensemble of actors its simplistic rehearsal style; compressed rehearsal period, minimal set, costume and props and finally no director; began to mirror that of Shakespeare's own theatre practices. Following enormous local success and increased demand the company began to explore and expand further. Henceforth, the company's new ethos proclaimed their practical objective would reflectively and sensitively communicate to a live public audience, promising to do so through the use of traditional performance methods of the Elizabethan era.


The Grassroots Shakespeare Company UK, having launched to great success in August 2011 with A Midsummer Nights Dream now work collaboratively with the US company running a similar theatrical programme throughout the year in London.

The Merry Wives of Windsor will be the ninth Grassroots production and second for the London based company.


Please do not be put off by the donation total being recorded in American dollars, Grassroots Shakespeare London will receive all of your donations in BRITISH STERLING.
