summer production "A Midsummer Nights Dream" we were
offered over £1000 by our public audience to which we have paid
towards our residency this winter season. However, we are desperate
to immerse ourselves into the production in time for the Christmas
period and embark on a full scale event.


What we receive will pay towards our venue and costume hire, advertisement costs
(e.g. programmes, flyers, posters), audience refreshments and
hopefully if there's anything left a round of drinks for our actors!
Importantly for us we want to not only develop this performance, but
create a fund that can continue to develop the company and our plan
to maximise the interest for Shakespeare.




Who do we intend
to help?


One of our big plans
for 2012 includes a THEATRE IN EDUCATION TOUR. It would be wonderful
if part of the fund could support our campaign to get into schools
and educate children about the heritage of classical text and further
about how theatre and creativity can stimulate learning.


Alongside this, Grassroots Shakespeare believe whole-heartedly in supporting  others. One way we do this is by fundraising in support of our two chosen charities. 

Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research (c) and Myeloma UK (c). 

In this particular case the following breakdown applies:

FOR THE FIRST SET OF DONATIONS UP TO £500 10% WILL BE DONATED.

FOR THE SECOND SET OF DONATIONS UP TO £1000 20% WILL BE DONATED.

FOR EVERY DONATION RECEIVED AFTER THAT 30% WILL BE DONATED.

Each percentage will be equally split between THE TWO CHARITIES - so the more you give to us, the more we give to them!

To see more information on our chosen charities and the work we aim to do on their behalf please visit our Twitter account on: @grassrootsLON 


Please do not be put off by the donation total being recorded in American dollars, Grassroots Shakespeare London will receive all of your donations in BRITISH STERLING.





How much should
you donate?


Absolutely anything you can
afford. We are grateful to receive any financial support we can and
accept it with enormous gratitude.


NOTE: Each charitable
donation will be listed with thanks, in our programme and further on
our website. 
Please do not be put off by the donation total being recorded in American dollars, Grassroots Shakespeare London will receive all of your donations in BRITISH STERLING.
.......................................................................................................................................


GRASSROOTS
SHAKESPEARE CO. was founded in 2009 in Utah, USA. Originally
developed through an ensemble of actors its simplistic rehearsal
style; compressed rehearsal period, minimal set, costume and props
and finally no director; began to mirror that of Shakespeare's own
theatre practices. Following enormous local success and increased
demand the company began to explore and expand further. Henceforth,
the company's new ethos proclaimed their practical objective would
reflectively and sensitively communicate to a live public audience,
promising to do so through the use of traditional performance methods
of the Elizabethan era. 







The
Grassroots Shakespeare Company UK, having launched to great success
in August 2011 with A Midsummer Nights Dream now work collaboratively
with the US company running a similar theatrical programme throughout
the year in London.






The
Merry Wives of Windsor will be the ninth Grassroots production
and second for the London based company. 



Please do not be put off by the donation total being recorded in American dollars, Grassroots Shakespeare London will receive all of your donations in BRITISH STERLING.

story:
Women of Color Human Rights Theatre Project

 

Women of Color Productions, Inc. is a non-for-profit company that produces, creates and presents new plays, classical plays, musicals, performance art pieces, film festivals and TV projects by or about Women of Color.  Our projects are multicultural and deal with the alternative political and cultural perspectives from the past, present and future.

The Women of Color Human Rights Theatre Project will present workshop productions of five one-act plays that deal with human rights issues from the perspective of characters who are women of color.  The three playwrights in our 2011 Playwright Development Program, Kristine M. Reyes, Jorshinelle Taleon-Sonza and Jacqueline Wade, began researching and writing their plays in April 2011 under the guidance of dramaturg Maxine Kern.


From the Philippines to Rwanda, Nazi Germany to New York City, these plays span time and place in order to shed light on the many injustices suffered by women of color throughout the world’s history.  While each story is unique, there is a common thread that proves the strength and resiliency of these women characters, even in the face of tremendous hardship.

Your contributions and support will help make this project a reality, and allow these untold stories to finally be heard. 

 

Performances are scheduled for: 
June 22-24 and June 29-July 1 (additional dates will be added)
 
Location:  Joria Productions Theatre
260 West 36th Street, 3rd Floor
New York, NY
 


THE PLAYS

 

Lena’s Way by Jorshinelle Taleon-Sonza

Lena’s Way is a story about first love in the time of Philippine martial law.  A young girl awakens to the wonders of first love in the midst of violence and chaos.  Her family sabotages that love, her loved one betrays her and what she does next surprises everyone, including herself.

 

Triptych Knot by Jacqueline Wade

Triptych Knot is three short plays that explore what happens to women who are entangled and stuck in a web of unbearable situations when their human rights have been violated or taken away.  One woman is from Rwanda in, Mama Africa, another is from Nazi Germany in, Sterilization, and the third, Mary Theresa is stuck in the New York City Board of Education, "rubber room."   How do they find freedom and survive?

 

Lola Luning’s First Steps by Kristine M. Reyes

As Lola Luning’s worsening dementia causes the trauma of her young life in the Philippines during WWII to resurface, her granddaughter Gabriela struggles to uncover the whole story.  Meanwhile, Lola Luning’s daughter Virgie denies that what’s happening is anything more than the workings of a failing mind, exposing her inability to confront the truth about her own past.  Can Gabriela put together the pieces of her family’s history before Lola Luning falls deeper into dementia and their story is lost forever?

 

THE PLAYWRIGHTS

 

Kristine M. Reyes is a Filipina American playwright raised and based in New York City.   Her one-act plays Quarter Century Baby and Something Blue were produced as part of Diverse City Theater Company’s (DCT) Pearl Project: A Filipino-American Theater Festival at The Clurman Theatre at Theatre Row, July 2010.  In 2011, her 10-Minute play Ready, Aim…Fire! was presented twice, first in Primary Stages Einhorn School of Performing Arts’ (ESPA) Detention Series, and then in The Asian American Women Playwrights Short Play Festival, co-presented by Actors’ Equity Association and Leviathan Lab.  She is a Playwright Associate at DCT where she was a First Draft Fellow for her full-length play Queen for a Day.  Kristine is a Co-Director of the Leviathan Lab Asian American Women Writers Workshop, a Mary Louise Rockwell Scholar at ESPA and a member of The Dramatists Guild.  www.kristinemreyes.com

 

Jorshinelle Taleon-Sonza holds a Ph.D. in Postcolonial Literature from Drew University and an MFA degree from the Actors Studio at The New School.  Her play The Encounter was produced by Diverse City Theater Company as part of The Pearl Project: A Filipino American Theater Festival at The Clurman Theatre in 2010.  Her trilogy of plays, Migration Blues, was produced by the University Initiative at The New School; and her play, Sandman, was presented at the Circle in the Square Theater as part of the Actors Studio repertory season.  Sonza’s play, Dog Days in America, earned a spot in the University of Massachusetts Southeast Asian Women Playwright Archive.  Cold Flesh, her one-act play, was presented at The Clurman Theatre in 2005.  Other awards include the Philippine Centennial Literary prize for her play, Domestic Helper, and the Palanca Literary Award for her play, Pure.

 

Jacqueline Wade is a graduate of Temple University's Theatre Department and Circle in the Square Two Year Actor's Training Program.  She is a member of the professional acting unions, AEA and SAG.  As a playwright, she has written over 20 plays and performance art pieces, including Juneteenth, A Caribbean Christmas Carol, Phillis Wheatley: The African Muse, Black Panther Women, Women in Comedy, Madam C.J. Walker, The Three Sides of Anita Hill, Miles Davis, Tituba, Garvey's Wives, Zora’s Tales, Nat Turner, Rosa, Mae.  Her plays have been produced at and/or toured many theatres and festivals, including New York International Fringe Festival, LaMaMa ETC., Henry Street Settlement, 40 Queens Libraries, African Meeting House Museum, Mary McLeod Bethune Council House Museum, Old South Meeting House Museum, Harlem School of the Arts, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, New York University, York College Performing Arts Center, Queens Theatre in the Park, Black Spectrum Theatre, Jamaica Arts Center, Sun Dog Productions, Riverbank State Park, Vinnette Carroll Theatre.  Jacqueline’s mission is to bring theatre to the people and to present the side of history that is not often told.  In 2002, Franklin Westbrooks was nominated for an AUDELCO AWARD for his role in her play, Miles Davis.  Jacqueline has been awarded the Walt Disney Pride Rock Grant and the Ethel Surgent Grant for $15,000, which helped to fund the touring of her plays to over 30 culturally deprived schools and institutions in Pennsylvania.  She has worked extensively with youth to motivate them to be positive, to have empowerment, and to be creative through workshops, art-in-education programs, and creative dramatics programs as a director, playwright, and acting teacher.  She was honored by Delta Zeta Chapter in Philadelphia for teaching cultural literacy through drama, and recently awarded a writing residency at Virginia Center for the Creative Arts.  Ms. Wade has directed and produced many plays and is co-founder of Through Her Eyes Women of Color Film Festival.  She is the founder and executive producer of Women of Color Productions, Inc.

story:
You can now purchase tickets through smarttix.com!

Lunge is a new dance ensemble created by Billy Bell. Originally from South Florida, Billy now trains at The Juilliard School and was recently on FOX’S SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE. He now aspires to start his own project by project dance ensemble. With access to some of the world’s best dancers and award winning choreographers, it’s a match made in heaven. To get his start, he wants to create not a dance performance, but a dance experience. He plans on producing an evening performance that is part traditional proscenium theater and part dance installation. He needs your help to do so. He needs to raise around $5000 to cover the dancer’s pay, travel, studio and performance rental fees, crew and advertisement. He can in return give anything from a personalized “Thank You!” to free Lunge Dance experience tickets and your name in the program. Please help fund this project and help Billy Bell and his dancers create. Also, don’t forget to spread the word via facebook, twitter, etc…
Thanks!

story:
Our Story

Here, comes a new comedic extravaganza, Show Girls in Drag.  Yes, it is a parody of the 1995 classic cult classic with an irresitably hilarious twist:  The lead roles made famous by Elizabeth Berkley and Gina Gershon will be played by drag queens. This will be an interactive stage show directed by Stephen Guarino from ABC's Happy Endings and the Big Gay Sketch Show. Stephen is donating his time because he believes in this project and we hope you will too.


The Impact

YOU WILL BE WHO WE THANK FOR MAKING THIS SHOW HAPPEN
 

The LGBT community is very talented and I am always impressed with the quality of performance when I attend a drag show. I wanted to create an outlet for them to do more than just lip-sync. I loved the movie Show Girls and thought what a great way to poke fun of this classic but do a show using even more dramatic actors and actresses. We are an all inclusive show.  Straights, gays and everything in between will be a part of this.This show is about coming together and laughing because in the end laughter is the best medicine.


What We Need & What You Get

As our way of thanking you for helping us get the show on its feet donors will receive any number of Show Girls gifts: SWAG BAG, Celebrity After Party Tickets, T-Shirts & FREE VIP Tickets for any 2011 production, Cast-Signed Posters, FREE regular tickets and so much more! 


The Show Girls in Drag show will be a one of a kind experience that you can be a part of no matter where you live or what you do. You can be a major part of this production by just donating. No work needed just a few clicks on the mouse and you could be one of the Executive Producers of this show.


Other Ways You Can Help

(SPREAD THE WORD!!! Show Girls in Drag  is nothing with out people like you. So please pass this on to any friend, co-worker, acquaintance you know that would appreciate the opportunity to help. Thank you for reading this hope to see you at the show stay tuned www.showgirlsindrag.com

story:
Our Story

Spontaneous Shakespeare Players is a group of professional independent theatre artists who bring the spontaneity and fun of Shakespeare's plays to modern audiences.  Shakespeare’s theatre was a theatre for the people, from monarch to groundling and everyone in between.  SSP strives to keep that tradition alive by entertaining people of all ages with powerful, engaging, and spontaneous performances.  By using Elizabethan performance techniques, which involve limited to no rehearsal, we give our audiences a historical taste of how Shakespeare's plays would have originally been performed and entertain audiences with the same moment-to-moment vivacity that made theatre the premier form of entertainment in Shakespeare’s day.

The Impact

This year, in addition to providing free, live summer theatre in Central Park, we expanded our work to include educational programs.  We offer competitive and economical prices in order for schools to incorporate live arts programs into their curriculum during a time of drastic arts education budget cuts. Although our style of unrehearsed Shakespeare is incredibly cost effective—we don’t pay for elaborate sets or expensive performance spaces—we do need to raise money to compensate our artists and teachers and pay for costumes, props, publicity, educational materials, and park permits. 

What We Need & What You Get

This year, as we prepare for our upcoming production of Twelfth Night and continue to expand our educational curriculum, we are launching a fundraising campaign to raise $4,000 through individual donations.  Your support is incredibly important to us, as a majority of SSP’s budget comes from the generous support of individuals like you. 


If you are able to donate to our project, we would like to list your name as one of our supporters on both SSP’s website (www.spontaneousshakespeare.com) and in Twelfth Night’s program.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially, please help spread the word about SSP by liking us on Facebook and bringing anyone and everyone you know out to our FREE shows in Central Park May 14th, 15th, 21st, 28th and 29th.  All shows are at 3pm at Central Park's Summit Rock.  (Enter Central Park at Central Park West and 85th Street. Go up the hill and to the right. A sign for Summit Rock will be on your right past the playground.)

story:
For only $55, you can sponsor a New York City teenager for one week of participation in our unique educational theatre program... 

Or for as little as $15 you will help to ensure a future for New York's most cutting edge educational theatre program!

Keen Teens gives students the opportunity to work with professional artists in a professional setting.  Students participate in rehearsals for 12 weeks and then go through the real-world process of getting the plays ready for performance and presenting them at an Off-Broadway Theatre.  And to top it all off, there is NO CHARGE FOR ANY STUDENTS TO PARTICIPATE IN KEEN TEENS. 

Your tax-deductible contribution will go a long way towards ensuring that we finish off this season strongly. Our budget is as tight as we can make it and we will be producing the plays with extremely limited resources, but certain costs (theatre rental, rehearsal space, minimal fees for our professional artists) are impossible to do without, and we want to ensure that that all 33 students get the full experience of being involved with the exceptional plays the writers created exclusively for Keen Teens. We will be presenting the shows in an Off-Broadway production at the Clurman Theatre at Theatre Row from May 6-8th, and expect to continue our trend of selling out all five performances.

OUR SHOWS

VIRTUAL CONGRESS
Written by Mike Lew; Directed by David F. Chapman

THE FLIP SIDE
Written by Jenny Schwartz; Directed by Sarah Cameron Sunde

THE BORING-EST POEM IN THE WORLD
Written by Greg Kotis; Directed by John Clancy

OUR IMPACT

The impact of Keen Teens on students and drama teachers is tremendous, and will grow with each year of our program. The students who participate in our rehearsal process are the immediate beneficiaries. But students across the United States are already also benefiting. The Playscripts catalogue, which lists the plays along with a synopsis and production history, is mailed to 40,000 recipients. This gives students and administrators all over the world access to our plays for reading, acting class work and for production and participation in Theatre Festivals. Playscripts also makes a large portion of each script available through their online catalogue so teachers and actors have the opportunity to read some of it before purchasing. 

To date, there have been 121 licensed performances of our plays and 1,720 copies of our scripts have been purchased by teachers and students at high schools all across the globe, including the United States, Canada, New Zealand, Japan, Australia, Germany, Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Switzerland! That means that approximately 15,480 students are working on Keen Teens plays.

OUR STUDENTS


During our casting process, we are committed to bringing students from vastly different geographic, economic, and educational backgrounds together. They come from Suffolk County to Rockland County, from Jersey City to the Upper East Side to audition for our program. These are students who ordinarily would not have met each other nor worked together at this point in their lives. Some students have professional experience, and some have never been in a play before. We continue to see that this diversity defines the heart of the program. Teaching students that true theatre is about finding your own voice and learning how to listen to someone and respond to them truthfully and honestly continues to be our greatest goal each week.

~

Tickets to Keen Teens are now on sale and are only $18: 
http://www.telecharge.com/BehindTheCurtain.aspx?prodid=8482


Keen Company is a 501(c)(3) Not-for-Profit Company so your donation is tax-deductible.

voice and learning how to listen to someone and respond to them truthfully and
honestly continues to be our greatest goal each week.~Tickets to Keen Teens are now on sale and are only $18: 
http://www.telecharge.com/BehindTheCurtain.aspx?prodid=8482
Keen
Company is a 501(c)(3) Not-for-Profit Company so your donation is tax-deductible.

story:
About Us:

The organization was established December 2012. The organization's founders, Dedrick Lee Anthony and Colleen Bialas have been passionate about the performing arts in West Michigan, specifically Muskegon County. As youth they both were highly involved and nurtured in the performing arts community in Muskegon County. Both participated in many outreach programs, theater productions, student showcases and dance companies.

Dedrick moved to New York City to further his aspirations while Colleen moved to California to reach her goals as a performing artist. With overwhelming support from family, friends, mentors and the community, they both have a combined total of 25 years of professional dance experience.

In 2012, Dedrick and Colleen came together and realized the need to enrich the performing arts and arts education within Muskegon County, and set on a mission to uplift and empower the community.

The anthony + bialas danse project's main mission is to cultivate artists from primary school through college to a higher level of dance performance through arts education and training from experienced dance professionals from across the nation. The organization hopes to make greater performing arts opportunities available to youth of Muskegon County, as well as to exhibit the advantages of learning and creating dance. 

The organization's objective is to afford youth of all social and economic backgrounds in West Michigan the experience to participate in performing arts opportunities. Participants will benefit from: 

  • Masterclasses in ballet, modern, contemporary, jazz, musical theatre and hip hop led by various guest artists from across the nation.
  • Workshops/Lectures led by various guest artists, that will train students in many facets of building a dance career.
  • Annual performances that will help promote and enrich the fine arts of the community.

Dedrick Lee Anthony:

Dedrick Lee Anthony is a graduate of The Ailey School, the official school of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre. He has performed in regional theatre productions such as Godspell, Jesus Christ Superstar, Ain't Misbehavin' and Guys & Dolls. Dedrick has had the opportunities to perform in Switzerland, France, Germany, Belgium, Hawaii, and the Bahamas. He has worked with many major companies such as School Zone, Norwegian Cruise Lines, ABC, Adidas, Google, L'Oreal Professionnel, and Vogue Italia. Currently residing in New York City, he teaches nationally and internationally and is an award winning choreographer. 

Colleen Bialas:

Colleen Bialas graduated from the prestigious Interlochen Arts Academy in Northern Michigan. After high school she was a trainee with the Richmond Ballet in Richmond, VA.  She then relocated to Santa Barbara, CA where she performed with the State Street Ballet and Ballet Santa Barbara. She graduated from San Francisco State University, where she studied Dance and Biology. She has performed in China, Belgium, France, Germany, Austria and countless stages across the United States. Currently, she is a dance instructor in San Francisco.

Our Campaign:

The anthony + bialas danse project aspires to create programming for the community that is new and innovative. Through a combination of workshops, masterclasses and performances the anthony + bialas danse project wants to reach the largest possible audience and leave an everlasting impression in the arts community.

In December 2012, the anthony + bialas danse project successfully provided public masterclasses to over 100 students at Cassell Gymnastics and Dance Training Center and Zeeland High School in West Michigan. In March 2013, the organization held dance workshops at West Michigan Academy of the Arts and Academics reaching over 200 students. In April 2013, the anthony + bialas danse project held another series of public masterclasses to over 70 students at Cassell Gymnastics and Dance Training Center and Spotlight Dance Academy.

 

The organization's main goal for 2013 is to double our student enrollment by:

  • Resuming masterclass series at local dance studios.
  • Hosting an evening of dance performances in collaboration with a local performing arts organization. These performances will featuring local students as well as distinguished guest artists and will captivate West Michigan audiences.
  • Producing a summer dance intensive involving dance professionals, instructors from across the country and local talent.

The anthony + bialas danse project is looking to expand our programing and services to the community. In order to do so, the organization needs your support. 

Contributions:

Contributions to our campaign will help us mentor and bring exciting performing arts opportunities to West Michigan students. We want to bring world class artists to inspire students and audiences alike. Please help by donating what you can.

Thank you so much for your support in helping us to inspire a new generation of young performing artists and audiences in West Michigan!

Dedrick Lee Anthony + Colleen Bialas, Artistic Directors

story:
WHAT IS PLAYBACK THEATRE?
Playback is a unique form of improvised social change theater practiced in 50 countries around the world for community-building, conflict-resolution and celebration.  Volunteers from the audience share important moments from their lives, and actors instantly "play back" their stories using drama, dance, song, and music.

WHY IS PLAYBACK IMPORTANT?
As seen by the ugliness of the recent elections, we live in a deeply divided country.  We believe Playback Theatre -- a form of embodied empathy -- can be a powerful tool in these times, helping to open peoples' hearts to each other across divides. 

“I want us to organize, to tell the personal stories that create empathy, which is the most revolutionary emotion.”  - Gloria Steinem

EXAMPLES OF THE POWER OF PLAYBACK THEATRE
Virginia from Memphis Playback: We have honored stories of white and African-American people working together to stop youth violence in Memphis, the city where Dr. King was murdered.

Anne-Liese from New Orleans Playback Theatre:  We have helped survivors of Katrina tell their deepest stories to heal and move their lives forward.

Armand from Living Arts Playback Ensemble: We have helped descendants of Holocaust survivors and Nazis dialogue and transform their legacies of historical trauma into constructive action.


LIGHT THE FIRE OF EMPATHY
If you, too, want to help ignite empathy across divisions, please join our “30 Stories, 30 Days” campaign today. You will help Playback North America grow the powerful work of Playback ensembles such as the ones above.  The funds from this campaign will support us to:

  • Gather 30 powerful stories of how Playback Theatre has fostered healing or built bridges across painful social divides.  We’ll use these to initiate potential partnerships with activist groups working on these issues, as well as to promote the work of 76 Playback troupes across North America.
  • Increase effectiveness by interviewing Playback troupes that work on key timely social issues, including environmental action, immigration, anti-bullying in schools, cross-racial dialogue.  We’ll share the lessons learned via teleconferences, YouTube and more.  
  • Connect troupes working on common issues. We will then together seek foundation funding for multi-troupe projects where Playback’s healing power on specific issues can be amplified and documented.  
  • Collaborate on these endeavors with the Centre for Playback Theatre and the International Playback Theatre Network.

We see this as the first stage of a many-year project to build empathy and understanding across America’s chronic divisions through the engaging medium of Playback Theatre.

HOW TO JOIN THE CAMPAIGN

  1. Donate to Playback North America - help us raise $3,000 in 30 days.  Contributions are tax-deductible.
  2. Spread hope.  Let your friends and colleagues know about this unique tool for building empathy. Share this page and encourage them to join the campaign.
  3. Share your story. If you have experienced Playback’s power, please take ten minutes to write a few sentences about your experience on our Facebook page.

WHO WE ARE
When we read appeals we always wonder, “Who is behind this project?” We are Christopher and Anne Ellinger, Amber Espar and Eva Vander Giessen from the Boston area, working to grow Playback North America. Anne and Christopher have been successfully launching nonprofits for 20 years and joyfully performing Playback for over a decade.  Amber and Eva are organizers, teachers and performers.  Over the past three years, with involvement of many others, the four of us have helped to launch Playback North America, a network to support the 76 Playback Theatre troupes across the continent. Learn more here about Playback Theatre.


Please donate, share and join in. It is time for empathy to bridge the divides.

Your story keepers,
Christopher, Anne, Amber & Eva
on behalf of Playback North America

P.S. If you would like more detailed information or to consider a more substantial contribution, please contact Eva Vander Giessen at eva@artsrising.net or 415.844.0986.

P.P.S. For reassurance that we have the skills to pull off this project, you can see what we’ve done the past three years to build Playback North America and browse the other nonprofits Anne and Christopher launched:  Bolder Giving, More Than Money, Arts Rising and True Story Theater. Or call us!

story:
Short Summary

I'm entering a stage in comedy where I have the opportunity to travel to interesting places to perform, but the only way for comics like me to make a living on these performances is by selling merchandise as well. I believe recording an album is far more intimate and artistically satisfying than simply making a t-shirt to sell. 

I also desperately need your attention and prefer to have it for 45 minutes. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

I'm aiming to raise $2500 which would cover the cost of some recording equipment, a sound engineer to record, mix, and master the album, and a distributor to print 1,000 copies of the album as well as make it available on iTunes, Amazon, and Spotify. Also, some of the money is taken by Indiegogo (about 7% I believe between their commission and PayPal transfer fees.)

Anyone who gives more than $25 receives a copy of the album, and take a look at the more specific perks to see what weird stuff you can get for greater donations. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's completely OK. However, if you'll be in the New York area on May 22, I'd love for you to come to the recording at Union Hall in Park Slope, Brooklyn at 8 PM to laugh and support and, mainly, laugh. 

Also, please spread the word about the fundraiser and the show! Forward this project to anyone you think might be interested in helping out.
